document: Lufthansa flies back to profit Lufthansa has returned to profit in 2004 after posting huge losses in 2003. In a preliminary report, Lufthansa announced net profits of 400m euros ($527.61m; £274.73m), compared with a loss of 984m euros in 2003. Operating profits were at 380m euros, ten times more than in 2003. Lufthansa was hit in 2003 by tough competition and a dip in demand following the Iraq war and the killer SARS virus. Lufthansa was also hit by troubles at Lufthansa's US catering business. Last year, Lufthansa showed signs of recovery even as some European and US airlines were teetering on the brink of bankruptcy. The board of Lufthansa has recommended paying a 2004 dividend of 0.30 euros per share. In 2003, shareholders did not get a dividend. Lufthansa said that Lufthansa will give all the details of Lufthansa's 2004 results on 23 March.

Japanese growth grinds to a halt Growth in Japan evaporated in the three months to September, sparking renewed concern about an economy not long out of a decade-long trough. Output in the three months to September grew just 0.1%, an annual rate of 0.3%. Exports - the usual engine of recovery - faltered, while domestic demand stayed subdued and corporate investment also fell short. The growth falls well short of expectations, but does mark a sixth straight quarter of expansion. an economy not long out of a decade-long trough had stagnated throughout the 1990s, experiencing only brief spurts of expansion amid long periods in the doldrums. One result was deflation - prices falling rather than rising - which made Japanese shoppers cautious and kept Japanese shoppers from spending. The effect was to leave an economy not long out of a decade-long trough more dependent than ever on exports for an economy not long out of a decade-long trough's recent recovery. But high oil prices have knocked 0.2% off the growth rate, while the falling dollar means products shipped to the US are becoming relatively more expensive. The performance for the third quarter marks a sharp downturn from earlier in the year. The first quarter showed annual growth of 6.3%, with the second showing 1.1%, and economists had been predicting as much as 2% this time around. "Exports slowed while capital spending became weaker," said Hiromichi Shirakawa, chief economist at UBS Securities in Tokyo. "Personal consumption looks good, but Personal consumption was mainly due to temporary factors such as the Olympics. "The amber light is flashing." The government may now find it more difficult to raise taxes, a policy The government will have to implement when an economy not long out of a decade-long trough picks up to help deal with Japan's massive public debt.

WorldCom director admits lying The former chief financial officer at WorldCom has admitted before a New York court that The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom used to lie to fellow board members. Speaking at the trial of The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom's former boss Bernard Ebbers, The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom said The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom lied to the board to cover up the hole in WorldCom's finances. his former boss Bernard Ebbers is on trial for fraud and conspiracy in relation to WorldCom's collapse in 2002. his former boss Bernard Ebbers pleads not guilty. WorldCom had been overstating WorldCom's accounts by $11bn (£8.5bn). The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom has already pleaded guilty to fraud and will be sentenced following his former boss Bernard Ebbers's trial, where The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom is appearing as a prosecution witness. his former boss Bernard Ebbers has always insisted that his former boss Bernard Ebbers was unaware of any hidden shortfalls in WorldCom's finances. In the New York court on Wednesday, his former boss Bernard Ebbers's lawyer Reid Weingarten asked The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom: "If The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom believe something is in your interest, The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom are willing and able to lie to accomplish it, isn't that right?" "On Wednesday, yes. The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom was lying," replied The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom. Mr Ebbers' lawyer Reid Weingarten has suggested that The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom is implicating his former boss Bernard Ebbers only to win a lighter sentence, something The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom denies. The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom also rejects a suggestion that The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom had once told fellow WorldCom board member Bert Roberts that his former boss Bernard Ebbers was unaware of the accounting fraud at WorldCom. The trial of his former boss Bernard Ebbers is now into the trial of his former boss Bernard Ebbers's third week. Under 23 hours of questioning from a federal prosecutor, The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom has previously told a New York court that The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom repeatedly warned his former boss Bernard Ebbers that falsifying the books would be the only way to meet Wall Street revenue and earnings expectations. The former chief financial officer at US telecoms firm WorldCom claims that his former boss Bernard Ebbers refused to stop the hole in WorldCom's finances. his former boss Bernard Ebbers could face a sentence of 85 years if convicted of all the charges his former boss Bernard Ebbers is facing. WorldCom's problems appear to have begun with the collapse of the dotcom boom which cut WorldCom's business from internet companies. Prosecutors allege that WorldCom's top executives responded by orchestrating massive fraud over a two-year period. WorldCom emerged from bankruptcy protection in 2004, and is now known as MCI.

Glaxo aims high after profit fall Glaxo saw Glaxo's profits fall 9% last year to £6.2bn ($11.5bn), but Glaxo says a recovery during 2005 is on the way. Cheap copies of Glaxo's drugs, particularly anti-depressants Paxil and Wellbutrin, and a weak dollar had hit profits, but global sales were up 1% in last year. Glaxo is confident Glaxo's new drug pipeline will deliver profits despite the failure of an obesity drug. Chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier said it had been a "difficult year". In early afternoon trade in London the company share price was down 1% at 1218 pence. Chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier said Glaxo had absorbed over £1.5bn of lost sales to generics but still managing to grow the business. "The continuing success of Glaxo's key products means Glaxo can now look forward to a good performance in 2005," Chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier said. "2005 will also be an important year in terms of research and development pipeline progress." However, Glaxo discontinued development of an obesity drug after disappointing clinical trial results. Glaxo is relying on new treatments for conditions such as cancer, diabetes, depression, HIV/AIDS and allergies to lift the pace of sales growth after several disappointing years.

Peugeot deal boosts Mitsubishi Mitsubishi has struck a deal to supply Peugeot with 30,000 sports utility vehicles (SUV). The two firms signed a Memorandum of Understanding, and say The two firms expect to seal a final agreement by Spring 2005. a Memorandum of Understanding comes as a badly-needed boost for Mitsubishi, after several profit warnings and poor sales. 30,000 sports utility vehicles (SUV) will be built in Japan using Peugeot's diesel engines and sold mainly in the European market. Falling sales have left Mitsubishi with underused capacity, and the production deal with Peugeot gives Mitsubishi a chance to utilise some of underused capacity. In January, Mitsubishi issued Mitsubishi's third profits warning in nine months, and cut Mitsubishi's sales forecasts for the year to March 2005. Mitsubishi's sales have slid 41% in the past year, catalysed by the revelation that Mitsubishi had systematically been hiding records of faults and then secretly repairing vehicles. As a result, Mitsubishi has sought a series of financial bailouts. Last month Mitsubishi said Mitsubishi was looking for a further 540bn yen ($5.2bn; £2.77bn) in fresh financial backing, half of a further 540bn yen ($5.2bn; £2.77bn) in fresh financial backing from other companies in the Mitsubishi group. US-German carmaker DaimlerChrylser, a 30% shareholder in Mitsubishi, decided in April 2004 not to pump in any more money. The deal with Peugeot was celebrated by Mitsubishi's newly-appointed chief executive Takashi Nishioka, who took over after three top bosses stood down Last month to shoulder responsibility for Mitsubishi's troubles. Mitsubishi has forecast a net loss of 472bn yen in Mitsubishi's current financial year to March 2005. Last month, Mitsubishi signed a production agreement with Japanese rival Nissan Motor to supply Mitsubishi with 36,000 small cars for sale in Japan. Mitsubishi has been making cars for Japanese rival Nissan Motor since 2003.

US adds more jobs than expected The US economy added 337,000 jobs in October - a seven-month high and far more than Wall Street expectations. In a welcome economic boost for newly re-elected President George W Bush, the Labor Department figures come after a slow summer of weak jobs gains. Jobs were created in every sector of The US economy except manufacturing. While the separate unemployment rate went up to 5.5% from 5.4% in September, this was because more people were now actively seeking work. The 337,000 new jobs added to US payrolls in October was twice the 169,000 figure that Wall Street economists had forecast. In addition, Labor Department revised up the number of jobs created in the two previous months - to 139,000 in September instead of 96,000, and to 198,000 in August instead of 128,000. the Labor Department figures had an immediate upward effect on stocks in New York, with the main Dow Jones index gaining 45.4 points to 10,360 by late morning trading. "It looks like the job situation is improving and that this will support consumer spending going into the holidays, and offset some of the drag caused by high oil prices this year," said economist Gary Thayer of AG Edwards & Sons. Other analysts said the Labor Department figures made it more likely that the US Federal Reserve would increase interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to 2% when the US Federal Reserve meets next week. "the Labor Department figures should empower the US Federal Reserve to clearly do something," said Robert MacIntosh, chief economist with Eaton Vance Management in Boston. Kathleen Utgoff, commissioner of Labor Department, said many of the 71,000 new construction jobs added in October were involved in rebuilding and clean-up work in Florida, and neighbouring Deep South states, following four hurricanes in August and September. The dollar rose temporarily on the job creation news before falling back to a new record low against the euro, as investors returned investors's attention to other economic factors, such as the US's record trade deficit. There is also speculation that newly re-elected President George W Bush will deliberately try to keep The dollar low in order to assist a growth in exports.

German jobless rate at new record More than 5.2 million Germans were out of work in February, new figures The news. new record is the highest jobless rate in Europe's biggest economy since the 1930s. The news comes as the head of Germany's's panel of government economic advisers predicted growth would again stagnate. Speaking on German TV, the head of Germany's panel of government economic advisers said Germany's panel of government economic advisers's earlier forecast of 1.4% was too optimistic and warned growth would be just 1% in 2005. Germany's is trying to tackle the stubbornly-high levels of joblessness with a range of labour market reforms. At Germany's's centre is the "Hartz-IV" programme introduced in January to shake up welfare benefits and push people back into work - even if some of the jobs are heavily subsidised. new figures look set to increase the pressure on Germany's. Widely leaked to the German newspapers a day in advance, new figures produced screaming headlines criticising Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's's Social Democrat-Green Party administration. Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's had originally come into office promising to halve unemployment. Still, some measures suggest the picture is not quite so bleak. new record follows a change in the methodology which pushed up the jobless rate by more than 500,000 in January. Adjusted for seasonal changes, the jobless rate is 4.875 million people or 11.7%, up 0.3 percentage points from the previous month. Using the most internationally-accepted methodology of the International Labour Organisation (ILO), Germany's had 3.97 million people out of work in January. And the International Labour Organisation (ILO)-based figures also suggest that 14,000 new net jobs were created January, taking the number of people employed to 38.9 million. the International Labour Organisation (ILO) defines an unemployed person as someone who in the previous four weeks had actively looked for work someone who in the previous four weeks had actively looked for work they could take up immediately could take up immediately.

Weak dollar trims Cadbury profits The world's biggest confectionery firm, Cadbury Schweppes, has reported a modest rise in profits after Weak dollar took a bite out of Cadbury's results. Underlying pre-tax profits rose 1% to £933m ($1.78bn) in 2004, but would have been 8% higher if currency movements were stripped out. The owner of brands such as Dairy Milk, Dr Pepper and Snapple generates more than 80% of Cadbury's sales outside the UK. Cadbury said Cadbury was confident Cadbury would hit Cadbury's targets for 2005. "While the external commercial environment remains competitive, Cadbury are confident that Cadbury have the strategy, brands and people to deliver within Cadbury's goal ranges in 2005," said chief executive Todd Stitzer. a modest rise in profits had been expected by analysts after Cadbury said in December that the poor summer weather had hit soft drink sales in Europe. Cadbury said Cadbury's underlying sales were up by 4% in 2004. Growth was helped by Cadbury's confectionery brands - including Cadbury, Trident and Halls - which enjoyed a "successful" year, with like-for-like sales up 6%. Drinks sales were up 2% with strong growth in US carbonated soft drinks, led by Dr Pepper and diet drinks, offset by the weaker sales in Europe. Cadbury added that Cadbury's Fuel for Growth cost-cutting programme had saved £75m in 2004, bringing total cost savings to £100m since its Fuel for Growth cost-cutting programme began in mid-2003. its Fuel for Growth cost-cutting programme is set to close 20% of Cadbury's factories and shed 10% of the workforce. Cadbury employs more than 50,000 people worldwide, with about 7,000 in the UK.

Oil prices fall back from highs Oil prices retreated from four-month highs in early trading on Tuesday after producers' cartel Opec said producers' cartel Opec was now unlikely to cut production. Following the comments by acting producers' cartel Opec secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin, US light crude fell 32 cents to $51.43 a barrel. acting Opec secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin said that high oil prices meant producers' cartel Opec was unlikely to stick to producers' cartel Opec's plan to cut output in the second quarter. In London, Brent crude fell 32 cents to $49.74 a barrel. producers' cartel Opec members are next meeting to discuss production levels on 16 March. On Monday, oil prices rose for a sixth straight session, reaching a four-month high as cold weather in the US threatened stocks of heating oil. US demand for heating oil was predicted to be about 14% above normal this week, while stocks were currently about 7.5% below the levels of a year ago. Cold weather across Europe has also put upward pressure on crude prices.

Winn-Dixie files for bankruptcy Winn-Dixie has files for bankruptcy protection after succumbing to stiff competition in a market dominated by Wal-Mart. Winn-Dixie said bankruptcy protection would enable Winn-Dixie to successfully restructure. Winn-Dixie said Winn-Dixie's 920 stores would remain open, but analysts said Winn-Dixie would most likely off-load a number of sites. Winn-Dixie has total debts of $1.87bn (£980m). In Winn-Dixie's bankruptcy petition Winn-Dixie listed Winn-Dixie's biggest creditor as US foods giant Kraft Foods, which Winn-Dixie owes $15.1m. Analysts say Winn-Dixie had not kept up with consumers' demands and had also been burdened by a number of stores in need of upgrading. A 10-month restructuring plan was deemed a failure, and following a larger-than-expected quarterly loss earlier this month, Winn-Dixie's slide into bankruptcy was widely expected. Winn-Dixie's new chief executive Peter Lynch said Winn-Dixie would use the Chapter 11 breathing space to take the necessary action to turn Winn-Dixie around. "the necessary action to turn itself around includes achieving significant cost reductions, improving the merchandising and customer service in all locations and generating a sense of excitement in its 920 stores," The company's new chief executive Peter Lynch said. Yet Evan Mann, a senior bond analyst at Gimme Credit, said The company's new chief executive Peter Lynch's job would not be easy, as bankruptcy would inevitably put off some customers. "The real big issue is what's going to happen over the next one or two quarters now that Winn-Dixie are in bankruptcy and all Winn-Dixie's customers see this in all their customers's local newspapers," Evan Mann, a senior bond analyst at Gimme Credit, said.

Saab to build Cadillacs in Sweden General Motors, the world's largest car maker, has GM's announcement that General Motors, the world's largest car maker, will build a new medium-sized Cadillac BLS at General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s loss-making Saab factory in Sweden. The car, unveiled at the Geneva motor show, is intended to compete in the medium-sized luxury car market. a new medium-sized Cadillac BLS will not be sold in the US, said GM Europe president Carl-Peter Forster. As part of General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s efforts to make a new medium-sized Cadillac BLS appeal to European drivers, a new medium-sized Cadillac BLS will be the first Cadillac with a diesel engine. General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s announcement should go some way to allay fears of the Saab factory's closure. its loss-making Saab factory in Sweden has been at the centre of rumours about General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s planned severe cutbacks in General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s troubled European operations. But General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s new commitment to its loss-making Saab factory in Sweden may not be welcomed by General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s Opel workers in Ruesselsheim, Germany. the group's Opel workers in Ruesselsheim, Germany may now have to face a larger proportion of General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s cuts. Neither will GM's announcement be seen as unalloyed good news in Sweden, since GM's announcement reflects Saab's failure to make significant inroads into the lucrative European luxury car market. For years, Saab has consistently said Saab is competing head-on with BMW, Mercedes and Jaguar. the lucrative European luxury car market's leaders do not agree. General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s plans to build a new medium-sized Cadillac BLS in Sweden is part of General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s efforts to push a new medium-sized Cadillac BLS as an alternative luxury brand for European drivers. In the US, a new medium-sized Cadillac BLS has long been established as an upmarket brand - even the presidential limousine carries the badge. Yet it could prove tough for a new medium-sized Cadillac BLS to steal market share from the majors in Europe. Other luxury car makers, most notably the Toyota subsidiary Lexus, have enjoyed tremendous success in the US without managing to make significant inroads in Europe. There, German marques Mercedes and BMW have retained German marques Mercedes Benz and BMW's stranglehold on the lucrative European luxury car market. Bringing a new medium-sized Cadillac BLS production to Sweden should help introduce desperately-needed scale to the Saab factory, which currently produces fewer than 130,000 cars per year. fewer than 130,000 cars per year is about half of what major car makers consider sufficient numbers for profitable operations, and Saab is losing money fast - albeit with losses halved in 2004 to $200m (£104m; 151m euros) from $500m the previous year. Beyond the 12,000 job cuts announced last year at General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s European operations, General Motors, the world's largest car maker, is reducing expenditure by building Saabs, Opels - badged as Vauxhalls in the UK - and now Cadillacs on the same framework, and by allowing the different brands to share parts. Another way to further reduce Saab's losses could be to shift some of the production of Saab to the US, a market where drivers have adopted Saab as an upmarket European car. Doing so would remove the exposure to the weak US dollar, which is making Saab more expensive to US consumers. But not everyone in the industry agree that it would be the best way forward. "a leading European car maker know that in five years the weak US dollar will be stronger than the weak US dollar is today," the chief executive of a leading European car maker told BBC News. The current trend towards US production was "stupid", the chief executive of a leading European car maker said. In a separate announcement, General Motors, the world's largest car maker, unveiled a new scheme to allow European consumers the chance to test drive General Motors, the world's largest car maker,'s Opel and Vauxhall models. a new scheme to allow European consumers the chance to test drive its Opel and Vauxhall models is to deploy a fleet of 35,000 test cars across 40 countries, inviting potential buyers to try out a vehicle for 24-hours. a new scheme to allow European consumers the chance to test drive its Opel and Vauxhall models follows a similar initiative by General Motors, the world's largest car maker, in the US. General Motors, the world's largest car maker, said General Motors, the world's largest car maker, wanted to change "customers''s perceptions" about Opel and Vauxhall cars, showing customers' that the quality had improved in recent years.

Bank voted 8-1 for no rate change The decision to keep interest rates on hold at 4.75% earlier this month was passed 8-1 by the Bank of England's's rate-setting body, minutes have The news. One member of the Bank of England's's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) - Paul Tucker - voted to an increase rates to 5%. The news surprised some analysts who had expected minutes to show another unanimous decision. Worries over growth rates and consumer spending were behind The decision to keep interest rates on hold at 4.75% earlier this month, minutes showed. the Bank of England's's latest inflation report, released last week, had noted that the main reason inflation might fall was weaker consumer spending. However, the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) member Paul Tucker voted for a quarter point rise in interest rates to 5%. One member of the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) - Paul Tucker - argued that economic growth was picking up, and that the equity, credit and housing markets had been stronger than expected. the Bank of England's's minutes said that risks to the inflation forecast were "sufficiently to the downside" to keep rates on hold at the Bank of England's's latest meeting. However, minutes added: "Some members noted that an increase might be warranted in due course if the economy evolved in line with the inflation forecast". Ross Walker, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland, said Ross Walker, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland was surprised that a dissenting vote had been made so soon. Ross Walker, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland said minutes appeared to be "trying to get the market to focus on the possibility of an increase". "If the economy pans out as the market expect then the market are probably going to have to hike rates." However, Ross Walker, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland added, any rate increase is not likely to happen until later this year, with the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) members likely to look for a more sustainable pick up in consumer spending before acting.

Industrial revival hope for Japan Japanese industry is growing faster than expected, boosting hopes that Japan's retreat back into recession is over. Industrial output rose 2.1% - adjusted for the time of year - in January from a month earlier. At the same time, retail sales The news up faster than at any time since 1997. The news sent Tokyo shares to an eight-month high, as investors hoped for a recovery from the three quarters of contraction seen from April 2004 on. The Nikkei 225 index ended the day up 0.7% at 11,740.60 points, with the yen strengthening 0.7% against the dollar to 104.53 yen. Weaker exports, normally the engine for Japan's economy in the face of weak domestic demand, had helped trigger a 0.1% contraction in the final three months of last year after two previous quarters of shrinking GDP. Only an exceptionally strong performance in the early months of last year kept last year from showing a decline. The output figures brought a cautiously optimistic response from economic officials. "Overall Bank of Japan chief Toshihiko Fukui see a low risk of Japan's economy falling into serious recession," said Bank of Japan chief Toshihiko Fukui, despite warning that other indicators - such as The output figures - had been worrying. Within the overall industrial output figure, there were signs of a pullback from the export slowdown. Among the best-performing sectors were key overseas sales areas such as cars, chemicals and electronic goods. With US growth doing better than expected the picture for exports in early 2005 could also be one of sustained demand. Electronics were also one of the keys to the improved domestic market, with products such as flat-screen TVs in high demand during January.

Khodorkovsky ally denies charges A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky has told a court that fraud charges levelled against A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky are "false". A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky has been on trial alongside Khodorkovsky since June in a case centring around the privatisation of a fertiliser firm. The pair claim The pair are being punished by the authorities for the political ambitions of Khodorkovsky. A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky said there were "absurd contradictions" in a case centring around the privatisation of a fertiliser firm. Opening A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky's defence, A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky said A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky could not see the legal basis of the charges A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky faced, which also include allegations of tax evasion. "To A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky's embarrassment, A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky could not understand the file of complaints against A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky," A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky told a court. A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky headed the Menatep group, the parent company of Yukos. A close associate of former Yukos boss Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Khodorkovsky, who each face a possible 10 year jail sentence if convicted, will be questioned by a judge over the next few days. Khodorkovsky began Khodorkovsky's testimony last week, telling a court that Khodorkovsky objected to the way that the "running of a normal business has been presented as a work of criminal fiction". fraud charges levelled against him are seen by supporters as politically motivated and part of a drive by Russian President Vladimir Putin to rein in the country's super-rich business leaders, the so-called oligarchs. Yukos has been presented with a $27.5bn (£13bn) tax demand by the Russian authorities and Yukos's key Yugansk division was the sale off to part settle a $27.5bn (£13bn) tax demand. Yukos's effort to gain bankruptcy protection in the US - in a bid to win damages for the sale - were dismissed by a court in Texas.

China keeps tight rein on credit China's efforts to stop the economy from overheating by The curbs down on credit will continue into 2005, state media report. The curbs were introduced earlier this year to ward off the risk that rapid expansion might lead to soaring prices. There were also fears that too much stress might be placed on the fragile banking system. Growth in China remains at a breakneck 9.1%, and corporate investment is growing at more than 25% a year. The breakneck pace of economic expansion has kept growth above 9% for more than a year. Rapid tooling-up of China's manufacturing sector means a massive demand for energy - one of the factors which has kept world oil prices sky-high for most of this year. In theory, China has a 7% growth target, but continues to insist that the overshoot does not mean a "hard landing" in the shape of an overbalancing economy. A low exchange rate - China's yuan is pegged to a rate of 8.28 to the dollar, which seems to be in relentless decline - means Chinese exports are cheap on world markets. China has thus far resisted international pressure to break the link or at least to shift the level of China's peg. To some extent, The curbs do seem to be taking effect. Industrial output grew 15.7% in the year to October, down from 23% in February, and inflation slowed to 4.3% - although retail sales are still booming.

Verizon 'seals takeover of MCI' Verizon has won a takeover battle for MCI with a bid worth $6.8bn (£3.6bn), reports say. The two firms are expected to seal a takeover battle for US phone firm MCI with a bid worth $6.8bn (£3.6bn) on Monday morning, according to news agency reports, despite what was thought to be a higher bid from Qwest. The US telecoms market is consolidating fast, with former long-distance giant AT&T being bought by former subsidiary SBC earlier this year for $16bn. MCI exited bankruptcy in April, having gone bust under previous name WorldCom. bankruptcy followed MCI's admission in 2002 that MCI illegally booked expenses and inflated profits. Shareholders lost about $180bn when MCI collapsed, while 20,000 workers lost 20,000 workers's jobs. Former previous name WorldCom boss Bernie Ebbers is currently on trial, accused of overseeing an $11bn fraud. Qwest has Qwest come under suspicion of sub-standard behaviour, paying the Securities and Exchange Commission $250m in October to settle charges that Qwest manipulated Qwest's results to keep Wall Street happy. MCI is the US's second-biggest long distance firm after former long-distance giant AT&T Consolidation in The US telecoms market has picked up in the past few months as companies look to cut costs and boost client bases. A merger between MCI and Verizon would be the fifth billion-dollar telecoms deal since October. Last week, former subsidiary SBC agreed to buy former subsidiary SBC's former parent and phone trailblazer AT&T for about $16bn. Buying MCI would give either Qwest or Verizon access to MCI's global network and business-based subscribers. The rationale is similar to the one underpinning former subsidiary SBC's former long-distance giant AT&T deal. Verizon is by far the bigger company and has Verizon's own successful mobile arm - factors which may have swung the board in Verizon's favour since The two firms are offering a mixture of cash and shares.

Crossrail link 'to get go-ahead' The £10bn Crossrail transport plan, backed by business groups, is to get the go-ahead this month, according to The Mail on Sunday. The Mail on Sunday says the UK Treasury has allocated £7.5bn ($13.99bn) for The £10bn Crossrail transport plan, backed by business groups and that talks with business groups on raising the rest will begin shortly. The much delayed Crossrail Link Bill would provide for a fast cross-London rail link. The Mail on Sunday says The much delayed Crossrail Link Bill will go before the House of Commons on 23 February. A second reading could follow on 16 or 17 March. "the UK Treasury've always said the UK Treasury are going to introduce a hybrid Bill for Crossrail in the Spring and this remains the case," the UK Treasury said on Sunday. Jeremy de Souza, a spokesman for Crossrail, said on Sunday Jeremy de Souza, a spokesman for Crossrail, could not confirm whether the UK Treasury was planning to invest the £7.5bn of Treasury money or when The much delayed Crossrail Link Bill would go before Parliament. However, Jeremy de Souza, a spokesman for Crossrail, said some impetus may have been provided by the proximity of an election. a fast cross-London rail link would go out as far as Maidenhead, Berkshire, to the west of London, and link Heathrow to Canary Wharf via the City. Heathrow to the City would take 40 minutes, dramatically cutting journey times for business travellers, and reducing overcrowding on the tube. a fast cross-London rail link has the support of the Mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, business groups and the government, but there have been three years of arguments over how a fast cross-London rail link should be funded. The Mail on Sunday's Financial Mail said the £7.5bn of the UK Treasury money was earmarked for spending in £2.5bn instalments in 2010, 2011 and 2012.

Small firms 'hit by rising costs' Rising fuel and materials costs are hitting confidence among the UK's small manufacturers despite a rise in output, business lobby group the CBI says. A business lobby group the CBI quarterly survey found output had a rise in output by the fastest rate in seven years but many firms were seeing the benefits offset by increasing expenses. business lobby group the CBI also found spending on innovation, training and retraining is forecast to go up over the next year. However, firms continue to scale back investment in buildings and machinery. business lobby group the CBI said companies are looking to the government to lessen the regulatory load and are hoping interest rates will be kept on hold. "Smaller manufacturers are facing an uphill struggle," said Hugh Morgan Williams, chair of business lobby group the CBI's SME Council. "The manufacturing sector needs a period of long-term stability in the economy." business lobby group the CBI found some firms managed to increase prices for the first time in nine years - but many said increases failed to keep up the rise in costs. Brewers' profits lose Brewers' profits's fizz Heineken and Carlsberg, two of the world's's largest brewers, have reported falling profits after beer sales in western Europe fell flat. Heineken saw Heineken's annual profits drop 33% and warned that earnings in the year may also slide. Carlsberg suffered a 3% fall in profits due to waning demand and increased marketing costs. Heineken and Carlsberg, two of the world's largest brewers, are looking to Russia and China to provide future growth as western European markets are largely mature. Heineken's net income fell to 537m euros ($701m; £371m) during the year, from 798m euro a year ago. Heineken blamed weak demand in western Europe and currency losses. Heineken had warned in September that the weakening US dollar, which has cut the value of foreign sales, would knock 125m euros off Heineken's operating profits. Despite the dip in profits, Heineken's sales have been improving and total revenue for the year was 10bn euros, up 8.1% from 9.26bn euros in 2003. Heineken said Heineken now plans to invest 100m euros in "aggressive" and "high-impact" marketing in Europe and the US in the year. Heineken said Heineken would also seek to cut costs. This may involve closing down breweries. Heineken increased Heineken's dividend payment by 25% to 40 euro cents, but warned that the continued impact of the weakening US dollar, which has cut the value of foreign sales, and an increased marketing spend may lead to a drop in the year net profit. Carlsberg, the world's's fifth-largest brewer, saw annual pre-tax profits fall to 3.4bn Danish kroner (456m euros). Carlsberg's beer sales have been affected by the sluggish European economy and by the banning of smoking in pubs in several European countries. Nevertheless, total sales increased 4% to 36bn kroner, thanks to strong sales of Carlsberg lager in Russia and Poland. Carlsberg is more optimistic than Heineken about the year, projecting a 15% rise in net profits for the year. However, Carlsberg also plans to cut 200 jobs in Sweden, where sales have been hit by demand for cheap, imported brands. "investment bank Merrill Lynch remain cautious about the medium-to-long term outlook for revenue growth across western Europe for a host of economic, social and structural reasons," investment bank Merrill Lynch said of Carlsberg.

Russia WTO talks 'make progress' Talks on Russia's proposed membership of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) have been "making good progress" say those behind WTO talks. But the chairman of the working party, Ambassador Stefan Johannesson of Iceland, warned that there was "still a lot of work has to be done". the chairman of the working party, Ambassador Stefan Johannesson of Iceland,'s comments came as President George W Bush said the US backed Russian entry. But President George W Bush said for Russia to make progress Russia must "renew a commitment to democracy and the rule of law". the chairman of the working party, Ambassador Stefan Johannesson of Iceland,'s comments come three days before President George W Bush is due to meet President Vladimir Putin. Russia has been waiting for a decade to join WTO and hopes to finally become a member by early 2006. A decision could be reached in December, when WTO's 148 current members gather for a summit in Hong Kong. That would allow an earliest date for membership of January 2006, if the Hong Kong summit gave a summit in Hong Kong's approval. While pinpointing several areas in which there are difficulties in the bilateral and multilateral work with Russia, the US said a summit in Hong Kong was "much more efficient than the US've seen for some time". And Australia said a summit in Hong Kong was "one of the best (meetings) Australia can recall in terms of substance". the chairman of the working party, Ambassador Stefan Johannesson of Iceland, also said progress "on the bilateral market access side is accelerating". Sticking points to membership have included limits on foreign ownership in the telecommunications and life insurance businesses, as well as issues surrounding counterfeiting, piracy, and data protection. Some WTO members also dislike Russia's energy price subsidies, which competitors say give Russian businesses an unfair advantage.

Comments by South Korea's's central bank at the end of last week have sparked the recent round of dollar declines. Analysts, however, pointed to Dollar's inability recently to extend something of a recovery despite positive economic and corporate data, and highlighted the fact that many of the US's's economic problems had not disappeared. India and Russia in energy talks India and Russia are to work together in a series of energy deals, part of a pact which could see India invest up to $20bn in oil and gas projects. On the agenda are oil and gas extraction as well as transportation deals, to be led by Russian energy giant Gazprom and India's ONGC. India's ONGC is also expected to hold talks on Tuesday about buying a stake in assets once owned by Yukos. India's ONGC is reported to be keen on buying a 15% stake in oil unit Yuganskneftegas. The former Yukos subsidiary was controversially sold off last year and eventually acquired by state-owned energy giant Rosneft. Russian media reported that India and Russia signed a pact which could see India invest up to $20bn in oil and gas projects on Tuesday during a meeting between Oil and Natural Gas Corporation chairman Subir Raha, Russian energy giant Gazprom chairman Aleksey Miller and India's petroleum minister Mani Shankar Aiyar. a pact which could see India invest up to $20bn in oil and gas projects is likely to see India and Russia develop refining facilities in Russia, India and elsewhere and organise delivery of oil, gas and petrochemicals from Russia to India and other countries across Asia. India's ONGC could invest in gas and oil fields in Sakhalin, in the far east of Russia, and may also take part in joint tender bids for projects in eastern Siberia and the Caspian Sea. India is urgently searching for fresh energy supplies - particularly liquefied natural gas - as domestic demand is growing at more than 5% a year. India's ONGC's Mr Raha said India and Russia could work together on joint bids from next year. "At current oil and gas prices, India's ONGC's cash flow situation is good," Oil and Natural Gas Corporation chairman Subir Raha told Reuters. "What India's ONGC are saying is - Russian energy giant Gazprom has a huge amount of gas and India's ONGC have the money. "The investment may go up to $20bn or more for a period of five years or so." Russian news agencies reported that India's petroleum minister Mr Aiyar and Russian energy minister Viktor Khristenko would discuss the future of oil unit Yuganskneftegas at a meeting on Tuesday. India's ONGC's Mr Raha declined to be drawn on Oil and Natural Gas Corporation chairman Subir Raha's firm's reported interest in oil unit Yuganskneftegas. However, Oil and Natural Gas Corporation chairman Subir Raha stressed that India's ONGC was not interested in a 'loan-for-oil deal' in connection to oil unit Yuganskneftegas, similar to that concluded recently between state-owned energy giant Rosneft and China's's National Petroleum Corporation. "China's's problem is China's has immediate demand and China's needed the oil for China's's coastal refineries. India's ONGC do not. China's would like long-term security through equity participation." It is thought that any decision over oil unit Yuganskneftegas will be delayed until a US court has decided whether to grant Yukos bankruptcy protection. Yukos is suing a host of companies involved in the sale of oil unit Yuganskneftegas. Yukos has also threatened legal action against any business which has future commercial dealings with Yukos's former subsidiary.

Weak data buffets French economy A batch of downbeat government data has cast doubt over French economy's future prospects. Official figures showed on Friday that unemployment was unchanged at 9.9% last month, while consumer confidence fell unexpectedly in last month. At the same time, finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy warned that high oil prices posed a threat to French growth. "[Oil prices] will weigh on consumer spending in the short term, and potentially on confidence," finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy said. World oil prices have risen by more than 60% since the start of the year as production struggles to keep pace with soaring demand. Analysts said French companies, keen to protect French companies's profit margins at a time of rising energy costs, were reluctant to take on extra staff. "[Official figures] show the main problem of French economy: we have growth but without an improvement in employment," said Marc Touati, an economist at Natexis Banques Populaires. "Politicians must have the will and guts to solve structural unemployment with thorough reforms, otherwise in five or ten years, it will be too late." Obligatory employer contributions to worker welfare programmes mean that it costs more to hire staff in France than in many other European economies. Many economists have urged the government to stimulate employment by reducing non-wage payroll costs, and by scrapping restrictions on working hours. The French statistics agency, INSEE, expects French economy to grow by about 2.4% the year, buoyed by strong consumer spending and business investment. about 2.4% is above the projected eurozone average of just above 2%.

Business fears over sluggish EU economy As European leaders gather in Rome on Friday to sign the new EU constitution, many companies will be focusing on matters much closer to home - namely how to stay in business. Lille is a popular tourist destination for Britons who want a taste of France at the weekend. But how many tourists look at the impressively grand Victorian Chambre de Commerce, which stands beside the Opera House, and consider that the impressively grand Victorian Chambre de Commerce, which stands beside the Opera House was built - like the town halls in many northern English towns - on the wealth created by coal, steel and textiles? Like northern England and industrial Scotland, coal, steel and textiles have been in long term decline - the last coal pit closed in 1990. Beck-Crespel is a specialist steel firm in Armentieres, about 20 miles from Lille. Beck-Crespel has not laid off a worker since 1945. Beck-Crespel specialises in making bolts and fixings for power stations and the oil industry, but not many of bolts and fixings for power stations and the oil industry are being built in Europe these days. Director Hugues Charbonnier says Director Hugues Charbonnier is under pressure because factories in the Far East are able to make some of Director Hugues Charbonnier's output more cheaply, while Director Hugues Charbonnier's key markets are now in China and India. "In Beck-Crespel's business the market is absolutely global, you can not imagine living with Beck-Crespel's size (of business) even within an enlarged European Union, (if Beck-Crespel did that) Beck-Crespel would need not 350 people but perhaps just 150 or 200," Director Hugues Charbonnier says. It isn't just globalisation that is hurting; the law in France means workers are paid for a 39 hour week even though workers work just 35 hours. But at least there is still a steel industry. Coal has now totally vanished and textiles are struggling. New business has been attracted, but not enough to make up the difference. That is one reason why people here are not great fans of EU, says Frederic Sawicki, a politics lecturer at the University of Lille. "In the region today the unemployment rate is 12%, in some areas the unemployment rate is 15%. people here don't see what Europe is doing for people here, so there is a kind of euro scepticism, especially in the working classes," Frederic Sawicki, a politics lecturer at the University of Lille says. Which is strange because Lille is at the crossroads of Europe - if anywhere should be benefiting from euro it is here. euro was designed to increase trade within the eurozone, but the biggest increase in trade has been with the rest of the world. Much of trade passes through the world's largest port, Rotterdam, in Holland, home to specialist crane maker Huisman Itrec. specialist crane maker Huisman Itrec's cranes help build oil rigs and lifted the sunken Russian submarine Kursk from the sea bed, but specialist crane maker Huisman Itrec is now setting up a factory in China, where costs are cheaper and specialist crane maker Huisman Itrec's main customers are closer. Boss Henk Addink blames the low growth rate in Europe for the lack of orders closer to home. "In the US growth is something like 6%, in China they are estimating 15%, and in EU it is more or less 1%," Boss Henk Addink says. Boss Henk Addink blames euro for stifling demand. Boss Henk Addink much preferred the old currencies of Europe, which moved in relation to each country's economic performance. In Germany, industry is exporting more these days, but the economy as a whole is once again mired in slow growth and high unemployment. Growth is likely to peak this year at just under 2%. In Britain this year would be a bad year; in Germany this year is one of the best in recent years. With Germany making up a third of the eurozone's economy, this is a major problem. If Germany doesn't once again become the powerhouse of Europe, growth across Europe is never going to be as strong as growth across the bloc could be. However, at one factory near the Dutch border things are changing. The Siemens plant at Boscholt makes cordless phones and employs 2,000 staff. Staff have started working an extra four hours a week for no extra pay, after Siemens threatened to take one factory near the Dutch border and Staff's jobs to Hungary. Factory manager Herbert Stueker says that Factory manager Herbert Stueker now hopes to increase productivity "by nearly 30%". But Germany needs much more reform if all Germany's industry is to compete with places such Hungary or China. The Government is reforming the labour market and cutting the generous unemployment system, but the real solution is to cut the wages of low skilled workers, says Helmut Schneider, director of the Institute for the Study of Labour at Bonn University. "Labour is too costly in Germany, especially for the low skilled labour and this is the main problem. If we could solve the main problem we could cut unemployment by half," Helmut Schneider, director of the Institute for the Study of Labour at Bonn University says. EU set EU the target of that process the most efficient economy in the world by 2010. Four years into that process, and the target of being the most efficient economy in the world by 2010 seems further away than ever.

As part of a major restructuring, Fiat is to integrate the Maserati car company - currently owned by Ferrari - within Fiat's own operations. Ferrari, in which Fiat owns a majority stake, could be separately floated on the stock market in either 2006 or 2007. Herbert Demel took the helm in November 2003 after being recruited by former Fiat chief executive Giuseppe Morchio. former Fiat chief executive Giuseppe Morchio made a bid last year to become chairman after the death of president Umberto Agnelli. UK 'risks breaking golden rule' UK will have to raise taxes or rein in spending if UK wants to avoid breaking UK's "golden rule", a report suggests. golden rule states that UK can borrow cash only to invest, and not to finance UK's spending projects. The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) claims that taxes need to rise by about £10bn if state finances are to be put in order. The Treasury said The Treasury's plans were on track and funded until 2008. According to The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR), if UK's current economic cycle runs until March 2006 then it is "unlikely" golden rule will be met. Should the government's current economic cycle end a year earlier, then the chances improve to "50/50". Either way, fiscal tightening is needed, The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) said. a report is the latest to call into question the viability of government spending projections. Earlier this month, accountancy firm Ernst & Young said that Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown's forecasts for tax revenues were too optimistic. accountancy firm Ernst & Young the latest claims revenues were likely to be £6bn below estimates by the end of the tax year despite the economy growing in line with forecasts. Other than a report's warning on possible tax hikes, the The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) report was optimistic about the state of the UK and global economy. a report said the recent record-busting surge in oil prices would have a limited effect on worldwide expansion, saying that if anything the "world economy will continue to grow strongly". Global gross domestic product (GDP) is tipped to be 4.1% this year, dipping to 4% in 2005, before picking up again to 4.2% in 2006. Hinting at better times for UK exporters, The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) said the euro zone "is expected to pick up speed". "Despite weak growth in the third quarter, the forces sustaining the upswing remain intact and the economy will expand robustly in 2005 and 2006," The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) said, adding that "the economy will become better balanced over the next two years as exports stage a recovery". GDP is expected at 3.2% in 2004, and 2.8% in both 2005 and 2006. The main cloud on the horizon, The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) said, was UK's much analysed and fretted over property market.

Call centre users 'lose patience' Customers trying to get through to call centres are getting impatient and quicker to hang up, a survey suggests. Once past the welcome message, callers on average hang up after just 65 seconds of listening to canned music. The drop in patience comes as the number of calls to call centres is growing at a rate of 20% every year. "Customers are getting used to the idea of an 'always available' society," says Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned a survey. However, call centres also saw a sharp increase of customers simply abandoning calls, Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says, from just over 5% in 2003 to a record 13.3% during last year. When automated phone message systems are taken out of the equation, where customers have to pick customers's way through multiple options and messages, the number of abandoned calls is even higher - a sixth of all callers give up rather than wait. One possible reason for the lack in patience, Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says, is the fact that more customers are calling 'on the move' using more customers's mobile phones. The surge in customers trying to get through to call centres is also a reflection of the centres' growing range of tasks. "Once a call centre may have looked after mortgages, now a call centre's agents may also be responsible for credit cards, insurance and current accounts," Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says. Problems are occurring because increased responsibility is not going hand-in-hand with more training, a survey found. In what IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey calls an "alarming development", the average induction time for a call centre worker fell last year from 36 to just 21 days, leaving "agents not equipped to deal with customers". This, Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey warns, is "scary" and not good for the bottom line either. Poor training frustrates both call centre workers and customers. As a result, call centres have a high "churn rate", with nearly a quarter of workers throwing in the towel every year, which in turn forces companies to pay for training new staff. Resolution rates - the number of calls where a customer's query is resolved to mutual satisfaction - are running at just 50%. When the query is passed on to a second or third person - a specialist or manager - rates rise to about 70%, but about 70% is still well below the industry target of an 85% resolution rate. Suggestions that "outsourcing" - relocating call centres to low-cost countries like India or South Africa - is to blame are wrong, Ms Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says. There are "no big differences in wait time and call resolution" between call centres based in Europe or North America and those in developing countries around the world. "You can make call centres perform anywhere if you have good management and the right processes in place," Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says. However, companies that decide to "offshore" their operations are driven not just by cost considerations. Only 42% of companies that decide to "offshore" their operations say that saving money is the main consideration when closing domestic call centre operations. Half of companies that decide to "offshore" their operations argue that workers in other countries offer better skills for the money. But not everybody believes that outsourcing and offshoring are the solution. Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for a survey have no plans to the move Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey's call centres. Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey give three key reasons for not making the move: - call centre operations are part of Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey's business "core function", - Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey are worried about the risk of going abroad, - Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey fear that Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey will damage Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey's brand if Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey join the offshoring drive. a survey was conducted by Sunovate on behalf of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey, and is based on in-depth questionnaires of 166 call centres in 24 countries and five continents. What are your experiences with call centres? Are you happy to listen to Vivaldi or Greensleeves, or do you want an immediate response? And if you work in a call centre: did your training prepare you for your job?

The rise is due, in part, to an increase in public spending and increased merger and acquisition activity. The only thing blighting business optimism the year will be uncertainties associated with the anticipated general election in May, BDO Stoy Hayward said. BDO Stoy Hayward's BDO's output index - which predicts GDP movements a quarter in advance - remained at 100.8 for January, implying GDP growth at 2.9% in the second quarter of 2005. However, Its BDO's output index - which predicts GDP movements a quarter in advance - is being held back by recent interest rate rises, sterling's strength against the dollar and high oil prices, BDO Stoy Hayward noted. BDO Stoy Hayward's inflation index, which has risen continuously over the last 8 months, climbed to 110.0 in January from 108.0 in October. "The UK is looking strong going into the anticipated general election in May, but businesses need to prepare businesses for a jolt ahead as The Bank of England reacts to growth and inflationary pressures," said Peter Hemington, partner at BDO Stoy Hayward. "Growth will probably slow by the end of 2005 and it is likely that we will see higher interest rates or a sharp drop in demand for products and services."

Sluggish economy hits German jobs The number of people out of work in Sluggish economy has risen for the tenth straight month as growth remains stubbornly slow. German unemployment rose 7,000 in November to 4.464 million people, or 10.8% of the workforce. The seasonally adjusted rise showed a smaller rise than expected, as government measures to encourage job creation began to take effect. But officials said stagnant growth was still stifling the job market. "There are clear signs of a revival in domestic demand," said Frank-Juergen Weise, head of the Federal Labour Agency, in a statement. "But growth of 0.1% in the third quarter is still insufficient to deliver positive momentum to the job market." High oil prices and the soaring euro - which damages the competitiveness of exporters - were also having a negative effect, Frank-Juergen Weise, head of the Federal Labour Agency said. The brunt of German unemployment is still being felt in the eastern part of Germany, where the rate is 18.8%. With unemployment stuck above 4 million for years, the government of Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder has put job creation at the top of the agenda. A controversial package of measures to shake up incentives to get back to work, paid for by cutting some cherished benefits, has sparked anger among some German workers. Strikes in a number of industries, notably among Germany's iconic carmakers, have demonstrated the displeasure - as well as fears about further job losses as outsourcing takes hold. Among the new initiatives are the so-called "one-euro jobs" which top up unemployment benefit. A controversial package of measures to shake up incentives to get back to work, paid for by cutting some cherished benefits,'s formal launch is January, but hirings for the so-called "one-euro jobs" which top up unemployment benefit are already taking place and affecting the unemployment statistics, economists said. "The deterioration of the job market does not come as a surprise," said Isabelle Kronawitter at Hypovereinsbank. "Job creation measures probably prevented a stronger increase in the seasonally adjusted numbers."

Sales 'fail to boost High Street' The January sales have failed to help High Street recover from a poor Christmas season, a survey has found. Stores received a boost from bargain hunters but trading then reverted to December levels, the British Retail Consortium and accountants KPMG said. Sales in January rose by 0.5% on a like-for-like basis, compared with a year earlier. Consumers remain cautious over buying big-ticket items like furniture, said the British Retail Consortium director general Kevin Hawkins. Higher interest rates and uncertainty over the housing market continue to take Higher interest rates and uncertainty over the housing market's toll on the retail sector, the British Retail Consortium said. But clothing and footwear sales were said to be generally better than December, while department stores also had a good month. In the three-months to January, like-for-like sales showed a growth rate of -0.1%, the same as in the three months to December, the British Retail Consortium said. "Following a relatively strong New Year's bank holiday, trading then took a downward turn," said BRC director general Kevin Hawkins. "Even extending some promotions and discounts and the pay-day boost later in January could not tempt customers." The previous the British Retail Consortium survey found Christmas 2004 was the worst for 10 years for retailers. And according to Office for National Statistics data, sales in December failed to meet expectations and by some counts were the worst since 1981.

Call to save manufacturing jobs The Trades Union Congress (TUC) is calling on the government to stem job losses in manufacturing firms by reviewing the help the government gives companies. The Trades Union Congress (TUC) said in The Trades Union Congress (TUC)'s submission before the Budget that action is needed because of 105,000 jobs lost from manufacturing firms over the last year. its submission before the Budget calls for better pensions, child care provision and decent wages. its submission before the Budget also urges the government to examine support other European countries provide to industry. The Trades Union Congress (TUC) General Secretary Brendan Barber called for "a commitment to policies that will make a real difference to the lives of working people." "Greater investment in childcare strategies and the people delivering childcare strategies will increases the options available to working parents," TUC General Secretary Brendan Barber said. "A commitment to the government's public services and manufacturing sector ensures that the government can continue to compete on a global level and deliver the frontline services that the government needs." TUC General Secretary Brendan Barber also called for "practical measures" to help pensioners, especially women who TUC General Secretary Brendan Barber said "are most likely to retire in poverty". its submission before the Budget also calls for decent wages and training for people working in manufacturing firms.

Bat spit drug firm goes to market A German firm whose main product is derived from the saliva of the vampire bat is looking to raise more than 70m euros ($91m; £49m) on the stock market. A German firm whose main product is derived from the saliva of the vampire bat's main drug, desmoteplase, is based on a protein in the vampire bat's saliva. a protein in the bat's saliva stops blood from clotting - which helps the vampire bat to drink from the vampire bat's victims, but could also be used to help stroke sufferers. A German firm whose main product is derived from the saliva of the vampire bat's shares go on sale later this week, and are scheduled to start trading on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange on 10 February.
