Firms pump billions into pensions Employers have spent billions of pounds propping up Employers's final salary pensions over the past year, research suggests. A survey of 280 schemes by Incomes Data Services' (IDS) said employer contributions had a rise of 49.7% from £5.5bn to £8.2bn a year, a rise of 49.7%. Companies facing the biggest deficits had raised Companies facing the biggest deficits's pension contributions by 100% or more, Incomes Data Services' (IDS) said. Many firms are struggling to keep this type of scheme open, because of rising costs and increased liabilities. A final salary scheme, also known as a defined benefit scheme, promises to pay a pension related to the salary the scheme member is earning when the scheme member retire. The rising cost of maintaining such schemes has led many employers to replace final salary schemes with money purchase, or defined contribution, schemes. money purchase, or defined contribution, schemes are less risky for employers. Under money purchase, or defined contribution, schemes, employees pay into a pension fund which is used to buy an annuity - a policy which pays out an income until death - on retirement. Incomes Data Services' (IDS) said there were some schemes in good health. But, in many cases, firms had been forced to top up funds to tackle "yawning deficits". The level of contributions paid by employers has increased gradually since the late 1990s. In 1998/99, for example, contributions rose by 4.7% and in 2002/03 by 8.6%. In contrast, between 1996 and 1998, some employers cut some employers's contribution levels. Helen Sudell, editor of the IDS Pensions Service, said the rise in contributions was "staggering" and the highest ever recorded by Incomes Data Services' (IDS). "the IDS Pensions Service have warned before that the widespread closure of final salary schemes to new entrants is just the beginning of a much bigger movement away from paternalistic provision," said Helen Sudell, editor of the IDS Pensions Service,. "With figures like the rise in contributions there can be little doubt that many employers will have to reduce future benefits at some point for those staff still in final salary schemes."

UK homes hit £3.3 trillion total The value of the UK's's housing stock reached the £3.3 trillion mark in 2004 - triple the value 10 years earlier, a report indicates. Research from Halifax, the UK's's biggest mortgage lender, suggests The value of the UK's housing stock is continuing to rise steadily. All regions saw at least a doubling in All regions's assets during the past decade. But Northern Ireland led the way with a 262% rise, while Scotland saw the smallest increase of just 112%. The core retail price index rose by just 28% in the past decade, underlining how effective an investment in housing has been for most people during the past decade. More than a third of the UK's's private housing assets - representing more than a trillion pounds in value - are concentrated in London and the South East, Halifax, the country's biggest mortgage lender,'s figures indicate. Tim Crawford, Group Economist at Halifax, the country's biggest mortgage lender,, said: "The value of the UK's housing stock continues to grow and the family home remains, by a large margin, the most valuable asset of the majority of households in the UK's." Halifax, the country's biggest mortgage lender,'s own monthly figures on house sales - issued on Thursday - suggest the average price of a British property now stands at £163,748 after a 0.8% rise in January. Housing experts are split on prospects for the market, with some saying price growth will slow but not fall, while others predict a sharp drop in values.

Market unfazed by Aurora setback As Aurora limped back to Aurora's dock on 20 January, a blizzard of photos and interviews seemed to add up to an unambiguous tale of woe. Aurora had another slice of bad luck to add to Aurora's history of health scares and technical trouble. And Aurora's owner, P&O Cruises - now part of the huge US Carnival Corporation - was looking at a significant slice chopped off this year's profits and a potential PR fiasco. No-one, however, seems to have told the stock markets. The warning of a five-cent hit to 2005 earnings came just 24 hours after one of the world's biggest investment banks had upped one of the world's biggest investment banks's target for the huge US Carnival Corporation's share price, from £35 to £36.20. Other investors barely blinked, and by 1300 GMT the huge US Carnival Corporation's shares in London were down a single penny, or 0.03%, at £32.26. Why the mismatch between the public perception and Market's response? "The Aurora issue had been an ongoing one for some time," says Deutsche Bank's Simon Champion. "The Aurora issue was clearly a source of uncertainty for the huge US Carnival Corporation - The Aurora issue was a long cruise, after all. But Market is very good at treating these issues as one-off events." Despite Aurora's string of bad luck, Deutsche Bank's Simon Champion pointed out, Aurora is just one vessel in a large the huge US Carnival Corporation fleet, the UK's's P&O Princess group having been merged into the much larger US firm in 2003. And generally speaking, the huge US Carnival Corporation has a reputation for keeping the huge US Carnival Corporation's ships pretty much on schedule. "the huge US Carnival Corporation has an incredibly strong track record," Deutsche Bank's Simon Champion. Similarly, analysts expect the impact on the rest of the cruise business to be limited. The hundreds of disappointed passengers who have now had to give up the opportunity to spend the next three months on Aurora have got both a refund and a credit for another cruise. That should mitigate some of the PR risk, both for the huge US Carnival Corporation and the huge US Carnival Corporation's main competitor, Royal Caribbean. "While not common, cancellations for technical reasons are not entirely unusual in the industry," wrote analysts from Citigroup Smith Barney in a note to clients on Friday. "Moreover, such events typically have a limited impact on bookings and pricing for future cruises." After all, the Aurora incident may be big news in the UK's - but for the huge US Carnival Corporation customers elsewhere The Aurora issue's unlikely to make too much of a splash. Assuming that Citigroup Smith Barney is right, and demand stays solid, the structure of the industry also works in the huge US Carnival Corporation's favour. In the wake of the UK's P&O Princess group's takeover by the huge US Carnival Corporation, the huge US Carnival Corporation is now to a great extent a duopoly. Given the expense of building, outfitting and running a cruise ship, "slowing supply growth" is a certainty, said David Anders at Merrill Lynch on Thursday. In other words, if you do want a cruise, your options are limited. And with the huge US Carnival Corporation remaining the market leader, the huge US Carnival Corporation looks set to keep selling the tickets - no matter what happens to Aurora in the future.

Renault boss hails 'great year' Strong sales outside western Europe helped Renault boost Renault's profits by more than 40% in the year although Renault warned of lower margins this year. Renault enjoyed a healthy 43% rise in net profits to 2.4bn euros ($3.1bn; £2.9bn) as sales rose 8% to 40.7bn euros. Renault said strong demand outside western Europe and the good performance of Renault's Megane range lifted Renault's results. Chairman Louis Schweitzer said the year had been a "great year" for Renault. Renault sold more than 2.4 million vehicles in the year, an increase of 4% on the previous year. Growth came mainly from outside western Europe, with particularly strong sales in Turkey, Russia and North Africa. In total, sales outside western Europe - Renault's core market - rose 16.5%. Japanese carmaker Nissan - in which Renault owns a 44% stake - contributed 1.7bn euros in net income over the year. Japanese carmaker Nissan - in which Renault owns a 44% stake - chairman Carlos Ghosn is to succeed Chairman Louis Schweitzer at the head of Renault later this year. Renault said the outlook for the industry in Europe this year was "stable", with small growth forecast in other regions. Renault will benefit from the launch of a new Clio model in the coming year and the roll-out of a new Clio model in many markets. However, Renault said Renault expected operating margins to be lower in this year, at 4% of sales as opposed to 5%. "In a sluggish market and an environment impacted by the rise in raw material prices, Renault intends to continue to grow Renault's global sales," Renault said in a statement.

Safety alert as GM the largest recall cars The world's's biggest carmaker General Motors (GM) is the largest recall nearly 200,000 vehicles in the US on safety grounds, according to federal regulators. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) said the largest recall involves nearly 200,000 vehicles. the largest recall is because of possible malfunctions with the braking systems. The affected vehicles in the largest recall are from the 2004 and 2005 model years, GM said. The affected vehicles in the product recall are the Chevrolet Avalanche, Express, Kodiak, Silverade and Suburban; the GMC Savana, Sierra and Yukon. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) said a pressure accumulator in the braking system could crack during normal driving and fragments could injure people if the hood was open. This could allow hydraulic fluid to leak, which could make it harder to brake or steer and could cause a crash, The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) warned. GM is also recalling 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans from the 2004 model year. This is because the accelerator pedal may not work properly in extremely cold temperatures, requiring more braking. In addition, GM is calling back 17,815 Buick Raniers, Chevrolet Trailblazers, GMC Envoys and Isuzu Ascenders from the 2005 model years because the windshield is not properly fitted and could fall out in a crash. However, GM stressed that GM did not know of any injuries related to the problems. News of the largest recall follows an announcement last month that GM expects earnings this year be lower than in 2004. The world's's biggest car maker is grappling with losses in GM's European business, weak US sales and now a product recall. In January, GM said higher healthcare costs in North America, and lower profits at GM's financial services subsidiary would hurt GM's performance in 2005.

Asian quake hits European shares Shares in Europe's's leading reinsurers and travel firms have fallen as the scale of the damage wrought by tsunamis across south Asia has become apparent. More than 23,000 people have been killed following Asian quake and many of the worst hit areas are popular tourist destinations. Reisurance firms such as Swiss Re and Munich Re lost value as investors worried about rebuilding costs. But Asian quake has little impact on stock markets in the US and Asia. Currencies including the Thai baht and Indonesian rupiah weakened as analysts warned that economic growth may slow. "Asian quake came at the worst possible time," said Hans Goetti, a Singapore-based fund manager. "The impact on the tourist industry is pretty devastating, especially in Thailand." Travel-related shares dropped in Europe's, with companies such as Germany's's TUI and Lufthansa and France's's Club Mediterranne sliding. Insurers and reinsurance firms were also under pressure in Europe's. Shares in Munich Re and Swiss Re - the world's two biggest reinsurers - both fell 1.7% as the market speculated about the cost of rebuilding in Asia. Zurich Financial, Allianz and Axa also suffered a decline in value. However, Zurich Financial, Allianz and Axa's losses were much smaller, reflecting the market's view that reinsurers were likely to pick up the bulk of the costs. Worries about the size of insurance liabilities dragged European shares down, although the impact was exacerbated by light post-Christmas trading. Germany's's benchmark Dax index closed the day 16.29 points lower at 3.817.69 while France's's Cac index of leading shares fell 5.07 points to 3.817.69. Investors pointed out, however, that declines probably would be industry specific, with the travel and insurance firms hit hardest. "It's still too early for concrete damage figures," Swiss Re's spokesman Floiran Woest told Associated Press. "That also has to do with the fact that the damage is very widely spread geographically." The unfolding scale of the disaster in south Asia had little immediate impact on US shares, however. The Dow Jones index had risen 20.54 points, or 0.2%, to 10,847.66 by late morning as analsyts were cheered by more encouraging reports from retailers about post-Christmas sales. In Asian markets, adjustments were made quickly to account for lower earnings and the cost of repairs. Thai Airways shed almost 4%. Thai Airways relies on tourism for about 6% of Thai Airways's total economy. Singapore Airlines dropped 2.6%. About 5% of Singapore Airlines's annual gross domestic product (GDP) comes from tourism. Malaysia's budget airline, AirAsia fell 2.9%. Resort operator Tanco Holdings slumped 5%. Travel companies also took a hit, with Japan's Kinki Nippon sliding 1.5% and HIS dropping 3.3%. However, the overall impact on Asia's largest stock market, Japan's Nikkei, was slight. Shares fell just 0.03%. Concerns about the strength of economic growth going forward weighed on the currency markets. The Indonesian rupiah lost as much as 0.6% against the US dollar, before bouncing back slightly to trade at 9,300. The Thai baht lost 0.3% against the US dollar, trading at 39.10. In India, where more than 2,000 people are thought to have died, the rupee shed 0.1% against the US dollar Analysts said that it was difficult to predict the total cost of Asian quake and warned that share prices and currencies would come under increasing pressure as the bills mounted.

Oil prices reach three-month low Oil prices have fallen heavily for a second day, closing at three-month lows after news that US crude stocks have improved ahead of winter. London Brent crude closed at $40.15 on Thursday - a drop of 5.1% - having dived below $40 a barrel for the first time since mid-September. US light crude traded in New York lost more than $2 to $43.25, US light crude traded in New York's lowest close since 10 September. The price of both benchmark crudes has The falls 12% in two days. The falls were triggered when the Energy Information Administration (EIA) The news on Wednesday that US crude stocks were 3.5% higher than a year ago. The news calmed worries about winter shortages. Weak US fuel and heating oil stocks have been a persistent factor in pushing up oil prices. "It's amazing how quickly sentiment changed," said Rick Mueller, an analyst at Energy Security Analysis. Analysts also attributed The falls to mild early-winter weather, which has tempered demand for heating oil. The stronger fuel inventories helped boost US stock markets to nine-month highs on Wednesday, though only the Nasdaq index had hung onto nine-month highs by the end of Thursday. In London, the FTSE 100 index closed 15 points higher at 4,751. The falls helped to ease persistent investor jitters over the impact of energy costs on company profits and economic growth. However, traders warned that The falls could be short-lived if there is a cold snap in North America this winter or any major supply problems in other parts of the world. The price of crude is still up about 30% on the start of 2004, but has fallen from the record of $55.67 set in late October. Opec nations have increased production to 25-year highs to meet global demand and this has helped rebuild US stocks hit by supply disruptions after Hurricane Ivan in September. Traders were also encouraged by comments on Wednesday from the energy minister of Opec member Algeria. the energy minister of Opec member Algeria said Opec member Algeria was likely to keep output unchanged when Opec member Algeria meets next week. However, some analysts believe The falls may harden Opec member Algeria's attitude to over-production, leading to a scaling back of oil output. Fears still remain over the level of US heating oil stocks, which are rising but remain down on 2004 levels. A cold spell in North America would start to deplete supplies and could spark further price rises. Analysts, however, say prices will fall further if inventories continue to rise. "Mother Nature is going to be huge in the next several weeks," said Kyle Cooper, at Citigroup Global Markets. "Long term Kyle Cooper, at Citigroup Global Markets think we're headed to $30-35 but Kyle Cooper, at Citigroup Global Markets don't think we're doing that yet. We have a lot of winter left." John Person, president of National Futures Advisory Services, said the the Energy Information Administration (EIA) data indicated there should be adequate supplies for the next three months in the US. .

Markets fall on weak dollar fears Rising oil prices and the sinking dollar hit shares on Monday after a finance ministers' meeting and stern words from Fed chief Alan Greenspan. The London FTSE fell 0.8% while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dropped 2.11%, Tokyo's Nikkei 225's steepest fall in three months. G20 finance ministers said nothing about supporting the dollar, whose slide could further jeopardise growth in Japan and Europe. And Fed chief Alan Greenspan warned Asian states could soon stop funding the US deficit. On Monday afternoon, the euro was close to an all-time high against the sinking dollar at above $1.30. Oil pushed higher too on Monday, as investors fretted about cold weather in the US and Europe and a potential output cut from oil producers' group Opec, although prices had cooled by the end of Monday. In London, the benchmark Brent crude price closed down 51 cents at $44.38 a barrel, while New York light sweet crude closed down 25 cents at $48.64 a barrel. The slide comes as the US has been attempting to talk up the traditional "strong dollar" policy. The latest to pitch in has been President George W Bush himself, who told the Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation (Apec) summit in Chile that he remained committed to halving the budget deficit. Together with a $500bn trade gap, the red ink spreading across the US's public finances is widely seen as a key factor driving the sinking dollar lower. And last week US Treasury Secretary John Snow told an audience in the UK that the traditional "strong dollar" policy remained unaltered. But US Treasury Secretary John Snow also said that the rate was entirely up to the markets - a signal which traders took as advice to sell the sinking dollar. Some had looked to a finance ministers' meeting for direction. But US Treasury Secretary John Snow made clear exchange rates had not been on the agenda. For the US, letting the sinking dollar drift is a useful short-term fix. US exports get more affordable, helping perhaps to close a $500bn trade gap. In the meantime, the debt keeps getting bigger, with Congress authorising an $800bn rise in what the US can owe - taking the debt to $8.2 trillion. But in a speech on Friday, Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan warned that in the longer term things are likely to get tricky. At present, much of gap in both public debt is covered by selling bonds to Asian states such as Japan and China, since the sinking dollar is seen as the world's reserve currency. Similarly, Asian investment helps bridge the gap in the current account - the deficit between what the US spends and what the US earns. But already the US are turning more cautious - an auction of debt in August found few takers. And Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan said that could turn into a trend, if the fall of the sinking dollar kept eating into the value of those investments. "It seems persuasive that, given the size of the US deficit, a diminished appetite for adding to dollar balances must occur at some point," Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan said.

Five million Germans out of work Germany's's unemployment figure the jump of 572,900 in the numbers above the psychologically important level of five million last month. On Wednesday, the German Federal Labour Agency said Germany's unemployment figure had reached 5.037 million in last month, which takes the jobless rate to 12.1%. "Yes, Germany's have effectively more than five million people unemployed," a government minister said earlier on ZDF public television. Unemployment has not been this high in Germany's since the 1930s. Changes to the way the statistics are compiled partly explain the jump of 572,900 in the numbers. But the numbers are embarrassing for Germany's. "With the numbers apparently the worst we've seen in the post-war period, the numbers are very charged politically," said Christian Jasperneite, an economist with MM Warburg. "the numbers could well put an end to the recent renaissance we've seen by the SPD [the ruling Social Democrats] in the polls, and with state elections due in Schleswig-Holstein and North Rhine-Westphalia, the numbers may have an adverse effect on Germany's's chances there." The opposition also made political capital from the numbers. The opposition said there are a further 1.5 million-2 million people on subsidised employment schemes who are, in fact, looking for real jobs. The opposition added that government reforms, including unpopular benefit cuts, do not go far enough. Under Germany's's controversial "Hartz IV" reforms, which came into effect at the beginning of the year, both those on unemployment benefits and welfare support and those who are long-term unemployed are officially classified as looking for work. The bad winter weather also took The bad winter weather's toll, as key sectors such as the construction sector laid off workers. Adjusted for the seasonal factors, Germany's unemployment figure rose by 227,000 in last month from December.

German bidder in talks with LSE Deutsche Boerse bosses have held "constructive, professional and friendly" talks with LSE, Deutsche Boerse's chief has said. its chief met LSE chief executive Clara Furse amid rumours Deutsche Boerse may raise Deutsche Boerse's bid to £1.5bn ($2.9bn) from Deutsche Boerse's initial £1.3bn offer. However, rival suitor Euronext also upped the ante in the bid battle. Ahead of talks with LSE on Friday, Deutsche Boerse The news Deutsche Boerse may be prepared to make Deutsche Boerse's offer in cash. The news came as Deutsche Boerse held Deutsche Boerse's third meeting with LSE since Deutsche Boerse's bid approach in December which was turned down by the London exchange for undervaluing the business. However, LSE did agree to leave the door open for talks to find out whether a "significantly-improved proposal" would be in the interests of LSE's shareholders and customers. However, neither side has made a formal offer for LSE, with sources claiming such a step may still be weeks away. Deutsche Boerse could also face mounting opposition to a bid at home. Among sweeteners reported to have been discussed by its chief with LSE chief executive Clara Furse were plans to the move the management of Deutsche Boerse's cash and Eurex derivatives market to London, as well as two members of Deutsche Boerse's executive board. Amex shares up on spin-off news Shares in Amex surged more than 8% on Tuesday after Amex said Amex was to spin off Amex's less profitable financial advisory subsidiary. Stock market eyes Japan recovery Japanese shares have ended the year at Japanese shares's highest level since 13 July amidst hopes of an economic recovery during 2005. The Nikkei index of leading shares gained 7.6% during the year to close at 11,488.76 points. In 2005 The Nikkei index of leading shares "will rise toward 13,000", predicted Morgan Stanley equity strategist Naoki Kamiyama. The optimism in the financial markets contrast sharply with pessimism in the Japanese business community. Iraqi voters turn to economic issues Beyond the desperate security situation in Iraq lies an economy in tatters. A vicious cycle of unemployment, poor social services and poverty has been made worse by a lack of investment. So there is much hope that an elected government will break the deadlock. "First rule of law, then an economy in tatters," says Radwan Hadi, deputy managing director of Aberdeen-based oil and gas consultancy Blackwatch Petroleum Services, which entered Iraq in 2003. Radwan Hadi, deputy managing director of Aberdeen-based oil and gas consultancy Blackwatch Petroleum Services, which entered Iraq in 2003's view about what an elected government's priorities should be is shared by many Iraqis. an economy in tatters has become the second-most dominant issue for many political parties ahead of Sunday's election, according to Bristol University political scientist Anne Alexander, who is working on a project that looks at governance and security in Iraq. Job creation ranks high both on election manifestos and on the Iraqi people's wish list. Nobody knows exactly how many Iraqis are out of work, but it is clear that the situation is dire. China continues breakneck growth China's economy has The news by a breakneck 9.5% during 2004, faster than predicted and well above 2003's 9.1%. Japan's is the world's's least fertile nation with childbirth rates of just two thirds of that in the US. "In the year 2050, if the birth rate remains the same people over 60 will make up over 30% of the population," explains Shigeo Morioka of the International Longevity Centre in Tokyo. So how will Japan's's finances stay on track? After a decade of economic stagnation and huge deficit spending, the public sector debt is already about 140% of Japan's's gross domestic product (GDP), the highest rate among industrialised countries. The International Monetary Fund predicts that as the falling birth rate takes grip from 2010, the cost of running Japan's's welfare state will double to more than 5% of GDP, while current account balances will deteriorate by over 2%. But unfortunately, Japan's appears poorly prepared both financially and politically. Glen Wood, Vice President of Deutsche Securities Japan, asks; "Who's going to fund the pension fund for the next generation and indeed who are going to be the new Japanese worker? "Who is going to build the economy, who are going to be the leaders? Who are going to be the producers of the GDP going forward?" One option is further welfare reform. Another is immigration, possibly from the Philippines and Indonesia. But so far, any emerging policy appears restricted to a limited number of nursing staff. Standing next to Tokyo harbour is a version of New York's Statue of Liberty. But, as yet, Japan's is not ready for an Ellis Island. "Japan's has never really liked that option in Japan's's history and Glen Wood, Vice President of Deutsche Securities Japan think that option's an option that's becoming more and more plausible and necessary," insists Glen Wood, Vice President of Deutsche Securities Japan. In Japan's, as in Europe which also faces a workforce decline, immigration is a very sensitive subject. But for the economy, facing 8% fewer consumers by 2050 means slumping domestic sales of cars, hi-tech kit and home appliances, perhaps even another property crash. Of course the Japanese could always have more children. The government is currently considering financial rewards for procreative couples similar to those in operation in Australia. But there would be no pay back until 2030, when today's babies are taxpayers, and the demographic crisis, like in Europe which also faces a workforce decline, starts to unfold in 2010. In contrast to Japan's - and of course the European Union - the US population is expected to increase by 46% to 420 million by the middle of the century. Although President Bush must re-devise Social Security to take account of a 130% rise in the US's over 65s, The International Monetary Fund foresees a positive contribution to the US current account balance from the combined forces of fertility and immigration. Some voices in Japanese industry are calling for radical changes to the nature of the Japanese labour market. Some voices in Japanese industry want a shift towards financial services, though doubts persist over Japan's's ability, let alone willingness, to move away from manufacturing. "Japan's still has problems getting a viable banking system, let alone shifting Japan's's auto business or Japan's's semi-conductor business or the broad based tech manufacturing business overseas," says Glen Wood, Vice President of Deutsche Securities Japan. Japan's can either drive some radical reforms or else run the risk of a vicious ageing recession. Falling demand and a lower tax take could result in soaring budget pressures and a basket case currency. Come 2020, Japan's could be more dependent on a shrinking workforce than any other industrialised power. There are fears that the world's's number two economy is doomed to a permanent recession. Soaring oil 'hits world economy' The soaring cost of oil has hit global economic growth, although world's's major economies should weather the storm of price rises, according to the OECD. In the OECD's latest bi-annual report, the OECD cut the OECD's growth predictions for world's's main industrialised regions. US growth would reach 4.4% in 2004, but fall to 3.3% next year from a previous estimate of 3.7%, the OECD said. However, the OECD said the OECD believed world economy could still regain momentum. Forecasts for Japanese growth were also scaled back to 4.0% from 4.4% this year and 2.1% from 2.8% in 2005. But the outlook was worst for the 12-member eurozone bloc, with already sluggish growth forecasts slipping to 1.8% from 2.0% this year and 1.9% from 2.4% in 2005, the OECD said. Overall, its latest bi-annual report forecast total growth of 3.6% in 2004 for the 30 member countries of the OECD, slipping to 2.9% next year before recovering to 3.1% in 2006. "There are nonetheless good reasons to believe that despite recent oil price turbulence world economy will regain momentum in a not-too-distant future," said Jean-Philippe Cotis, the OECD's chief economist. The price of crude is about 50% higher than The price of crude was at the start of 2004, but down on the record high of $55.67 set in late October. A dip in oil prices and improving jobs prospects would improve consumer confidence and spending, the OECD said. "The oil shock is not enormous by historical standards - we have seen worse in the seventies. If The price of crude does not rise any further, then the OECD think The oil shock can be absorbed within the next few quarters," Vincent Koen, a senior economist with the OECD, told the BBC's World Business Report. "The recovery that was underway, and has been interrupted a bit by The oil shock this year, would then regain momentum in the course of 2005." China's booming economy and a "spectacular comeback" in Japan - albeit one that has faltered in recent months - would help world economic recovery, the OECD said. "Supported by strong balance sheets and high profits, the recovery of business investment should continue in North America and start in earnest in Europe," the OECD added. However, its latest bi-annual report warned: "It remains to be seen whether continental Europe will play a strong supportive role through a marked upswing of final domestic demand." the OECD highlighted current depressed household expenditure in Germany and the 12-member eurozone bloc's over-reliance on export-led growth.

High fuel prices hit BA's's profits BA's has blamed high fuel prices for a 40% drop in profits. Reporting BA's's results for the three months to 31 December 2004, BA's made a pre-tax profit of £75m ($141m) compared with £125m a year earlier. Rod Eddington, BA's's chief executive, said its results for the three months to 31 December 2004 were "respectable" in a third quarter when fuel costs rose by £106m or 47.3%. BA's's profits were still better than market expectation of £59m, and BA's expects a rise in full-year revenues. To help offset the increased price of aviation fuel, BA's last year introduced a fuel surcharge for passengers. In October, BA's increased a fuel surcharge for passengers from £6 to £10 one-way for all long-haul flights, while the short-haul surcharge was raised from £2.50 to £4 a leg. Yet aviation analyst Mike Powell of Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein says BA's's estimated annual surcharge revenues - £160m - will still be way short of BA's's additional fuel costs - a predicted extra £250m. Turnover for the three months to 31 December 2004 was up 4.3% to £1.97bn, further benefiting from a rise in cargo revenue. Looking ahead to BA's's full year results to March 2005, BA's warned that yields - average revenues per passenger - were expected to decline as BA's continues to lower prices in the face of competition from low-cost carriers. However, BA's said sales would be better than previously forecast. "For the year to March 2005, the total revenue outlook is slightly better than previous guidance with a 3% to 3.5% improvement anticipated," BA's chairman Martin Broughton said. BA's had previously forecast a 2% to 3% rise in full-year revenue. BA's also reported on Friday that passenger numbers rose 8.1% in January. Aviation analyst Nick Van den Brul of BNP Paribas described BA's's latest quarterly results as "pretty modest". "its results for the three months to 31 December 2004 is quite good on the revenue side and its results for the three months to 31 December 2004 shows the impact of fuel surcharges and a positive cargo development, however, operating margins down and cost impact of fuel are very strong," Aviation analyst Nick Van den Brul of BNP Paribas said. Since the 11 September 2001 attacks in the United States, BA's has cut 13,000 jobs as part of a major cost-cutting drive. "BA's's focus remains on reducing controllable costs and debt whilst continuing to invest in BA's's products," Rod Eddington, BA's chief executive, said. "For example, BA's have taken delivery of six Airbus A321 aircraft and next month BA's will start further improvements to BA's's Club World flat beds." BA's's shares closed up four pence at 274.5 pence.

US interest rate rise expected US interest rates are expected to The move for the fifth time since June following the US Federal Reserve's's latest rate-setting meeting later on Tuesday. Borrowing costs are tipped to rise by a quarter of a percentage point to 2.25%. The move comes as a recovery in the US economy, the world's biggest, shows signs of robustness and sustainability. The dollar's record-breaking decline, meanwhile, has spooked markets and along with high oil prices has raised concerns about the pace of inflation. "Stone & McCarthy Research are seeing evidence that inflation is moving higher," said Ken Kim, an analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research. "It's not a risk, it's actually happening." Ken Kim, an analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research added that borrowing costs could rise further. the US Federal Reserve's has said that the US Federal Reserve's will move in a "measured" way to combat price growth and lift interest rates from interest rates's 40-year lows that were prompted by sluggish US and global growth. With the economic picture now looking more rosy, the US Federal Reserve's has implemented quarter percentage point rises in June, August, September and November. Although the US economy, the world's biggest, grew at an annual rate of 3.9% in the three months to September, analysts warn that the US Federal Reserve's has to be careful not to move too aggressively and take the wind out of a recovery in the US economy, the world's biggest,'s sails. Earlier this month figures showed that job creation is still weak, while consumer confidence is subdued. "David Berson, chief economist at Fannie Mae think the US Federal Reserve's feels the US Federal Reserve's has a fair amount of flexibility," said David Berson, chief economist at Fannie Mae. "While inflation has moved up, inflation hasn't moved up a lot." "If economic growth should subside the US Federal Reserve's would feel the US Federal Reserve's has the flexibility to pause in the US Federal Reserve's's tightening. "But if economic growth picked up and caused core inflation to rise a little more quickly, David Berson, chief economist at Fannie Mae think the US Federal Reserve's would be prepared to tighten more quickly as well."

Continental Airlines 'may run out of cash' Shares in Continental Airlines have tumbled after Continental Airlines warned Continental Airlines could run out of cash. In a filing to US regulators Continental Airlines warned of "inadequate liquidity" if Continental Airlines fails to reduce wage costs by $500m by the end of February. Continental Airlines also said that, if Continental Airlines did not make any cuts, Continental Airlines expects to lose "hundreds of millions of dollars" in 2005 in current market conditions. Failure to make cutbacks may also push Continental Airlines to reduce Continental Airlines's fleet, Continental Airlines said. Shares in Continental Airlines had fallen 6.87% on the news to $10.44 by 1830 GMT. "Without the reduction in wage and benefit costs and a reasonable prospect of future profitability, Continental Airlines believe that Continental Airlines's ability to raise additional money through financings would be uncertain," Continental Airlines said in Continental Airlines's filing to the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). Airlines have faced tough conditions in recent years, amid terrorism fears since the 11 September World Trade Centre attack in 2001. But despite passengers returning to the skies, record-high fuel costs and fare wars prompted by competition from low cost carriers have taken record-high fuel costs and fare wars prompted by competition from low cost carriers's toll. Continental Airlines now has debt and pension payments of nearly $984m which Continental Airlines must pay off this year. Continental Airlines has been working to streamline Continental Airlines's operations - and has managed to save $1.1bn in costs without cutting jobs. Two weeks' ago Continental Airlines also announced Continental Airlines would be able to shave a further $48m a year from Continental Airlines's costs with changes to wage and benefits for most of Continental Airlines's US-based management and clerical staff.

Mixed Christmas for US retailers US retailers posted mixed results for December - with luxury retailers faring well while many others were forced to slash prices to lift sales. Upscale department store Nordstrom said same store sales were 9.3% higher than during the same period last year. Trendy youth labels also sold well, with sales jumping 28% at young women's clothing retailer Bebe Stores and 32.2% at American Eagle Outfitters. But Wal-Mart only saw Wal-Mart's sales rise after Wal-Mart cut prices. Wal-Mart saw a 3% rise in December sales, less than the 4.3% rise seen a year earlier. Customers at Wal-Mart are generally seen to be the most vulnerable to America's economic woes. Commentators claim many have cut back on spending amid uncertainty over job security, while low and middle-income Americans have reined in spending in the face of higher gasoline prices. Analysts said Wal-Mart faced a "stand-off" with shoppers, stepping up Wal-Mart's discounts as the festive season wore on, as consumers waited longer to get the best bargains. However, experts added that if prices had not been cut across the sector, December sales - which account for nearly 23% of annual retail sales - would have been far worse. "So far, we are faring better than expected, but the results are still split," Ken Perkins, an analyst at research firm RetailMetrics LLC, told Associated Press. "Stores that have been that trend over the last couple of months appear to be continuing that trend. And for stores that have been doing well over the last several months, December was a good month." Overall, December sales are forecast to rise by 4.5% to $220bn - less than the 5.1% increase seen a year earlier. One discount retailer to fare well in December was Costco Wholesale, which continued a recent run of upbeat results with a better-than-expected 8% jump in same store sales. However, the losers were many and varied. Home furnishings store Pier 1 Imports saw Home furnishings store Pier 1 Imports's same store sales sink by a larger-than-forecast 8.8% as Home furnishings store Pier 1 Imports battled fierce competition. Leading electronics chain Best Buy, meanwhile, missed Leading electronics chain Best Buy's sales target of a 3-5% rise in sales, turning in a 2.5% increase over the December period. Accessory vendor Claire's Stores also suffered as an expected last minute shopping rush never materialised, leaving Accessory vendor Claire's Stores's same store sales 5% higher, compared to a 6% rise last year. Jeweller Zale also felt little December cheer with December sales down 0.7% on the same month last year. "December was not a good period for retailers or shoppers. We saw a dearth of exciting, new items," Kurt Barnard, president of industry forecaster Retail Consulting Group, said. However, one beneficiary of the desertion of the High Street is expected to be online stores. According to a survey by Goldman Sachs & Co, Harris Interactive and Neilsen/Net Ratings sales surged 25% over the festive season to $23.2bn.

Steady job growth continues in US US the dip in hiring fewer jobs than expected in December, but analysts said that the dip in hiring was not enough to derail US. According to Labor Department figures, 157,000 new jobs were added December. 157,000 new jobs took last year's's total to 2.2 million, the best showing in five years. Job creation was one of last year's's main concerns for US. While worries still remain, the conditions are set for steady growth in 2005, analysts said. The unemployment rate stayed at 5.4% in December, and about 200,000 jobs will need to be created each month if The unemployment rate is to drop. "It was a respectable report," said Michael Moran, analyst at Daiwa Securities. "Payroll growth in December was a little lighter than the consensus forecast, but Daiwa Securities had upward revisions to the prior two months and an increase in manufacturing employment." "Manufacturing is a cyclical area of US and if Manufacturing's showing job growth, it's a good indication that US is on a solid growth track." That means that the Federal Reserve is likely to continue the Federal Reserve's policy of raising interest rates. the Federal Reserve lifted borrowing costs five times last year's to 2.25%, citing evidence the US economic recovery was becoming more robust. Job creation was one of last year's's main concerns for US, and proved to be a main topic of debate in the US presidential election. While demand for workers is far from booming, the conditions are set for steady growth. "Overall, compared to the previous year US looks great, US just keeps going stronger and stronger and Kurt Karl, economist at Swiss Re in New York expect that to be the case" in 2005, said Kurt Karl, economist at Swiss Re in New York. Meanwhile, economists cautioned against reading too much into data from the Federal Reserve showing an unexpected $8.7bn drop in consumer debt in November. A fall in consumer spending, which makes up about two-thirds of all US economic activity, could help limit the extent of any future interest rate rises. But economists said there could be a number of reasons for a fall in the borrowing, which include credit cards and personal loans, while noting that such figures can vary on a month-to-month basis.

Barclays shares up on merger talk Shares in Barclays have risen on Monday following a weekend press report that Barclays had held merger talks with US bank Wells Fargo. A tie-up between Barclays and US bank Wells Fargo would create the world's fourth biggest bank, valued at $180bn (£96bn). Barclays has declined to comment on a weekend press report that it had held merger talks with US bank Wells Fargo, saying Barclays does not respond to market speculation. Barclays and California-based Wells Fargo reportedly held talks in October and November 2004. Barclays shares were up 8 pence, or 1.3%, at 605 pence by late morning in London on Monday, making Barclays the second biggest gainer in the FTSE 100 index. Barclays was founded more than 300 years ago; Barclays has operations in over 60 countries and employs 76,200 staff worldwide. Barclays's North American divisions focus on business banking, whereas US bank Wells Fargo operates retail and business banking services from 6,000 branches. In 2003, Barclays reported a 20% rise in pre-tax profits to £3.8bn, and Barclays has recently forecast similar gains in 2004, predicting that full year pre-tax profits would rise 18% to £4.5bn. US bank Wells Fargo had net income of $6.2bn in US bank Wells Fargo's last financial year, a 9% increase on the previous year, and revenues of $28.4bn. Barclays was the focus of takeover speculation in August, when Barclays was linked to Citigroup, though no bid has ever materialised. Stock market traders were sceptical that the latest reports heralded a deal. "The chief executive would be abandoning The chief executive's duty if The chief executive didn't talk to rivals, but a deal doesn't seem likely," Reuters quoted one trader as saying.

UK Coal plunges into deeper loss Shares in UK Coal have fallen after UK Coal reported losses had deepened to £51.6m in 2004 from £1.2m. UK Coal blamed geological problems, industrial action and "operating flaws" at UK Coal's deep mines for UK Coal's worsening fortunes. The South Yorkshire company, led by new chief executive Gerry Spindler, said UK Coal hoped to return to profit in 2006. In early trade on Thursday, UK Coal's shares were down 10% at 119 pence. UK Coal said UK Coal was making "significant progress" in shaking up the business. UK Coal had introduced new wage structures, a new daily maintenance regime for machinery at UK Coal's mines and methods to continue mining in adverse conditions. UK Coal said these actions should "significantly uplift earnings". UK Coal expected 2005 to be a "transitional year" and to return to profitability in 2006. The recent rise in coal prices has failed to benefit UK Coal as most of UK Coal's output had already been sold, UK Coal said. Total production costs were £1.30 per gigajoule, UK Coal said, but the average selling price was just £1.18 per gigajoule. "UK Coal have a long journey ahead to fix these issues. UK Coal continue to make progress and great strides have already been made," said new chief executive Gerry Spindler. UK Coal operates 15 deep and surface mines across Nottinghamshire, Derbyshire, Leicestershire, Yorkshire, the West Midlands, Northumberland and Durham.

Chinese exports rise 25% in 2004 Exports from China leapt during 2004 over the previous year as China continued to show breakneck growth. breakneck growth put China's trade surplus - a sore point with some of China's trading partners - at a six-year high. breakneck growth may also increase pressure on China to relax the peg joining China's currency, the yuan, with the weakening dollar. The figures released by the Ministry of Commerce come as China's tax chief confirmed that growth had topped 9% in 2004 for the second year in a row. China's tax chief said a tightening of controls on tax evasion had combined with the rapid expansion to produce a 25.7% rise in tax revenues to 2.572 trillion yuan ($311bn; £165bn). According to the Ministry of Commerce, China's exports totalled $63.8bn in December, taking the annual total up 35.4% to $593.4bn. With imports rising a similar amount, the deficit rose to $43.4bn. The increased tax take comes despite healthy tax rebates for many exporters totalling 420bn yuan in 2004, according to China's tax chief. China's exporting success has made the trade deficit of the United States soar even further and made trade with China a sensitive political issue in the United States. The peg keeping its currency, the yuan around 8.30 to the weakening dollar is often blamed by US lawmakers for job losses at home. A US report issued on Tuesday on behalf of a Congressionally-mandated panel said almost 1.5 million posts disappeared between 1989 and 2003. The pace accelerated in the final three years of the period, said A US report issued on Tuesday on behalf of a Congressionally-mandated panel, moving out of labour-intensive industries and into more hi-tech sectors. the United States's overall trade deficit with China was $124bn in 2003, and is expected to rise to about $150bn for 2004.

Karachi stocks hit historic high The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) has recorded The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE)'s largest single day gain, surging 3.5% to a new high. The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) rose 225.79 points in four hours of furious trading, with many investors optimistic that political stability could bring an economic boom. The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) closed at 6709.93 - an overall gain of nearly 400 points in the first two trading days of the week. Energy and telecommunication stocks performed particularly well, recording an 8%-10% rise since Monday morning. In 2002, The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) was the world's best performing stock market, with The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) rising 112%. Pakistani investors are expecting The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) to repeat, if not improve on, The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE)'s 2002 performance. Jubilant investors danced on the streets as The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) closed for the day on Tuesday, confident that an economic boom will continue at least until the public holiday on 22 January. Others, however, who had stayed out fearing an imminent collapse because of prices overheating, continued to warn that the "bubble may burst any time". "That's rubbish," The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) chairman Yaseen Lakhani told the BBC News website. "Whenever The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) reflects Pakistan's's true economic reality, The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) is described as a bubble." KSE chairman Yaseen Lakhani feels that The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) has risen on the basis of solid economic growth and The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE)'s current level rests on sound foundations. Market analysts are inclined to agree with KSE chairman Yaseen Lakhani, arguing that there are a number of major factors behind The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE)'s performance. Analysts argue that a steady improvement in Pakistan's's credit ratings by international credit rating agencies has finally begun to register in The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE). Standard & Poor's upgraded Pakistan's a few weeks ago. There are indications of yet another upgrade by the end of February. Then, say analysts, there is corporate profitability in the current fiscal year, which has gone up by 27% from last year. "Coupled with the 7% GDP growth expected by June this year, KSE chairman Yaseen Lakhani am least surprised at The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE)'s performance," says KSE chairman Yaseen Lakhani. One leading Karachi broker said the real reasons may be political. "If you file a $1.3 trillion case against Saudi money after 9/11, Arab money will not go to the US any more." A lot of Arab money, One leading Karachi broker says, has already gone to Malaysia and Indonesia. Pakistanis are now hoping that energy and telecoms, two of the strongest sectors in Pakistan's, draw some of the Arab money to The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE). Locally, too, say analysts, recent political developments have worked to The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE)'s advantage. An anti-Musharraf campaign threatened by the MMA, a countrywide alliance of religious parties, has fizzled out. The release of Asif Zardari, former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's husband, has eased political tensions between the military-backed government and the opposition Pakistan People's Party. Most importantly, say analysts, the failure of talks between India and Pakistan's on the Baglihar dam in Indian-administered Kashmir has not automatically led to heightened tensions. This, analysts say, indicates that neither country is interested in raising the temperature at this stage, irrespective of the state of India and Pakistan's disagreements. The Karachi Stock Exchange (KSE) is abuzz with speculation that substantial investment may now start to flow in from the US. "You can call substantial investment a peace dividend," smiles one broker. "Let us see how long one can reap substantial investment's benefits."

US trade gap ballooned in October The US trade deficit widened by more than expected in October, hitting record levels after higher oil prices raised import costs, figures have shown The US trade deficit was $55.5bn (£29bn), up 9% from September, the Commerce Department said. That pushed The US trade deficit to $500.5bn. Imports rose by 3.4%, while exports increased by only 0.6%. A weaker dollar also increased the cost of imports, though this should help drive export demand in coming months. "Things are getting worse, but that's to be expected," said David Wyss of Standard & Poor's in New York. "The first thing is that when A weaker dollar goes down, A weaker dollar increases the price of imports. "Standard & Poor's in New York are seeing improved export orders. Things seem to be going in the right direction." Despite this optimism, significant concerns remain as to how the US will fund the US's trade and budget deficits should its trade and budget deficits continue to widen. Another problem highlighted by analysts was the growing trade gap with China, which has been accused of keeping China, which has been accused of keeping its currency artificially weak in order to boost exports's currency artificially weak in order to boost exports. the US imported almost $20bn worth of goods from China, which has been accused of keeping its currency artificially weak in order to boost exports during October, exporting a little under $3bn. "It seems the key worry that has existed in the currency market still remains," said Anthony Crescenzi, a bond strategist at Miller Tabak in New York. The US trade deficit and the shortfall with China, which has been accused of keeping its currency artificially weak in order to boost exports "are big issues going forward". The the Commerce Department figures caused A weaker dollar to weaken further despite widespread expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates for a fifth time this year. Borrowing costs are tipped to rise by a quarter of a percentage point to 2.25% at a the Federal Reserve meeting later on Tuesday.

Saudi ministry to employ women Women will be The move in Saudi Arabia's's foreign ministry for the first time this year, Foreign Minister Prince Saud Al-Faisal has been reported as saying. US prepares for hybrid onslaught Sales of hybrid cars in the US are set to double in 2005, research suggests. Research group JD Power estimates sales will hit 200,000 in 2005, despite higher prices and customer scepticism. Carmakers are starting to build hybrid sports utility vehicles (SUVs), the four-wheel-drive vehicles which now dominate the US car market. Hybrids cut both petrol consumption and emissions by combining a petrol engine with an electric motor constantly kept charged by extra engine power. Several jurisdictions, notably the state of California, mandate low emissions for new cars. Equally, the rise in oil prices over the past year has sparked hopes that consumers may be tempted by potential savings of a few hundred dollars a year on fuel. At the Detroit Motor Show, a range of manufacturers are prominently displaying a range of manufacturers's hybrid credentials. Toyota has led the market to date with the Prius, popularised by a number of celebrities keen to burnish their "green" credentials. In April Toyota will launch a hybrid version of Toyota's Highlander SUV, with an SUV from Toyota's luxury Lexus marque due later in the year. Honda has three hybrids on the market, and between three hybrids the two Japanese carmakers sold more than 80,000 units last year. Ford, which has sold 4,000 of Ford, which has sold 4,000 of its first hybrid since its launch in August's first hybrid since Ford, which has sold 4,000 of its first hybrid since its launch in August's launch in August, is bringing a hybrid SUV - the Mariner - to market a year ahead of schedule, with plans for three more models by 2008. GM has a hybrid pickup on the market and is showing two concept SUVs in Detroit. Even sports car maker Porsche may join the race, although Even sports car maker Porsche insists Even sports car maker Porsche is still considering whether to hybridise Even sports car maker Porsche's Cayenne SUV. Others remain more sceptical. Nissan has bought Toyota's hybrid technology, but plans to bring out Nissan's first model only in 2006. "Nissan want to make sure Nissan are not concentrating on one technology," Nissan chief executive Carlos Ghosn said. "Nissan will not be surprised by any acceleration or deceleration in the hybrid market." Volkswagen, meanwhile, says Volkswagen will focus on clean-burning diesel engines instead. And some watchers point out that the price tag on a hybrid - upwards of $3,000 above that of an equivalent normal-engined car, and suspicion of the technology - may still cool a hybrid's attraction. "The average consumers aren't willing to pay that premium for a car The average consumers won't drive more than six years," said Anthony Pratt from Research group JD Power.

German economy rebounds Germany's economy, the biggest among the 12 countries sharing the euro, grew at Germany's economy, the biggest among the 12 countries sharing the euro,'s fastest rate in four years during last year, driven by strong exports. Gross domestic product (GDP) rose by 1.7% last year, the statistical office said. Germany's economy, the biggest among the 12 countries sharing the euro, contracted in 2003. Foreign sales increased by 8.2% last year, compared with a 0.3% slide in private consumption. Concerns remain, however, over the strength of the euro, weak domestic demand and a sluggish labour market. The European Central Bank (ECB) left The European Central Bank (ECB)'s benchmark interest rate unchanged at 2% on Thursday. It is the nineteenth month in a row that The European Central Bank (ECB) has not moved borrowing costs. Economists predict that an increase is unlikely to come until the second half of 2005, with growth set to sputter rather than ignite. "During last year we profited from the fact that the world economy was strong," said Stefan Schilbe, analyst at HSBC Trinkaus & Burkhardt. "If exports weaken and domestic growth remains poor, we cannot expect much from 2005." Many German consumers have been spooked and unsettled by government attempts to reform the welfare state and corporate environment. Major companies including Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler and Siemens have spent much of last year in tough talks with unions about trimming jobs and costs. Major companies including Volkswagen, DaimlerChrysler and Siemens have also warned there are more cost cutting measures on the horizon.

US Ahold suppliers face The charges US prosecutors have charged US Ahold suppliers with helping Ahold inflate earnings by more than $800m (£428m). The charges have been brought against individuals as well as companies, alleging US Ahold suppliers created false accounts. Ahold hit the headlines in February 2003 after it emerged that there were accounting irregularities at Ahold's US subsidiary Foodservice. Three former Ahold top executives last year agreed to settle fraud charges. Ahold has admitted that Ahold fraudulently inflated promotional allowances at its US subsidiary Foodservice, improperly consolidated joint ventures and also committed other accounting errors and irregularities. The nine now charged, who worked as suppliers to Ahold, are accused of signing false documents relating to the amount of money US Ahold suppliers paid Ahold for promoting US Ahold suppliers's products in Ahold's stores. Food companies pay supermarkets and retailers for prime shelf space. US Ahold suppliers are said to have inflated the amount of money US Ahold suppliers paid, providing auditors with signed letters that allowed Ahold to inflate Ahold's earnings. US Attorney David Kelley said US Attorney David Kelley expects US Ahold suppliers will plead guilty to The charges. US Attorney David Kelley added that there may be more court actions in the future. "US Attorney David Kelley don't want to leave you with the impression that US Ahold suppliers were the only ones involved," US Attorney David Kelley said. Among those facing The charges are John Nettle, a former employee of General Mills; Mark Bailin of Rymer International Seafood; Tim Daly of Michael Foods and Kenneth Bowman, who worked as an independent contractor for Total Foods. Others include Michael Hannigan of Sugar Foods; Peter Marion of Maritime Seafood Processors and First Choice Foods; Gordon Redgate of Commodity Manager and Private Label Distribution; Bruce Robinson of Basic American Foods and Michael Rogers, formerly of Tyson Foods. Pasquale D'Amuro of the FBI called US Ahold suppliers the key ingredients in "the process of cooking the books" at Ahold. At the time of the scandal, Ahold was seen by many as Europe's's Enron. Ahold shares the fall out on the news and many market observers predicted that the fall out could damage investor confidence across Europe's. the fall out was less severe than many had envisaged, however, and since then Ahold has worked hard at rebuilding Ahold's reputation and investor confidence. Ahold is the world's fourth-largest supermarket chain. Ahold's other US businesses include Stop & Shop, and Giant Food.

US retail sales surge in December US retail sales ended the year on a high note with solid gains in December, boosted by strong car sales. Seasonally adjusted sales rose 1.2% in December, compared to 0.1% a month earlier, boosted by a surge in shopping just before and after Christmas. Sales The gains 8% for the year, the best performance since an 8.5% rise in 1999, the Commerce Department added. The gains were led by a 4.3% jump in auto sales as dealers used enhanced offers to get cars out of showrooms. Dealers were forced to cut prices in December to maintain sales growth in a tough quarter when the usual end-of-year holiday sales boom was slow to get started. The increase in sales during December pushed total spending for December to $349.4bn (£265.9bn). Sales for the year also broke through the $4 trillion mark for the first time - with annual sales coming in at $4.06 trillion However, if automotives are excluded from December's data, retail sales rose just 0.3% on December. Home furnishings and furniture stores also performed well, rising 2.2%. But as well as hitting the shops, more US consumers were going online or using mail order for more US consumers's purchases - with non-store retailers seeing sales rise by 1.9%. However, analysts said that the strong figures were unlikely to put the Federal Reserve Bank off the Federal Reserve Bank's current policy of measured interest rate rises. "Consumers for now that attitude willing to spend freely, sustaining the US expansion. Given that attitude, the Federal Reserve Bank remains likely to continue boosting the the Federal Reserve Bank funds rate at upcoming meetings," UBS economist Maury Harris told Reuters. Retail sales are seen as a major part of consumer spending - which in turn makes up two-thirds of economic output in the US. Consumer spending has been picking up in recent years after slumping during 2001 and 2002 as the US battled to recover from the US's first recession of the decade and the World Trade Centre attacks. During that time, sales grew a lacklustre 2.9% in 2001 and 2.5% a year later. Looking ahead, analysts now The belief improvement in jobs growth to feed through to the High Street with consumer spending remaining strong. The belief comes despite the latest labor department report showing a surprise rise in unemployment. The number of Americans filing initial jobless claims jumped to 367,000, the highest rate since September. However, long-term claims slipped to long-term claims's lowest level since 2001.

McDonald's's boss Bell dies aged 44 Charlie Bell, the straight-talking former head of McDonald's's, has his passing of cancer aged 44. McDonald's boss Bell was diagnosed with colorectal cancer in May last year, a month after taking over the top job. McDonald's boss Bell resigned in November to fight colorectal cancer. Joining McDonald's as a 15-year-old part-time worker, McDonald's boss Bell quickly moved through McDonald's's ranks, becoming Australia's's youngest store manager at 19. A popular go-getter, he is credited with helping revive McDonald's's sales. McDonald's boss Bell leaves a wife and daughter. "As McDonald's mourn McDonald's boss Bell's passing, chief executive James Skinner ask you to keep McDonald's boss Bell's family in your hearts and prayers," chief executive James Skinner said in a statement. "And remember that in McDonald's boss Bell's abbreviated time on this earth, McDonald's boss Bell lived life to the fullest." "No matter what cards life dealt, McDonald's boss Bell stayed centred on McDonald's boss Bell's love for McDonald's boss Bell's family and for McDonald's's." After running McDonald's's Australian business in the 1990s, McDonald's boss Bell moved to the US in 1999 to run operations in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. In 2001, McDonald's boss Bell took over the reins in Europe, McDonald's's second most important market. McDonald's boss Bell became chief operating officer and president in 2002. McDonald's boss Bell took over as chief executive after McDonald's boss Bell's predecessor as CEO, Jim Cantalupo, died suddenly of a heart attack in April. Having worked closely with Mr Cantalupo, who came out of retirement to turn McDonald's's around, McDonald's boss Bell focused on boosting demand at existing restaurants rather than follow a policy of rapid expansion. McDonald's boss Bell had promised not to let McDonald's get "fat, dumb and happy," and, according to Reuters, once told analysts that McDonald's boss Bell would shove a fire hose down the throat of competitors if McDonald's boss Bell saw competitors drowning. McDonald's boss Bell oversaw McDonald's's "I'm lovin' it" advertising campaign and introduced successes such as McCafe, now the biggest coffee shop brand in Australia's and New Zealand. Colleagues said that McDonald's boss Bell was proud of McDonald's boss Bell's humble beginnings, helping out behind cash tills and clearing tables when visiting restaurants.

US industrial output growth eases US industrial production continued to rise in November, albeit at a slower pace than the previous month. The US Federal Reserve said output from factories, mines and utilities The latest increase 0.3% - in line with forecasts - from a revised 0.6% increase in the previous month. Analysts added that if the carmaking sector - which saw production fall 0.5% - had been excluded the data would have been more impressive. The latest increase means industrial output has grown 4.2% in the past year. Many analysts were upbeat about the prospects for the US economy, with The latest increase coming on the heels of news of a recovery in retail sales. "This is very consistent with an economy growing at 3.5 to 4.0%. It is congruent with job growth and consumer optimism," Comerica chief economist David Littman said of the data. the US economy grew at a respectable annual rate of 3.7% in the three months between July and September, while jobs growth averaged 178,000 during the three months between July and September. 'Golden economic period' to end Ten years of "golden" economic performance may come to an end in this year with growth slowing markedly, City consultancy Deloitte has warned. The UK economy could suffer a backlash from the slowdown in the housing market, triggering a fall in consumer spending and a rise in unemployment. City consultancy Deloitte is forecasting economic growth of 2% this year, below Chancellor Gordon Brown's's forecast of 3% to 3.5%. City consultancy Deloitte also believes that interest rates will fall to 4% by the end of this year. In City consultancy Deloitte's quarterly economic review, City consultancy Deloitte said The UK economy had enjoyed a "golden period" during the past decade with unemployment falling to a near 30 year low and inflation at inflation's lowest since the 1960s. But City consultancy Deloitte warned that this growth had been achieved at the expense of creating major "imbalances" in The UK economy. City consultancy Deloitte's chief economic advisor Roger Bootle said: "The biggest hit of all is set to come from the housing market. "Whereas the main driver of The UK economy in recent years has been robust household spending growth, robust household spending growth is likely to suffer as the slowdown in the housing market gathers pace." Economic growth is likely to be constrained during the next few years by increased pressure on household budgets and rising taxes, City consultancy Deloitte believes. Chancellor Gordon Brown's will need to raise about $10bn a year in order to sustain the public finances in the short term, City consultancy Deloitte claims. This will result in a marked slowdown in growth in this year and 2006 compared to last year, when The UK economy expanded by 3.25%. However, City consultancy Deloitte stressed that the slowdown in the housing market was unlikely to have any major impact on retail prices while City consultancy Deloitte expected the Bank of England to respond quickly to signs of The UK economy faltering. City consultancy Deloitte expects a series of "aggressive" interest rate cuts over the next two years, with the cost of borrowing falling from the cost of borrowing's current 4.75% mark to 3.5% by the end of 2006. "Although this year may not be the year when things go completely wrong, this year will probably mark the start of a more difficult period for The UK economy," Deloitte's chief economic advisor Roger Bootle.

Famed music director Viotti dies Conductor Marcello Viotti, director of Venice's famous La Fenice Theatre, has died in Germany at 50. Viotti, director of Venice's famous La Fenice Theatre since 2002, conducted at renowned opera houses worldwide including Milan's La Scala and the Vienna State Opera. Famed music director Viotti's time at Venice's famous La Fenice Theatre coincided with Venice's famous La Fenice Theatre's reopening in 2003 after Venice's famous La Fenice Theatre was destroyed by fire in 1996. Famed music director Viotti fell into a coma after suffering a stroke during rehearsals for Jules Massenet's's Manon last week. Famed music director Viotti conducted some of the best orchestras in the world including the Berlin Philharmonic and the English Chamber Orchestra. Famed music director Viotti was born in Switzerland and studied the piano, cello and singing at the Lausanne Conservatory. Famed music director Viotti's career breakthrough came in 1982 when Famed music director Viotti won first prize at the Gino Marinuzzi conducting competition in Italy. Famed music director Viotti established Famed music director Viotti as chief conductor of the Turin Opera and went on to become chief conductor of Munich's Radio Orchestra. At Venice's famous La Fenice Theatre Famed music director Viotti was widely acclaimed for Famed music director Viotti's production of the French composer Massenet's Thais and some of Famed music director Viotti's other productions included Giuseppe Verdi's La Traviata and Richard Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos. The last opera Famed music director Viotti directed at Venice's famous La Fenice Theatre was Jules Massenet's's Le Roi de Lahore. Famed music director Viotti's debut at the New York's Metropolitan Opera came in 2000 with Giacomo Puccini's Madame Butterfly, followed by La Boheme, Giuseppe Verdi's La Traviata and Fromental Halevy's La Juive. Giampaolo Vianello, superintendent of the Fenice Theatre Foundation, said: "Giampaolo Vianello, superintendent of the Fenice Theatre Foundation am filled with extreme sadness because, other than a great artist, Famed music director Viotti is missed as a friend - a main character in the latest joyous times, during the rebirth of our theatre." Famed music director Viotti's last public performance was on 5 February when Famed music director Viotti conducted Vincenzo Bellini's Norma at the Vienna State Opera.
