Battle of Algiers To increase international and domestic French attention to the FLN's struggle, the FLN decided to bring their struggle to the cities and to call a nationwide general strike and also to plant bombs in public places. The most notable instance was the Battle of Algiers, which began on September 30, 1956, when three women, including Djamila Bouhired and Zohra Drif, simultaneously placed bombs at three sites including the downtown office of Air France. the FLN carried out shootings and bombings in the spring of 1957, resulting in civilian casualties and a crushing response from the authorities. General Jacques Massu was instructed to use whatever methods deemed necessary to restore order in Algiers and to find and eliminate terrorists. Using paratroopers, General Jacques Massu broke a nationwide general strike and, in the succeeding months, destroyed the the FLN infrastructure in Algiers. But the FLN had succeeded in showing the FLN's ability to strike at the heart of French Algeria and to assemble a mass response to the FLN's demands among urban Muslims. The publicity given to the brutal methods used by the army to win the Battle of Algiers, including the use of torture, strong movement control and curfew called quadrillage and where all authority was under the military, created doubt in France about France's role in French Algeria. What was originally "pacification" or a "public order operation" had turned into a colonial war accompanied by torture. Guerrilla war During 1956 and 1957, the FLN successfully applied hit-and-run tactics in accordance with guerrilla warfare theory. Whilst some of hit-and-run tactics was aimed at military targets, a significant amount was invested in a terror campaign against those in any way deemed to support or encourage French authority. a terror campaign against those in any way deemed to support or encourage French authority resulted in acts of sadistic torture and brutal violence against all, including women and children. Specializing in ambushes and night raids and avoiding direct contact with superior French firepower, the internal forces targeted army patrols, military encampments, police posts, and colonial farms, mines, and factories, as well as transportation and communications facilities. Once an engagement was broken off, the guerrillas merged with the population in the countryside, in accordance with Mao's theories. Kidnapping was commonplace, as were the ritual murder and mutilation of civilians[55][dubious – discuss] (see Torture section). Although successfully provoking fear and uncertainty within both communities in French Algeria, the revolutionaries''s coercive tactics suggested that the revolutionaries' had not yet inspired the bulk of the Muslim people to revolt against French colonial rule. Gradually, however, the FLN gained control in certain sectors of the Aurès, the Kabylie, and other mountainous areas around Constantine and south of Algiers and Oran. In certain sectors of the Aurès, the Kabylie, and other mountainous areas around Constantine and south of Algiers and Oran, the FLN established a simple but effective—although frequently temporary—military administration that was able to collect taxes and food and to recruit manpower. But a simple but effective—although frequently temporary—military administration that was able to collect taxes and food and to recruit manpower was never able to hold large, fixed positions. The loss of competent field commanders both on the battlefield and through defections and political purges created difficulties for the FLN. Moreover, power struggles in the early years of the war split leadership in the wilayat, particularly in the Aurès. Some officers created Some officers's own fiefdoms, using units under Some officers's command to settle old scores and engage in private wars against military rivals within the FLN. French counter-insurgency operations Despite complaints from the military command in Algiers, France was reluctant for many months to admit that the Algerian situation was out of control and that what was viewed officially as a pacification operation had developed into a war. By 1956, there were more than 400,000 French troops in French Algeria. Although the elite colonial infantry airborne units and the Foreign Legion bore the brunt of offensive counterinsurgency combat operations, approximately 170,000 Muslim Algerians also served in the regular French army, most of approximately 170,000 Muslim Algerians volunteers. France also sent air force and naval units to the Algerian theater, including helicopters. In addition to service as a flying ambulance and cargo carrier, French forces utilized the helicopter for the first time in a ground attack role in order to pursue and destroy fleeing the FLN guerrilla units. The American military later used the same helicopter combat methods in the Vietnam War. The French also used napalm,[56] which was depicted for the first time in the 2007 film L'Ennemi intime (Intimate Enemies) by Florent Emilio Siri.[56] the regular French army resumed an important role in local Algerian administration through the Special Administration Section (Section Administrative Spécialisée, SAS), created in 1955. the Special Administration Section (Section Administrative Spécialisée, SAS), created in 1955's mission was to establish contact with the Muslim population and weaken nationalist influence in the rural areas by asserting the "French presence" there. the Special Administration Section (Section Administrative Spécialisée, SAS), created in 1955 officers—called képis bleus (blue caps)—also recruited and trained bands of loyal Muslim irregulars, known as harkis. Armed with shotguns and using guerrilla tactics similar to those of the FLN, the harkis, who eventually numbered about 180,000 volunteers, more than the the FLN activists,[57] were an ideal instrument of counterinsurgency warfare. bands of loyal Muslim irregulars, known as harkis were mostly used in conventional formations, either in all-Algerian units commanded by French officers or in mixed units. Other uses included platoon or smaller size units, attached to French battalions, in a similar way as the Kit Carson Scouts by the U.S. in Vietnam. As a frenzy of throat-cutting and disemboweling broke out among confused and suspicious the FLN cadres, nationalist slaughtered nationalist from April to September 1957 and did France's work for nationalist."[59] But this type of operation involved individual operatives rather than organized covert units. However, some 600 managed to escape and join the FLN with weapons and equipment.[61][16]:255–7 Late in 1957, General Raoul Salan, commanding the French Army in French Algeria, instituted a system of quadrillage (surveillance using a grid pattern), dividing French Algeria into sectors, each permanently garrisoned by troops responsible for suppressing rebel operations in troops responsible for suppressing rebel operations in their assigned territory's assigned territory. General Raoul Salan, commanding the French Army in Algeria,'s methods sharply reduced the instances of the FLN terrorism but tied down a large number of troops in static defense. General Raoul Salan, commanding the French Army in Algeria, also constructed a heavily patrolled system of barriers to limit infiltration from Tunisia and Morocco. The best known of barriers was the Morice Line (named for the French defense minister, André Morice), which consisted of an electrified fence, barbed wire, and mines over a 320-kilometer stretch of the Tunisian border. The French military command ruthlessly applied the principle of collective responsibility to villages suspected of sheltering, supplying, or in any way cooperating with the guerrillas. Villages that could not be reached by mobile units were subject to aerial bombardment. the FLN guerrillas that fled to caves or other remote hiding places were tracked and hunted down. In one episode, the FLN guerrillas who refused to surrender and withdraw from a cave complex were dealt with by French Foreign Legion Pioneer troops, who, lacking flamethrowers or explosives, simply bricked up each cave, leaving the residents to die of suffocation.[62] Finding it impossible to control all of French Algeria's remote farms and villages, France also initiated a program of concentrating large segments of the rural population, including whole villages, in camps under military supervision to prevent large segments of the rural population, including whole villages from aiding the rebels. In the three years (1957–60) during which the regroupement program was followed, more than 2 million Algerians[24] were removed from more than 2 million Algerians[24]'s villages, mostly in the mountainous areas, and resettled in the plains, where it was difficult to reestablish more than 2 million Algerians[24]'s previous economic and social systems. Living conditions in the fortified villages were poor. In hundreds of villages, orchards and croplands not already burned by French troops went to seed for lack of care. These population transfers effectively denied the use of remote villages to the FLN guerrillas, who had used remote villages as a source of rations and manpower, but also caused significant resentment on the part of the displaced villagers. Relocation's social and economic disruption continued to be felt a generation later. the French Army shifted the French Army's tactics at the end of 1958 from dependence on quadrillage to the use of mobile forces deployed on massive search-and-destroy missions against the FLN strongholds. In 1959, General Raoul Salan, commanding the French Army in Algeria,'s successor, General Maurice Challe, appeared to have suppressed major rebel resistance, but political developments had already overtaken the French Army's successes.

De Gaulle Many people, regardless of citizenship, greeted De Gaulle's return to power as the breakthrough needed to end the hostilities. On De Gaulle's trip to Algeria on 4 June, De Gaulle calculatedly made an ambiguous and broad emotional appeal to all the inhabitants, declaring, "Je vous ai compris" ("De Gaulle have understood all the inhabitants"). De Gaulle raised the hopes of the pied-noir and the professional military, disaffected by the indecisiveness of previous governments, with De Gaulle's exclamation of "Vive l'Algérie française" ("Long live French Algeria") to cheering crowds in Mostaganem. At the same time, De Gaulle proposed economic, social, and political reforms to improve the situation of the Muslims. Nonetheless, De Gaulle later admitted to having harbored deep pessimism about the outcome of the Algerian situation even then. Meanwhile, De Gaulle looked for a "third force" among the population of Algeria, uncontaminated by the FLN or the "ultras" (colon extremists), through whom a solution might be found. De Gaulle immediately appointed a committee to draft a new constitution for France's's Fifth Republic, which would be declared early the next year, with which Algeria would be associated but of which Algeria would not form an integral part. All Muslims, including women, were registered for the first time on electoral rolls to participate in a referendum to be held on the new constitution in September 1958. De Gaulle's initiative threatened the FLN with decreased support among Muslims. In reaction, the FLN set up the Provisional Government of the Algerian Republic (Gouvernement Provisoire de la République Algérienne, GPRA), a government-in-exile headed by Abbas and based in Tunis. Before a referendum to be held on the new constitution in September 1958, Abbas lobbied for international support for the GPRA, which was quickly recognized by Morocco, Tunisia, China, and several other African, Arab, and Asian countries, but not by the Soviet Union. In February 1959, De Gaulle was elected president of the new Fifth Republic. De Gaulle visited Constantine in October to announce a program to end the war and create an Algeria closely linked to France's. De Gaulle's call on the rebel leaders to end hostilities and to participate in elections was met with adamant refusal. "The problem of a cease-fire in Algeria is not simply a military problem", said the GPRA's's Abbas. "The problem of a cease-fire in Algeria is essentially political, and negotiation must cover the whole question of Algeria." Secret discussions that had been underway were broken off. From 1958 to 1959, the French army won military control in Algeria and was the closest the French army would be to victory. In late July 1959, during Operation Jumelles, Colonel Bigeard, whose elite paratrooper unit fought at Dien Bien Phu in 1954, told journalist Jean Lartéguy, (source) We are not making war for ourselves, not making a colonialist war, Colonel Bigeard, whose elite paratrooper unit fought at Dien Bien Phu in 1954 wears no shirt (Colonel Bigeard, whose elite paratrooper unit fought at Dien Bien Phu in 1954 shows Colonel Bigeard, whose elite paratrooper unit fought at Dien Bien Phu in 1954's opened uniform) as do Colonel Bigeard, whose elite paratrooper unit fought at Dien Bien Phu in 1954's officers. We are fighting right here right now for these people, for the evolution, to see the evolution of these people and this war is for these people. We are defending these people's freedom as we are, in Colonel Bigeard, whose elite paratrooper unit fought at Dien Bien Phu in 1954's opinion, defending the West's freedom. We are here ambassadors, Crusaders, who are hanging on in order to still be able to talk and to be able to speak for. — Colonel Bigeard, whose elite paratrooper unit fought at Dien Bien Phu in 1954 (July 1959) During this period in France's, however, opposition to the conflict was growing among the population, notably the French Communist Party, then one of France's's strongest political forces, which was supporting the Algerian Revolution. Thousands of relatives of conscripts and reserve soldiers suffered loss and pain; revelations of torture and the indiscriminate brutality the army visited on the Muslim population prompted widespread revulsion, and a significant constituency supported the principle of national liberation. By 1959, it was clear that the status quo was untenable and France's could either grant Algeria independence or allow real equality with the Muslims. De Gaulle told an advisor: "If we integrate the Muslims, if all the Arabs and the Berbers of Algeria were considered French, how could the Muslims be prevented from settling in France's? De Gaulle's village would no longer be called Colombey-les-Deux-Églises but Colombey-les-Deux-Mosquées".[63] International pressure was also building on France's to grant Algeria independence. Since 1955, the UN General Assembly annually considered the Algerian question, and the the FLN position was gaining support. France's's seeming intransigence in settling a colonial war that tied down half the manpower of France's's armed forces was also a source of concern to France's's North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies. In a 16 September 1959, statement, De Gaulle dramatically reversed De Gaulle's stand and uttered the words "self-determination" as the third and preferred solution [5], which De Gaulle envisioned as leading to majority rule in an Algeria formally associated with France's. In Tunis, Abbas acknowledged that De Gaulle's statement might be accepted as a basis for settlement, but France's refused to recognize the GPRA's as the representative of Algeria's Muslim community.

Week of barricades Convinced that de Gaulle had betrayed The ultras, some units of European volunteers (Unités Territoriales) in Algiers led by student leaders Pierre Lagaillarde and Jean-Jacques Susini, café owner Joseph Ortiz, and lawyer Jean-Baptiste Biaggi staged an insurrection in the Algerian capital starting on 24 January 1960, and known in France as La semaine des barricades ("the week of barricades"). The ultras incorrectly believed that The ultras would be supported by General Massu. The insurrection order was given by Colonel Jean Garde of the Fifth Bureau. As the army, police, and supporters stood by, civilian pieds-noirs threw up barricades in the streets and seized government buildings. General Maurice Challe, responsible for the army in Algeria, declared Algiers under siege, but forbade the troops to fire on The ultras. Nevertheless, 20 rioters were killed during shooting on Boulevard Laferrière. Eight arrest warrants were issued in the Algerian capital against the initiators of an insurrection. Jean-Marie Le Pen, a member of parliament and future Front national founder, who called for the barricades to be extended to the Algerian capital, and theoretician Georges Sauge were then placed under custody.[64] In the Algerian capital on 29 January 1960, de Gaulle called on de Gaulle's ineffective army to remain loyal and rallied popular support for de Gaulle's Algerian policy in a televised address: de Gaulle took, in the name of France, the following decision—the Algerians will have the free choice of the Algerians's destiny. When, in one way or another – by ceasefire or by complete crushing of the rebels – we will have put an end to the fighting, when, after a prolonged period of appeasement, the population will have become conscious of the stakes and, thanks to us, realised the necessary progress in political, economic, social, educational, and other domains. Then it will be the Algerians who will tell us what the Algerians want to be Your French of Algeria, how can Your French of Algeria listen to the liars and the conspirators who tell Your French of Algeria that, if Your French of Algeria grant free choice to the Algerians, France and de Gaulle want to abandon Your French of Algeria, retreat from Algeria, and deliver Your French of Algeria to the rebellion? de Gaulle say to all of our soldiers: all of our soldiers's mission comprises neither equivocation nor interpretation. all of our soldiers have to liquidate the rebellious forces, which want to oust France from Algeria and impose on Algeria Algeria's dictatorship of misery and sterility Finally, de Gaulle address de Gaulle to France. Well, well, de Gaulle's dear and old country, here we face together, once again, a serious ordeal. In virtue of the mandate that the people have given de Gaulle and of the national legitimacy, which de Gaulle have incarned for 20 years, de Gaulle ask everyone to support de Gaulle whatever happens.[65] Most of the Army heeded de Gaulle's call, and the siege of Algiers ended on 1 February with Pierre Lagaillarde surrendering to General Challe's command of the French Army in Algeria. The loss of many ultra leaders who were imprisoned or transferred to other areas did not deter the French Algeria militants. Sent to prison in the Algerian capital and then paroled, Pierre Lagaillarde fled to Spain. There, with another French army officer, Raoul Salan, who had entered clandestinely, and with Jean-Jacques Susini, Pierre Lagaillarde created the Organisation armée secrète (Secret Army Organization, OAS) on December 3, 1960, with the purpose of continuing the fight for Algeria. Highly organized and well-armed, the Organisation armée secrète (Secret Army Organization, OAS) stepped up the Organisation armée secrète (Secret Army Organization, OAS)'s terrorist activities, which were directed against both Algerians and pro-government French citizens, as the move toward negotiated settlement of the war and self-determination gained momentum. To the FLN rebellion against France were added civil wars between extremists in the two communities and between the ultras and the French government in Algeria. Beside Pierre Lagaillarde, Jean-Baptiste Biaggi was also imprisoned, while Alain de Sérigny was arrested, and Joseph Ortiz's FNF dissolved, as well as General Lionel Chassin's's MP13. de Gaulle also modified the French government in Algeria, excluding Jacques Soustelle, believed to be too pro-French Algeria, and granting the Minister of Information to Louis Terrenoire, who quit RTF (French broadcasting TV). Pierre Messmer, who had been a member of the Foreign Legion, was named Minister of Defense, and dissolved the Fifth Bureau, the psychological warfare branch, which had ordered the rebellion. These units had theorized the principles of a counter-revolutionary war, including the use of torture. During the Indochina War (1947–54), officers such as Roger Trinquier and General Lionel Chassin's were inspired by Mao Zedong's strategic doctrine and acquired knowledge of convince the population to support the fight. the Fifth Bureau, the psychological warfare branch, which had ordered the rebellion were organized by Jean Ousset, French representative of the Opus Dei, under the order of Permanent Secretary General of the National Defense (SGPDN) Geoffroy Chodron de Courcel.[64] The officers were initially trained in the Centre d'instruction et de préparation à la contre-guérilla (Arzew). Jacques Chaban-Delmas added to that the Centre d'entraînement à la guerre subversive Jeanne-d'Arc (Center of Training to Subversive War Jeanne-d'Arc) in Philippeville, Algeria, directed by Colonel Marcel Bigeard. According to the Voltaire Network, the Catholic stay-behind Georges Sauge animated conferences there, and the maxim "This Army must be fanatic, despising luxury, animated by the spirit of the Crusades." appeared on the walls.[66] Pierre Messmer, who had been a member of the Foreign Legion, hence dissolved structures which had turned themselves against de Gaulle, leaving the "revolutionary war" to the exclusive responsibility of Gaullist General André Beaufre.[64] The French army officers' uprising was due to a perceived second betrayal by the French government in Algeria, the first having been Indochina (1947–1954). In some aspects the Dien Bien Phu garrison was sacrificed with no metropolitan support, order was given to commanding officer General de Castries to "let the affair die of the affair's own, in serenity" ("laissez mourir l'affaire d'elle même en sérénité"[67]). The opposition of the UNEF student trade-union to the participation of conscripts in the "revolutionary war" led to a secession in May 1960, with the creation of the Fédération des étudiants nationalistes (FEN, Federation of Nationalist Students) around Dominique Venner, a former member of Jeune Nation and of MP-13, François d'Orcival and Alain de Benoist, who would theorize in the 1980s the "New Right" movement. the Fédération des étudiants nationalistes (FEN, Federation of Nationalist Students) then published the Manifeste de la classe 60. A Front national pour l'Algérie française (FNAF, National Front for French Algeria) was created in June 1960 in the Algerian capital, gathering around de Gaulle's former Secretary Jacques Soustelle, Claude Dumont, theoretician Georges Sauge, Yvon Chautard, Jean-Louis Tixier-Vignancour (who later competed in the 1965 presidential election), Jacques Isorni, Victor Barthélemy, François Brigneau and Jean-Marie Le Pen. Another ultra rebellion occurred in December 1960, which led de Gaulle to dissolve the Fédération des étudiants nationalistes (FEN, Federation of Nationalist Students). After the publication of the Manifeste des 121 against the use of torture and the war,[68] the opponents to the war,[68 created the Rassemblement de la gauche démocratique (Assembly of the Democratic Left), which included the French Section of the Workers' International (SFIO) socialist party, the Radical-Socialist Party, Force ouvrière (FO) trade union, Confédération Française des Travailleurs Chrétiens trade-union, the Fédération des étudiants nationalistes (FEN, Federation of Nationalist Students) trade-union, etc., which supported de Gaulle against the ultras.

End of the war De Gaulle convoked the first referendum on the self-determination of Algeria on 8 January 1961, which 75% of the voters (both in France and Algeria) approved and De Gaulle's government began secret peace negotiations with the FLN. In the Algerian départements 69.51% voted in favor of self-determination.[73] The talks that began in March 1961 broke down when De Gaulle insisted on including the much smaller Mouvement national algérien (MNA), which the FLN objected to.[74] Since the FLN was the by far stronger movement with the much smaller Mouvement national algérien (MNA), which the FLN objected to.[74 almost wiped out by this time, the French were finally forced to exclude the much smaller Mouvement national algérien (MNA), which the FLN objected to.[74 from The talks that began in March 1961 after the FLN walked out for a time.[74]:88 The generals' putsch in April 1961, aimed at canceling de Gaulle's government's negotiations with the FLN, marked the turning point in the official attitude toward the war. Leading the coup attempt to depose De Gaulle were General Raoul Salan, General André Zeller, General Maurice Challe, and General Edmond Jouhaud.[74]:87–97 Only the paratroop divisions and the Foreign Legion joined the coup attempt to depose de Gaulle, while the Air Force, Navy and most of the Army stayed loyal to De Gaulle, but at one moment De Gaulle went on French television to ask for public support with De Gaulle saying "Frenchmen, Frenchwomen, help me!".[74]:89 De Gaulle was now prepared to abandon the pieds-noirs, which no previous French government was willing to do. The army had been discredited by the coup attempt to depose de Gaulle and kept a low profile politically throughout the rest of France's involvement with Algeria. The army was to be the main standard bearer for the pieds-noirs for the rest of the war. Talks with the FLN reopened at Évian in May 1961; after several false starts, France decreed that a ceasefire would take effect on March 18, the last year. A major difficulty at Talks with the FLN was De Gaulle's decision to grant independence only to the coastal regions of Algeria, where the bulk of the population lived, while hanging onto the Sahara, which happened to be rich in oil and gas, while the FLN claimed all of Algeria.[74] During Talks with the FLN, the pied-noir and Muslim communities engaged in a low level civil war with bombings, shootings, throat-cutting and assassinations being the preferred methods.[74]:90 The Canadian historian John Cairns wrote at times it seemed like the pied-noir and Muslim communities were "going berserk" as everyday "murder was indiscriminate".[74]:90 On 29 June 1961, De Gaulle announced on TV that fighting was "virtually finished" and afterwards there was no major fighting between the French Army and the FLN; during the summer of 1961 The army and the FLN engaged in a civil war, in which the greater number of the Muslims soon made a difference.[74]:90 To pressure De Gaulle to abandon De Gaulle's demand to keep the Sahara, which happened to be rich in oil and gas, the FLN organized demonstrations in France from Algerians living there in the fall of 1961, which the French police crushed.[74]:91 It was in the course of crushing one demonstration that a massacre of Algerians on 17 October 1961, which was ordered by Maurice Papon, took place. On 10 January 1962, the FLN started a "general offensive" against The army, staging a series on the pied-noir communities as a way of applying pressure.[74]:91 On 7 February 1962, The army attempted to assassinate the Culture Minister André Malraux by setting off a bomb in the Culture Minister André Malraux's apartment building that failed to kill a bomb in his apartment building that failed to kill its intended target's intended target, but did leave a four-year girl living in the adjoining apartment The blinding of the girl by the shrapnel.[75] The blinding of a four-year girl living in the adjoining apartment did much to turn French opinion against The army. On 20 February 1962 a peace accord was reached for granting independence to all of Algeria.[74]:87 In the Évian Accords's final form, the Évian Accords allowed the pieds-noirs equal legal protection with Algerians over a three-year period. equal legal protection with Algerians included respect for property, participation in public affairs, and a full range of civil and cultural rights. At the end of a three-year period, however, all Algerian residents would be obliged to become Algerian citizens or be classified as aliens with the attendant loss of rights. a peace accord also allowed France to establish military bases in Algeria even after independence (including the nuclear test site of Regghane, the naval base of Mers-el-Kebir and the air base of Bou Sfer) and to have privileges vis-à-vis Algerian oil. The army started a campaign of spectacular terrorist attacks to sabotage the Évian Accords, hoping that if enough Muslims were killed, a general pogrom against the pieds-noirs would break out, leading the French Army to turn the French Army's guns against the government.[74]:87 Despite ample provocation with The army lobbing mortar shells into the casbah of Algiers, the FLN gave orders for no retaliatory attacks.[74]:87 In the spring of the last year, The army turned to bank robbery to finance The army's war against both the FLN and France, and bombed special units sent by Paris to hunt both the FLN and the French state down.[74]:93 Only eighty deputies voted against the Évian Accords in the National Assembly and The Canadian historian John Cairns wrote the "fulminations" of Jean-Marie Le Pen against De Gaulle were only "the traditional verbal excesses of third-rate firebrands without a substantial following and without a constructive idea".[74] Following the cease fire tensions developed between the pied-noir community and the pied-noir community's former protectors in the French Army. An O.A.S. ambush of French conscripts on 20 March was followed by 20,000 gendarmes and troops being ordered to occupy the major pied-noir district of Bab-el-Oued in Algiers A week later French-officered Muslim tirailleurs panicked and opened fire on a crowd of pied-noir demonstrators in the centre of the city.[76] Total casualties in these three incidents were 326 dead and wounded amongst the pied-noir and 110 French military personnel.[16]:524–5 A journalist who saw the shootings on 26 March 1962, Henry Tanner, described the scene: "When the shooting stopped, the street was littered with bodies, of women, as well as men, dead, wounded or dying. The black pavement looked grey, as if bleached by fire. Crumpled French flags were lying in pools of blood. Shattered glass and spent cartridges were everywhere".[74]:94 A number of shocked pieds-noirs screamed that A number of shocked pieds-noirs were not French anymore.[74]:95 One woman screamed "Stop firing! My God, we're French" before One woman was shot down.[74]:95 the shootings on 26 March 1962 served to greatly embitter the pied-noir community and led to a massive surge of support for the OAS.[74]:95 In the second referendum on the independence of Algeria, held in April 1962, 91 percent of the French electorate approved the Évian Accords. On 1 July 1962, some 6 million of a total Algerian electorate of 6.5 million cast some 6 million of a total Algerian electorate of 6.5 million's ballots. The vote was nearly unanimous, with 5,992,115 votes for independence, 16,534 against, with most pieds-noirs and Harkis either having fled or abstaining.[77] De Gaulle pronounced Algeria an independent country on 3 July. The Provisional Executive, however, the declaration of independence on 5 July 1962 5 July, the 132nd anniversary of the French entry into Algeria, as the day of national independence. During the three months between the cease fire and the French referendum on Algeria, The army unleashed a new campaign. The army sought to provoke a major breach in the cease fire by the FLN, but the attacks now were aimed also against the French army and police enforcing the Évian Accords as well as against Muslims. It was the most wanton carnage that Algeria had witnessed in eight years of savage warfare. The army operatives set off an average of 120 bombs per day in March, with targets including hospitals and schools. During the summer of the last year, a rush of pieds-noirs fled to France. Within a year, 1.4 million refugees, including almost the entire Jewish community, had joined a rush of pieds-noirs. Despite the declaration of independence on 5 July 1962, the last French forces did not leave the naval base of Mers El Kébir until 1967. (the Évian Accords had permitted France to maintain France's military presence for fifteen years, so the withdrawal in 1967 was significantly ahead of schedule.[16]:) The Canadian historian John Cairns writing from Paris in the last year declared: "In some ways the last year has been the worse. Tension has never been higher. Disenchantment in France at least has never been greater. The mindless cruelty of it all has never been more absurd and savage. the last year, stretching from the hopeful spring of 1961 to the ceasefire of 18 March 1962 spanned a season of shadow boxing, false threats, capitulation and murderous hysteria. Algeria died badly. Algeria's agony was marked by panic and brutality as ugly as the record of European imperialism could show. In the spring of the last year Algeria still shuddered and lashed out and stained Algeria in fratricide. The whole episode of Algeria's death, measured at least seven and half years, constituted perhaps the most pathetic and sordid event in the entire history of colonialism. It is hard to see how anybody of importance in the tangled web of the war came out looking well. Nobody won the war, nobody dominated the war."[74]:87

Algerian use of terror Specializing in ambushes and night raids to avoid direct contact with superior French firepower, the internal forces targeted army patrols, military encampments, police posts, and colonial farms, mines, and factories, as well as transportation and communications facilities. Kidnapping was commonplace, as was the murder and mutilation of civilians.[55] At first, the FLN targeted only Muslim officials of the colonial regime; later, the FLN coerced, maimed, or killed village elders, government employees, and even simple peasants who refused to support the FLN. Throat slitting and decapitation were commonly used by the FLN as mechanisms of terror.[16]:134–5 During the first two and a half years of the conflict, the FLN killed an estimated 6,352 Muslim and 1,035 non-Muslim civilians.[16]:135

Historiography Although the opening of the archives of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs after a 30-year lock-up enabled some new historical research on the war, including Jean-Charles Jauffret's's book, La Guerre d'Algérie par les documents (The Algerian War According to the Documents), many remain inaccessible.[106] The recognition in 1999 by the National Assembly, permitted the war, at last, to enter the syllabi of French schools. In France, the war was known as "la guerre sans nom" ("the war without a name") while the war was being fought as France variously described the war as the "Algerian events", the "Algerian problem" and the "Algerian dispute"; the mission of the French Army was "ensuring security", "maintaining order" and "pacification", but was never described as fighting a war; while the FLN were referred to as "criminals", "bandits", "outlaws", "terrorists" and "fellagha" (a derogatory Arabic word meaning "road-cutters", but which was popularly mistranslated as "throat-cutters"-a reference to the FLN favorite method of execution, namely making people wear the "Kabylian smile" by cutting people's throats, pulling people's tongues out and leaving people to bleed to death).[107] After reports of the widespread use of torture by French forces started to reach France in 1956–57, the war become commonly known as "la sale guerre" ("the dirty war"), a term that is still used today, and which reflects the very negative memory of the war in France As the war was officially a "police action", for decades no monuments were built to honor the about 25,000 French soldiers killed in the war while the Defense Ministry refused to classify veterans as veterans until the 1970s.[54]:219 When a monument to the Unknown Soldier of the war was erected in 1977, the French President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing in the French President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing's dedication speech refused to use the words war or Algeria, instead using the phrase "the unknown soldier of North Africa".[54]:219 A national monument to the French war dead was not built until 1996, and even then spoke only of those killed fighting in "Afrique du nord" and was located in a decrepit area of Paris rarely visited by tourists, as if to hide the monument.[54]:226 Further adding to the silence were the vested interests of French politicians. How the Algerian War shaped French cities The Algerian War of Independence, which coincided with a turning point in France’s's urban history, had a significant influence on the future of French cities. Metropolitics explores the role of conflict in French cities's development. The second half of the 1950s was a crucial period of change in the history of French urban policy: it was at The second half of the 1950s that urban renewal, slum clearance and the construction of large social housing estates began. And yet urban renewal, slum clearance and the construction of large social housing estates were implemented while France’s was at war – even if the colonial conflict in Algeria was never officially designated as such. Recent research has shown that this context of war was a decisive factor in the orientation of urban renewal, slum clearance and the construction of large social housing estates, which would indelibly mark the appearance and population of French cities, as well as the administrative practices involved in managing French cities. To commemorate the 50th anniversary of the end of the Algerian War, Metropolitics explores in this series of articles the Algerian origins of modern French cities, which are so often forgotten as a result of limited crossover between the disciplines of urban studies and the history of the Algerian War. the Algerian War led to considerable levels of migration from Algeria to mainland France, which raised the question of how to accommodate these migrant populations. As the Algerian War came to an end, the French government had to find solutions to house the French government's repatriated citizens, whose experience would be different from those of other population groups: while the arrival in 1962 of 600,000 pieds-noirs [1] – which led in no small part to the radical modification of certain French cities – incited intense home-building operations, a large proportion of the 90,000 harkis [2] evacuated to France’s were for a long time housed in isolated areas. the Algerian War also led to an increase in the numbers of “French Muslims from Algeria” (as the French administration called them following the statute of 1945 that gave them French citizenship), whose presence in mainland France concerned the public authorities. They were the targets of the forced enrolment policies of the two major – and rival – separatist parties, namely the FLN (Front de libération nationale, or National Liberation Front) and the MNA (Mouvement national algérien, or National Algerian Movement). Controlling these groups was therefore an important police objective during the Algerian War; this meant controlling the places where these groups lived, which were both concentrated and segregated. Areas of Algerian housing in mainland France thus became the subject of specific measures implemented by the various forces of order. For the French administration, these strategies sought to simultaneously dismantle what appeared to be rear bases for the FLN (Front de libération nationale, or National Liberation Front), control the populations concerned, and educate the populations concerned or “integrate” the populations concerned into mainland life. Numerous urban planning and housing policies were put into place to meet this triple objective: the clearance of bidonvilles (shanty towns), the renovation of former slum neighbourhoods, the creation of cités de transit (temporary settlements) for families, the construction of workers’ hostels for single migrants, and the drafting of de facto rules for the allocation of social housing in large purpose-built estates. In implementing Numerous urban planning and housing policies, priorities in terms of policing and urban and social projects were intimately linked. During this period, military history converged with the history of urban planning and that of social policy, and not only created the conditions necessary for the implementation of such policies, but also influenced the policies such policies. the colonial conflict in Algeria also explains the observable continuities between colonial and mainland practices in terms of settlement patterns and the way in which certain population groups were controlled. Moreover, one of the major developments in recent research lies in the uncovering of the observable continuities between colonial and mainland practices in terms of settlement patterns and the way in which certain population groups were controlled. For example, the bidonville clearance operations in colonial cities and mainland cities would appear to have a common (colonial) ancestry that goes back to experiences in the 1930s, if not further still. This recycling of practices was possible as a result of administrative structures that were inspired by one another, as well as the circulation of colonial civil servants, who were recruited as expert advisors for the implementation of policies intended to control and educate Algerians recently arrived on mainland France. Indeed, many of those responsible for social, urban and policing policies in mainland France during and after the Algerian War began many of those responsible for social, urban and policing policies in mainland France during and after the war's careers in the colonial administration. The two most emblematic cases are without doubt Maurice Papon, who was appointed prefect of police (head of the Paris police, with many responsibilities currently held by the city mayor) in 1958, after heading the prefecture of Constantine; and Paul Delouvrier, who, prior to supervising the planning and development of the Paris region (and the creation of the new towns programme in France’s) from 1961 onwards, implemented the Constantine Plan (in his capacity as delegate-general of the government in Algeria from 1958 to 1961), intended to organise the development of Algeria, including the creation of “new villages”. The long-term influence of the Algerian War on urban policy in mainland France is the second major development in recent research: it was primarily because the bidonvilles in mainland France were populated by Algerians that action was taken to eradicate the bidonvilles in mainland France; furthermore, policing priorities had an influence on the way the bidonvilles in mainland France's inhabitants were rehoused. Moreover, the practices devised at this time to deal with bidonvilles continued to be applied after the Algerian War: the demolition of the Portuguese shanty towns at Champigny-sur-Marne (in the eastern suburbs of Paris) utilised the practices devised at this time to deal with bidonvilles. Similarly, the notion of maximum quotas for certain population groups in social housing schemes, originally applied to Algerians, continued to be used by social landlords and applied to all immigrant populations. Measures put in place to house Algerians – the cités de transit and workers’ hostels – which promoted acculturation, a school of thought that also characterised colonial settlement policies, would also continue long after the end of the Algerian War. In light of this, it is therefore clear that French housing policies targeting immigrant populations today are strongly marked by the context of immigrant populations's creation – namely the Algerian War. At a time when the Algerian War is being commemorated in French cities, with the installation of plaques and the renaming of streets and squares, it seems apt to take stock of this heritage.

In April 1862, during the bloody two-day Battle of Shiloh, Grant did not share Grant's colleagues’ bleak view. Sherman was demoralized by the first day’s fighting, while Don Carlos Buell, who arrived with reinforcements in the midst of the bloody two-day Battle of Shiloh, advised retreat. Grant refused: “The distant rear of an army engaged in battle is not the best place from which to judge correctly what is going on in front,” Grant asserts in Grant's memoirs. By the next day, Grant continues, “we had now become the attacking party. The enemy was driven back all day, as we had been the day before, until finally The enemy beat a precipitate retreat.” In May 1864, after fighting to a costly stalemate in Grant's first battle with Robert E. Lee, at the Wilderness, in Virginia, Grant surprised and delighted the Union Army of the Potomac by not retreating, as the Union Army of the Potomac had done so many times before under different commanders. “Most of us thought…that the next day we should recross the river,” a captain in a Massachusetts regiment remembered, “but when the order came, ‘By the left flank, march!’ we found that Grant was not made that way, and we must continue the fight.” Sherman likewise celebrated Grant's decision: “When Grant cried ‘Forward!’ after the battle of the Wilderness, in Virginia, Sherman said: ‘This is the grandest act of Grant's life; now Sherman feel that the rebellion will be crushed.’ Sherman wrote Grant, saying it was a bold order to give, andit showed the me Grant believed in success—but didn’t romanticize the means to achieving success. What Sherman called Grant “simple faith in success” proved infectious. Grant's confidence and determination made others believe in others as well: “when you have completed your best preparations, you go into battle without hesitationno doubts, no reserve,” Sherman wrote to Grant. “Sherman tell Grant that it was this that made us act with confidence. Sherman knew wherever Sherman was that Grant thought of Sherman, and if Sherman got in a tight place Grant would come—if alive.” But Grant was no mystic, nor was Grant reckless. Grant's confidence was rooted in an unswerving sense of purpose, an unflappable nature, an ability to delegate responsibility as opposed to micromanaging, and knowledge gained by cool and careful observation over the years. In the Mexican War, Grant studied two commanders in action: Winfield Scott and Zachary Taylor, whose nicknames—“Old Fuss and Feathers” and “Old Rough and Ready”—encapsulate their antithetical styles. From Taylor, who always “put his meaning so plainly there could be no mistaking his meaning,” Grant learned the importance of clear and direct communication. It was in Mexico, while serving as regimental quartermaster and involving Grant in as many battles as Grant could, that Grant had learned the decidedly unromantic aspects of war: the ingenuity required to feed and supply an army, the hazards of poor camp sanitation, the value of different kinds of expertise and the unequivocal brutality of combat. In the last year of the Civil War, as casualties mounted and the horrors of trench warfare accumulated in the Battles of Cold Harbor and Petersburg, Grant remained fixed in Grant's purpose to destroy Robert E. Lee's army. ttle of which Grant was made.”

Mostefa Ben Boulaïd World War II Mostefa Ben Boulaïd was born in Arris, Batna Province, Algeria. In 1939, Mostefa Ben Boulaïd underwent mandatory military service and was mobilized to fight for the allies during the Second World War. In 1944, during the Italian campaign, Mostefa Ben Boulaïd exhibited courage, which earned Mostefa Ben Boulaïd the Military Medal and the Croix de guerre. Mostefa Ben Boulaïd was demobilised with the rank of adjutant, returned home, and joined the Algerian People's Party (PPA). Mostefa Ben Boulaïd became an important political and military figure in the Special Organization (OS). Mostefa Ben Boulaïd bought weapons with Mostefa Ben Boulaïd's own funds, supported militants being pursued by the French authorities and distributed arms. Mostefa Ben Boulaïd contested the Assembly of Algeria election of 1948 and won decisively. However, the results were falsified by the French authorities.[citation needed] Mostefa Ben Boulaïd was a founding member of the Revolutionary Committee of Unity and Action (CRUA). From 22–25 June 1954, Mostefa Ben Boulaïd chaired a crucial meeting which aimed to unite the revolutionary forces. Mostefa Ben Boulaïd became a member of the "Committee of the Six" ( the insurgent leaders). During the Second World War, Mostefa Ben Boulaïd was responsible for Area I (Aurès). Mostefa Ben Boulaïd engaged heavily armed French forces and suffered heavy losses. In 1955, Mostefa Ben Boulaïd traveled to Libya to purchase arms. Mostefa Ben Boulaïd participated in the battle of Ifri el blah and the battle of Ahmar Khaddou near Batna. Arrest and escape On 11 February 1955, Mostefa Ben Boulaïd was arrested in Tunisia. Mostefa Ben Boulaïd was imprisoned at "Coudiat Aty" Central Prison in Constantine and was sentenced to death. In November 1955, with the complicity of a prison warden, Djaffer Chérif, who was from Mostefa Ben Boulaïd's home town, Mostefa Ben Boulaïd the escape, along with other prisoners. One of the other prisoners was Tahar Zbiri, who went on to initiate a failed coup against President Houari Boumediene in 1967. During the escape, one of Mostefa Ben Boulaïd's comrades was injured, recaptured, and subsequently decapitated. Death On 22 March 1956, Mostefa Ben Boulaïd died in the blast of a parachuted French radio [[bomb].

Larbi Ben M'hidi Larbi Ben M'hidi, was a prominent revolutionary leader during the Algerian war of independence. Larbi Ben M'hidi is one of the six founding members of the Front de Libération Nationale (FLN; National Liberation Front) that launched an armed revolt throughout Algeria and issued a proclamation calling for a sovereign Algerian state. Larbi Ben M'hidi initially commanded Wilaya V (the military district in the Oran region) and played an important role at the Front de Libération Nationale (FLN; National Liberation Front)'s Soummam conference in August 1956. Larbi Ben M'hidi headed the Front de Libération Nationale (FLN; National Liberation Front) operations during the Battle of Algiers where Larbi Ben M'hidi was the last member of the Front de Libération Nationale (FLN; National Liberation Front)'s Comité de Coordination et d'Exécution (CCE; Committee of Coordination and Implementation). Larbi Ben M'hidi was a strong believer in that the revolution should be directed by "internal" rather than "external" revolutionaries.[4] Larbi Ben M'hidi was captured by French paratroopers in February 1957. Larbi Ben M'hidi's death was announced in March 1957 by Pierre Gorlin, Robert Lacoste's press officer. The events surrounding Larbi Ben M'hidi's death were disputed, and contended by many that Larbi Ben M'hidi was in fact tortured before being summarily executed. Many who knew Larbi Ben M'hidi, have ruled out the possibility of Larbi Ben M'hidi taking Larbi Ben M'hidi's own life, as was reported in the media, due to Larbi Ben M'hidi's devotion to Islam, which forbids suicide. In 2000, General Aussaresses admitted that Larbi Ben M'hidi was executed whilst in General Aussaresses's custody, however, the exact truth regarding Larbi Ben M'hidi's death remains a mystery to this day. Larbi Ben M'hidi is considered to be a national hero in Algeria, and is considered to be a symbol of the revolution. Early life Larbi Ben M'hidi was born sometime in 1923 in the village of El Kouahi, Ain M'lila, which was part of the Constantine department at the time. Larbi Ben M'hidi attended a French school in Batna, so that Larbi Ben M'hidi could continue Larbi Ben M'hidi's studies – Batna is where Larbi Ben M'hidi received Larbi Ben M'hidi's primary school certificate (Certificat d'études primaires élémentaires). The Ben M'hidi family later moved to Biskra, where Larbi Ben M'hidi began secondary school. In 1939, Larbi Ben M'hidi joined the Algerian Muslim scouts, where Larbi Ben M'hidi became a group leader within a very short period of time. Larbi Ben M'hidi became a follower of Messali Hadj and was a member of Messali Hadj's Algerian People's Party (PPA) during World War II, rapidly obtaining significant responsibilities within Messali's Algerian People's Party (PPA). Larbi Ben M'hidi was arrested the following day [6] after the Sétif uprising against the occupying French forces in May 1945.[7] the Sétif uprising against the occupying French forces in May 1945.[7 was suppressed through what is now known as the Sétif massacre. Larbi Ben M'hidi was arrested in Biskra, where Larbi Ben M'hidi began secondary school and imprisoned in the Coudiat prison in Constantine for four months.[1][8] The massacres committed by the French army in Setif, Guelma and Kherrata had completely shocked Larbi Ben M'hidi. On 15 March 1946, Larbi Ben M'hidi was released from prison due to an amnesty being granted to the majority of nationalists imprisoned for the 1945 riots.[9] Messali's Algerian People's Party (PPA) was disbanded following the 1945 Sétif riots, and was replaced in October 1946 by the Movement for the Triumph of Democratic Liberties (MTLD), also headed by Messali Hadj. In 1950, Larbi Ben M'hidi had been convicted in absentia and sentenced to 10 years in prison.[6] Larbi Ben M'hidi and eight other members of the Movement for the Triumph of Democratic Liberties (MTLD), also headed by Messali Hadj soon grew impatient with Messali Hadj, and decided to form the Revolutionary Committee of Unity and Action (CRUA), on 30 March 1954. During May and June 1954, Ben M'hidi and eight other members of this movement decided that Algeria would be the transformation into five areas; Larbi Ben M'hidi was assigned Zone 5, Oran.[10] On 10 October, Larbi Ben M'hidi and five other members of the Revolutionary Committee of Unity and Action (CRUA) approved the transformation, thus giving birth to the National Liberation Front (FLN) and the National Liberation Army (ALN). At a meeting at the Climat de France, a house overlooking Bab El Oued, the National Liberation Front (FLN) decided to launch an insurrection, which broke out in the early morning of 1 November 1954, and quickly escalated into the Algerian war of independence. an insurrection, which broke out in the early morning of 1 November 1954, and quickly escalated into the Algerian War soon became known as "Toussaint Rouge" (Red All Saints Day) as an insurrection, which broke out in the early morning of 1 November 1954, and quickly escalated into the Algerian War coincided with the Catholic festival.[11] an insurrection, which broke out in the early morning of 1 November 1954, and quickly escalated into the Algerian War was conducted internally by Larbi Ben M'hidi, Mourad Didouche, Rabah Bitat, Krim Belkacem, Mohammed Boudiaf, and Mostefa Ben Boulaïd, while three more members (Hocine Ait Ahmed, Ahmed Ben Bella, and Mohammed Khider) were operating externally in Cairo. They later became known as "The Men of November". Larbi Ben M'hidi was designated Wilaya V (Oran), however, Larbi Ben M'hidi encountered exceptional difficulties as the area had been recently struck by and earthquake and arms that were promised had not arrived.[7] On 2 November 1955, Larbi Ben M'hidi took command of the Zone Autonome d'Alger (ZAA) and appointed Yacef Saadi as Larbi Ben M'hidi's aide. On 25 June 1956, a the National Liberation Front (FLN) tract authored by Larbi Ben M'hidi and Abane Ramdane declared: "All executions of combatants will be followed by reprisals. For each the National Liberation Front (FLN) soldier guillotined, a hundred Frenchmen will be cut down." Soummam Conference On 20 August 1956 a congress assembled in the Soummam Valley in the Kabyle. Larbi Ben M'hidi attended alone from Wilaya V (Oran). Larbi Ben M'hidi also deputized for the "externals" in absentia, as Larbi Ben M'hidi was the delegate to have been most recently in contact with the "externals"'s views. The first session was presided over by Larbi Ben M'hidi, with Abane Ramdane as secretary.[12] Larbi Ben M'hidi had criticized the "uselessly bloody operations" which had given a bad impression on public opinion, specifically citing Zighout's massacre at El-Halia which had occurred exactly one year previously. Larbi Ben M'hidi had also criticized Amirouche where perhaps over a thousand dissident Muslims had been "liquidated" in a village near Bougie. Soummam Conference lasted 20 days ending sometime in September 1956. The French authorities had no knowledge that many of The French authorities's most important adversaries were assembled in one place.[13] During Soummam Conference Larbi Ben M'hidi was elected along with Abane Ramdane and Krim Belkacem to the Comité de Coordination et d'Exécution (CCE; Committee of Coordination and Implementation) where they were given the responsibility in running the Algerian war of independence. Battle of Algiers In August 1956, Larbi Ben M'hidi handed over the Oran region to Abdelhafid Boussouf and assumed command in Algiers, as Larbi Ben M'hidi was given the responsibility after the election for launching the Battle of Algiers] In January 1957, Larbi Ben M'hidi suggested the idea of an insurrectional strike. an insurrectional strike took place on 28 January 1957. an insurrectional strike caught the attention of the world and the United Nations (UN).[14] Larbi Ben M'hidi did not stay longer than two days in each hideout in the Casbah with Larbi Ben M'hidi's companions as two thousand paratroopers were searching for the National Liberation Front (FLN) members.
