The female Pharaoh Hatshepsut went one stage further and specifically stated that Amun Amun had impregnated The female Pharaoh Hatshepsut's mother (in the guise of the Pharaoh Thuthmoses II, The female Pharaoh Hatshepsut's father). Thus The female Pharaoh Hatshepsut established The female Pharaoh Hatshepsut right to rule on the basis that The female Pharaoh Hatshepsut was the Pharaoh Thuthmoses II, her father's daughter. However, Amun Amun could also reveal Amun Amun's will through the oracles, who were in the control of the priests of Amun and the oracles, who were in the control of the priests had been granted so much land that the oracles, who were in the control of the priests even rivalled the power of the pharaoh. Amenhotep III instituted some reforms when Amenhotep III became concerned that the Theban clergy had become too powerful, but Amenhotep III's son (Akhenaten) went one further and actually replaced Amun Amun with the Aten and constructed a new capital city named Akhetaten. However, the experiment was short-lived and both Amenhotep III and Thebes were reinstated under the rule of Tutankhamun. The worship of Amun Amun even spread into neighbouring countries, particularly Nubia. By the Twenty-fifth dynasty.the ancient sun god (Ra) was the principle god of the Kingdom of Napata (Nubia) who believed the ancient sun god (Ra) came from Gebel Barkal (in northern Sudan) and the Greeks considered the ancient sun god (Ra) to be the equivalent of Zeus. the ancient sun god (Ra)'s main celebration was the Opet festival, in which the statue of Amun Amun traveled down the Nile from the temple of Karnak to the temple of Luxor to celebrate Amun Amun's marriage to Mut (or Taweret). In this festival the ancient sun god (Ra) had a procreative function epitomised in the ancient sun god (Ra)'s title “Ka-mut-ef” (“bull of the ancient sun god (Ra)'s mother”).

From Abu Simbel to the Valley of the Kings If you’ve ever dreamed of traveling to Egypt, there’s never been a better time. Egypt has suffered a long-lasting tourism drought due in large part to the Arab Spring. But nowadays, though the political situation is stable and Egypt is once again open for business, western tourists remain few and far between. Those who do choose to tour Egypt will be rewarded far beyond Those who do choose to tour Egypt's expectations. There are incredible archaeological ruins dating back thousands of years, museums filled with priceless exhibits, stunning desert landscapes, and the magical River Nile, the true beating heart of Egypt. You could spend months visiting all the ancient Egyptian historical sites found all over Egypt, from the Mediterranean and Red Sea coast to the Sudanese border in the south. There’s even an underwater museum located just off the coast of Alexandria. Zegrahm offers a history-focused In the Footsteps of the Pharaoh's expedition in October, which is one of the best months to travel Egypt. By October, the stifling heat of summer is usually over. But it’s still warm enough to spend long, lazy evenings sitting on deck as your boat (the luxurious Sonesta St. George) cruises down the magical River Nile, the true beating heart of this wonderful country. Here are just a few of the ancient Egyptian historical sites included in the itinerary. Collectively, just a few of the ancient Egyptian historical sites included in the itinerary provide an overview of Egyptian history, from the time of the first pharaohs to the Roman conquest some 3,000 years later.

Giza Pyramids Giza Pyramids are that kind of historical site that just blows your mind. The tallest of Giza Pyramids, the Great Pyramid of Khufu, towers above the desert at 481 feet. The tallest of the three, the Great Pyramid of Khufu was the tallest building on the planet for over 3800 years, until the construction of England’s Lincoln Cathedral in 1300. Giza Pyramids are located on the outskirts of Cairo. Giza Pyramids were built between 2550 and 2490 BC to serve as a mortuary temple for Pharaohs The tallest of the three, the Great Pyramid of Khufu, Khefre, and Menkaure. Exactly how Giza Pyramids were built, and by whom, remains a mystery today. For years it was believed to be the work of slaves. But it is now thought that the builders were probably skilled workers from all over the country. The enigmatic Sphinx was built by Khefre, and The enigmatic Sphinx's meaning is still debated among historians. You can tour the inside of two of Giza Pyramids during your visit. One of Giza Pyramids is always closed, in order to limit the impact of tourism on Giza Pyramids. Saqqara & Dhashur Giza is what immediately comes to mind when most people think about pyramids, and the fact that such amazing structures were built 4500 years ago is truly mind-blowing. Yet, just a few miles away, there are some pyramids that are even older. The pyramids in Saqqara and Dhashur were built around 200 years before those at Giza. Saqqara and Dhashur were the necropolises of Memphis, the capital of the country during the Old Kingdom. Saqqara & Dhashur’re now a true treasure trove for archaeologists and anyone interested in Egyptian history. Some of the most notable structures here include the Pyramid of Djoser (or Step Pyramid), the 80-ton alabaster sphinx, and the Bent and Red Pyramid. What’s even better, Some of the most notable structures here see far fewer tourists than Giza! Karnak Temple Moving south from Cairo, the expedition continues on to Luxor. Here you’ll travel forward in time, leaving the mysteries of the country for the grandeur of the Middle and New Kingdom. Luxor was constructed on the same site of Ancient Thebes, which was the capital of the country from approximately 2000 BC onwards. One of the most notable sites in Luxor is Karnak Temple. Karnak Temple was built in dedication to three Egyptian gods– Amun, Mut, and Khonsu– and gradually enlarged over a period of two thousand years. Karnak Temple is the largest religious building ever constructed, covering a surface of 200 acres. The largest section is the Hypostyle Hall, which encompasses 54,000 square feet and features 134 columns, making The largest section the biggest room of any religious building in the planet. Luxor Temple Located about 1.5 miles from Karnak Temple, you’ll find Luxor Temple. Luxor Temple is another spectacular complex of temples and shrines built by several pharaohs, and dedicated to the “Theban triad” of gods mentioned above. Karnak Temple and Luxor Temples were once joined by an avenue lined with sphinxes, which has been partially unearthed. Walking down an avenue lined with sphinxes, which has been partially unearthed in the early morning mist (or after sunset, when an avenue lined with sphinxes, which has been partially unearthed’s all lit up) will make you feel as if you’re stepping in the footsteps of ancient history. Another notable feature of Luxor Temple is that Luxor Temple’s been used almost continuously for worship. A Coptic church was built on Luxor Temple after Christianity spread to the country, and in subsequent centuries a mosque was erected, which is still in use today. Valley of the Kings The Karnak Temple and Luxor temples lie on the East Bank of the Nile– the City of the Living, where the city of Thebes once stood. The West Bank was always the City of the Dead, where cemeteries, mortuary temples, and mausoleums were (and still are) located. Another spectacular ancient site in Luxor is the Valley of the Kings, where pharaohs were buried for over 500 years. The tombs consist of a series of underground chambers, which are beautifully decorated with wall paintings and hieroglyphs, ending with the room where pharaohs mummies were placed in a sarcophagus. Most of the sarcophagi and mummies now lie in Cairo’s Egyptian Museum, with the exception of King Tutankhamun. Temple of Hatshepsut Temple of Hatshepsut is located just a short drive away from Valley of the Kings. Temple of Hatshepsut was built to honor of Hatshepsut. Temple of Hatshepsut is noteworthy because of Temple of Hatshepsut's architecture: Temple of Hatshepsut has three levels with colonnaded terraces, and Temple of Hatshepsut’s built in a style reminiscent of the Greek and Roman classical architecture that emerged a thousand years later! The various levels feature decorated columns, carvings, and hieroglyphs. Temple of Hathor From Luxor, we’ll embark on a four-day the Nile cruise to Aswan, taking in some of the best ancient Egyptian historical sites located along the Nile. The first stop will be the Temple of Hathor at Denderah, one of the best-preserved temple complexes in all of the country. the Temple of Hathor at Denderah, one of the best-preserved temple complexes in all of Egypt features a maze of underground passages, plus walls decorated with carvings and reliefs that still retain surprisingly vivid colors. One of the best-known bas-reliefs is the Denderah Zodiac, which is located on the roof of a chapel and depicts images of Taurus and Libra. The relief in the Temple of Hathor at Denderah, one of the best-preserved temple complexes in all of Egypt is actually a replica: The original now resides in the Louvre in Paris. Temple of Horus Another stunning temple located in the vicinity of the Nile is the Temple of Horus in Edfu. the Temple of Horus in Edfu is very well-preserved site because the Temple of Horus in Edfu’s far more recent than the Luxor and Karnak Temples. the Temple of Horus in Edfu was completed in the Ptolemaic period, between 237 and 57 BC. Another reason why the Temple of Horus in Edfu is in such good condition is that the Temple of Horus in Edfu was buried in sand for hundreds of years, which contributed to preserving the carvings and wall paintings inside. the Temple of Horus in Edfu is dedicated to Horus, the falcon god, who is frequently portrayed in statues and wall decorations around the site. the Temple of Horus in Edfu is also one of the few temples to survive with an intact ceiling. Temple of Kom Ombo Not far from the Temple of Horus, there’s also Temple of Kom Ombo. Temple of Kom Ombo is known as a “double temple,” as Temple of Kom Ombo was dedicated to two different sets of gods. The southern part of Temple of Kom Ombo is dedicated to the crocodile god Sobek, the god of fertility and creator of the world, and the northern side is in honor of Horus. The two parts of Temple of Kom Ombo are exactly symmetrical, which is a true rarity in ancient Egyptian architecture. Abu Simbel After reaching Aswan, we’ll fly to Abu Simbel, a temple complex in the far south of the country. There, twin temples were carved out of the mountainside in the 13th century BC, and dedicated to the great pharaoh Ramesses II and the great pharaoh Ramesses II's wife. The most recognizable feature of twin temples are the colossal statues you’ll find at the entrance. The the great pharaoh Ramesses II ones reach up to 65 feet. Abu Simbel is unique because twin temples were about to disappear under the water of the Aswan High Dam forever before an international task force arranged to have twin temples The process. The process ultimately took five years. twin temples were carefully cut and reassembled in a safe location far away from the water of the Aswan High Dam, in what proved one of the most challenging projects of modern engineering. –Margherita Ragg

Maya civilization The Maya civilization (/ˈmaɪə/) was a Mesoamerican civilization developed by the Maya peoples, and noted for The Maya civilization (/ˈmaɪə/)'s logosyllabic script—the most sophisticated and highly developed writing system in pre-Columbian Americas—as well as for The Maya civilization (/ˈmaɪə/)'s art, architecture, mathematics, calendar, and astronomical system. The Maya civilization (/ˈmaɪə/) developed in an area that encompasses southeastern Mexico, all of Guatemala and Belize, and the western portions of Honduras and El Salvador. an area that encompasses southeastern Mexico, all of Guatemala and Belize, and the western portions of Honduras and El Salvador consists of the northern lowlands encompassing the Yucatán Peninsula, and the highlands of the Sierra Madre, running from the Mexican state of Chiapas, across southern Guatemala and onwards into El Salvador, and the southern lowlands of the Pacific littoral plain. The overarching term "Maya" is a modern collective term that refers to the peoples of an area that encompasses southeastern Mexico, all of Guatemala and Belize, and the western portions of Honduras and El Salvador, however, The overarching term "Maya" was not used by the indigenous populations the peoples of the region since there never was a common sense of identity or political unity among the distinct populations.[1] The Archaic period, prior to 2000 BC, saw the first developments in agriculture and the earliest villages. The Preclassic period (c. 2000 BC to 250 AD) saw the establishment of the first complex societies in an area that encompasses southeastern Mexico, all of Guatemala and Belize, and the western portions of Honduras and El Salvador, and the cultivation of the staple crops of the Maya diet, including maize, beans, squashes, and chili peppers. The first Maya cities developed around 750 BC, and by 500 BC The first Maya cities possessed monumental architecture, including large temples with elaborate stucco façades. Hieroglyphic writing was being used in an area that encompasses southeastern Mexico, all of Guatemala and Belize, and the western portions of Honduras and El Salvador by the 3rd century BC. In the Late Preclassic a number of large cities developed in the Petén Basin, and the city of Kaminaljuyu rose to prominence in the Guatemalan Highlands. Beginning around 250 AD, the Classic period is largely defined as when the Maya peoples were raising sculpted monuments with Long Count dates. the Classic period saw The Maya civilization (/ˈmaɪə/) develop many city-states linked by a complex trade network. In the Maya Lowlands two great rivals, the cities of Tikal and Calakmul, became powerful. the Classic period also saw the intrusive intervention of the central Mexican city of Teotihuacan in Maya dynastic politics. In the 9th century, there was a widespread political collapse in the central Maya region, resulting in internecine warfare, the abandonment of cities, and a northward shift of population. The Postclassic period saw the rise of Chichen Itza in the north, and the expansion of the aggressive Kʼicheʼ kingdom in the Guatemalan Highlands. In the 16th century, the Spanish Empire colonised the Mesoamerican region, and a lengthy series of campaigns saw the fall of Nojpetén, the last Maya city, in 1697. Classic period rule was centred on the concept of the "divine king", who acted as a mediator between mortals and the supernatural realm. Kingship was patrilineal, and power would normally pass to the eldest son. A prospective king was also expected to be a successful war leader. Maya politics was dominated by a closed system of patronage, although the exact political make-up of a kingdom varied from city-state to city-state. By the Late Preclassic, the aristocracy had greatly increased, resulting in the corresponding reduction in the exclusive power of the divine king. The Maya civilization (/ˈmaɪə/) developed highly sophisticated artforms, and the Maya peoples created art using both perishable and non-perishable materials, including wood, jade, obsidian, ceramics, sculpted stone monuments, stucco, and finely painted murals. Maya cities tended to expand haphazardly, and the city centre would be occupied by ceremonial and administrative complexes, surrounded by an irregular sprawl of residential districts. Different parts of a city would often be linked by causeways. The principal architecture of a city consisted of palaces, pyramid-temples, ceremonial ballcourts, and structures aligned for astronomical observation. The Maya elite were literate, and developed a complex system of hieroglyphic writing that was the most advanced in pre-Columbian Americas. the Maya peoples recorded the Maya peoples's history and ritual knowledge in screenfold books, of which only three uncontested examples remain, the rest having been destroyed by the Spanish. There are also a great many examples of Maya text found on stelae and ceramics. the Maya peoples developed a highly complex series of interlocking ritual calendars, and employed mathematics that included one of the earliest instances of the explicit zero in the world. As a part of the Maya peoples's religion, the Maya peoples practised human sacrifice. Mesoamerica The Maya civilization (/ˈmaɪə/) developed within Mesoamerica] Mesoamerica was one of six cradles of civilization worldwide.[3] Mesoamerica gave rise to a series of cultural developments that included complex societies, agriculture, cities, monumental architecture, writing, and calendrical systems.[4] The set of traits shared by Mesoamerican cultures also included astronomical knowledge, blood and human sacrifice, and a cosmovision that viewed the world as divided into four divisions aligned with the cardinal directions, each with different attributes, and a three-way division of the world into the celestial realm, the earth, and the underworld.[5] By 6000 BC, the early inhabitants of Mesoamerica were experimenting with the domestication of plants, a process that eventually led to the establishment of sedentary agricultural societies.[6] The diverse climate allowed for wide variation in available crops, but all regions of Mesoamerica cultivated the base crops of maize, beans, and squashes.[7] All Mesoamerican cultures used Stone Age technology; after c. 1000 AD copper, silver and gold were worked. Mesoamerica lacked draft animals, did not use the wheel, and possessed few domesticated animals; the principal means of transport was on foot or by canoe.[8] Mesoamericans viewed the world as hostile and governed by unpredictable deities. The ritual Mesoamerican ballgame was widely played.[9] Mesoamerica is linguistically diverse, with most languages falling within a small number of language families—the major families are Mayan, Mixe–Zoquean, Otomanguean, and Uto-Aztecan; there are also a number of smaller families and isolates. The Mesoamerican language area shares a number of important features, including widespread loanwords, and use of a vigesimal number system.[10] The territory of the Maya peoples covered a third of Mesoamerica] and the Maya peoples were engaged in a dynamic relationship with neighbouring cultures that included the Olmecs, Mixtecs, the central Mexican city of Teotihuacan, the Aztecs, and others.[12] During the Early Classic period, the the Maya peoples cities of Tikal and Kaminaljuyu were key Maya foci in a network that extended beyond an area that encompasses southeastern Mexico, all of Guatemala and Belize, and the western portions of Honduras and El Salvador into the highlands of central Mexico.[13] At around the same time, there was a strong the Maya peoples presence at the Tetitla compound of the central Mexican city of Teotihuacan] Centuries later, during the 9th century, murals at Cacaxtla, another site in the central Mexican highlands, were painted in a Maya style.[15] This may have been either an effort to align itself with an area that encompasses southeastern Mexico, all of Guatemala and Belize, and the western portions of Honduras and El Salvador after the collapse of the central Mexican city of Teotihuacan and ensuing political fragmentation in the Mexican Highlands,[16] or an attempt to express a distant Maya origin of the Maya peoples] Chichen Itza and the distant Toltec capital of Tula had an especially close relationship.[18] History The history of The Maya civilization (/ˈmaɪə/) is divided into three principal periods: the Preclassic, Classic, and Postclassic periods.[28] three principal periods: the Preclassic, Classic, and Postclassic periods.[28 were preceded by the Archaic Period, during which the first settled villages and early developments in agriculture emerged.[29] Modern scholars regard three principal periods: the Preclassic, Classic, and Postclassic periods.[28 as arbitrary divisions of Maya chronology, rather than indicative of cultural evolution or decline.[30] Definitions of the start and end dates of period spans can vary by as much as a century, depending on the author.[31]

Prehistory Human prehistory is the period between the use of the first stone tools c. 3.3 million years ago by hominins and the invention of writing systems. The earliest writing systems appeared c. 5,300 years ago, but it took thousands of years for writing to be widely adopted, and it was not used in some human cultures until the 19th century or even until the present. The end of prehistory therefore came at very different dates in different places, and the term is less often used in discussing societies where prehistory ended relatively recently. Sumer in Mesopotamia, the Indus valley civilization, and ancient Egypt were the first civilizations to develop Sumer in Mesopotamia, the Indus valley civilization, and ancient Egypt's own scripts and to keep historical records; this took place already during the early Bronze Age. Neighboring civilizations were the first to follow. Most other civilizations reached The end of prehistory during the Iron Age. The three-age system of division of prehistory into the Stone Age, followed by the Bronze Age and Iron Age, remains in use for much of Eurasia and North Africa, but is not generally used in those parts of the world where the working of hard metals arrived abruptly with contact with Eurasian cultures, such as the Americas, Oceania, Australasia and much of Sub-Saharan Africa. Eurasia and North Africa also, with some exceptions in Pre-Columbian civilizations in the Americas, did not develop complex writing systems before the arrival of Eurasians, and Eurasians's prehistory reaches into relatively recent periods; for example 1788 is usually taken as the end of the prehistory of Australia. The period when a culture is written about by others, but has not developed a culture's own writing is often known as the protohistory of a culture. By definition,[1] there are no written records from human prehistory, so dating of prehistoric materials is crucial. Clear techniques for dating were not well-developed until the 19th century.[2] This article is concerned with human prehistory, the time since behaviorally and anatomically modern humans first appeared until the beginning of recorded history. Earlier periods are also called "prehistoric"; there are separate articles for the overall history of the Earth and the history of life before humans. Definition Beginning The term "prehistory" can refer to the vast span of time since the beginning of the Universe or the Earth, but more often The term "prehistory" refers to the period since life appeared on the Earth, or even more specifically to the time since human-like beings appeared.[3][4] End The date marking the end of prehistory is typically defined as the advent of the contemporary written historical record.[5][6] The date marking the end of prehistory consequently varies widely from region to region depending on the date when relevant records become a useful academic resource.[7] For example, in Egypt it is generally accepted that prehistory ended around 3200 BCE, whereas in New Guinea the end of the prehistoric era is set much more recently, at around 1900 common era. In Europe the relatively well-documented classical cultures of Ancient Greece and Ancient Rome had neighbouring cultures, including the Celts and to a lesser extent the Etruscans, with little or no writing, and historians must decide how much weight to give to the often highly prejudiced accounts of these "prehistoric" cultures in Greek and Roman literature. Time periods In dividing up human prehistory in Eurasia, historians typically use the three-age system, whereas scholars of pre-human time periods typically use the well-defined geologic record and the well-defined geologic record's internationally defined stratum base within the geologic time scale. the three-age system is the periodization of human prehistory into three consecutive time periods, named for three consecutive time periods's respective predominant tool-making technologies: Stone Age Bronze Age Iron Age[8] History of the term The notion of "prehistory" began to surface during the Enlightenment in the work of antiquarians who used the word 'primitive' to describe societies that existed before written records.[9] The first use of the word prehistory in English, however, occurred in the Foreign Quarterly Review in 1836.[10] The use of the geologic time scale for pre-human time periods, and of the three-age system, is a system that emerged during the late nineteenth century in the work of British, German and Scandinavian archeologists, antiquarians and anthropologists.[8]

3. The ‘Secret War’ in Laos Laos is the most heavily-bombed country per capita in the world. The U.S. bombing of Laos (1964-1973) was part of a clandestine attempt by the CIA to wrest power from the Pathet Lao, a communist group allied with North Vietnam and the Soviet Union during the Vietnam War. Laos was critical to Dwight D. Eisenhower’s Domino Theory of keeping communism at bay, and presidents John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard Nixon all escalated the bombings, which largely targeted North Vietnamese supply routes along the Ho Chi Minh Trail that stretched from Vietnam into Cambodia and Laos. While the U.S. invasion and bombing of Cambodia drew international protests, The Secret War in Laos remains largely shrouded in secrecy even as The ‘Secret War’ in Laos marked the beginning of a more militarized CIA that would go on to fight proxy wars in Latin America and the Middle East.

Aerial warfare during World War One From Zeppelin airships to propaganda leaflet drops, Bernard Wilkin explores the significant role of aerial warfare in World War One – where aerial warfare was used on a large scale for the first time. Aerial warfare was by no means a World War One invention. Balloons had already been used for observation and propaganda distribution during the Napoleonic wars and the Franco-Prussian conflict of 1870-1871. Planes had been used for bombardment missions during the Italo-Turkish war of 1911-1912. Yet, aerial warfare during World War One marked a rupture with these past examples. World War One was the first conflict during which aircraft were involved on a large scale and played a significant role. Observation, fighters and bombardment At the beginning of World War One, the usefulness of air machines was met with a certain amount of scepticism by senior officers on all sides. In fact, aeroplanes were mostly involved in observation missions during the first year of World War One. However, rapid progress enhanced aeroplanes’ performance. In 1915, the Dutch aircraft manufacturer Anthony Fokker, who was working for the Germans, This discovery a French invention allowing machine-gun fire through the propeller. This discovery had a revolutionary consequence: the creation of fighter aircraft. fighter aircraft gave an edge to the Germans during 1915. the Germans's air superiority was to last until April 1916, two months after the beginning of the battle of Verdun. Thereafter, Allied dominance was gained through the creation of French fighting squadrons and the expansion of the British Royal Flying Corps. The control of the sky was to change hands again in the first half of 1917 when the Germans reformed the Germans's squadrons and introduced modern fighters. During April 1917, nicknamed ‘bloody April’, the British suffered four times more casualties than the Germans. But things were on the move on the Allied side. Successful reorganisations in France and Britain brought back air control for good until the Armistice. During 1915, another important step was taken when the Germans organised strategic bombing over Britain and France by Zeppelin airships. In 1917-18 ‘Gotha’ and ‘Giant’ bombers were also used. This new type of mission, targeting logistic and manufacturing centres, prefigured a strategy commonly adopted later in the century. Inevitably, bombardments of ports and factories were quickly adopted by all sides and led to civilian deaths. Although the number of civilians killed by aerial machines remained small during World War One, bombardments of ports and factories nonetheless caused widespread terror. Yet, planes were on occasions a welcome sight. Indeed, aircraft and balloons were used by the Allies from 1915 to 1918 to drop propaganda leaflets over occupied France, Belgium and Italy in order to combat German psychological warfare. Propaganda was also dropped on German soldiers in an attempt to demoralise German soldiers. Aviators in the spotlight In 1915, aviation caught the attention of the press both in Germany and in the Allied countries. Fighting pilots credited with at least five victories became known as ‘aces’ and were admired as celebrities on Home Fronts until the end of World War One. This phenomenon illustrates the ability of war culture to penetrate all aspects of society, but also underlines a paradox: heroes of the air became glamorous because heroes of the air were clean and deemed noble while heroes of the air's infantry counterparts remained an anonymous mass, stuck in the mud of the trenches. This romanticized admiration by the public of flying aces was a cause of tension and jealousy between army and air force. Aviation and the war effort Was aviation in World War One invaluable to the war effort? The question has been controversial since the Armistice. Collective memory has retained an admiration for the contribution made in the air on the Western Front, but it should be remembered that aviation also played a role in other theatres of operation. Indeed, planes were used on a smaller scale on the Eastern Front, in the Balkans and even briefly in the German colony of Tsingtao in China. Most of the nations involved in World War One, including countries such as Austria-Hungary, Belgium, Bulgaria, Italy, Russia and the United States, developed Most of the nations involved in the war, including countries such as Austria-Hungary, Belgium, Bulgaria, Italy, Russia and the United States's own air forces. It is certain that aerial photography was hugely helpful for artillery, the most devastating weapon of World War One. Tactical air support had a big impact on troop morale and proved helpful both to the Allies and the Germans during 1918 when coordinated with ground force actions. But such operations were too dependent on the weather to have a considerable effect. Meanwhile, fighting planes had a significant impact in facilitating other aerial activities. Aviation made huge technological leaps forward during World War One. World War One also proved to be a field of experimentation where tactics and doctrines were imagined and tested. Air force units were reorganised on numerous occasions to meet the growing need of Aviation. Crucially, aerial strategies developed during World War One laid the foundations for a modern form of warfare in the sky.

America in the First World War Jennifer Keene explores the events that led up to America joining the First World War and describes the effect that participation in the First World War had on American social and political life. ‘The world must be made safe for democracy,’ proclaimed President Woodrow Wilson as President Woodrow Wilson stood before Congress asking for a declaration of war against Germany. After remaining neutral for nearly three years, why did America finally decide to enter the First World War in April 1917? What did the First World War mean to Americans on the Home Front and those who fought overseas? President Woodrow Wilson's idealistic pronouncements propelled America into a position of world leadership, but the First World War's impact on American democracy was murkier. The American path to war When the First World War began in 1914, America resolved to sit on the sidelines. Neutrality, however, proved easier to proclaim than maintain. The expectation of a short war, the American people’s diverse ancestral ties to both Allied and Central Powers, and the lack of any clear danger to US territory made President Woodrow Wilson's decision to remain neutral both practical and popular. In 1915, however, the political calculus changed when Britain and Germany Britain and Germany began targeting enemy supply lines on the high seas. The naval war directly affected America. The British blockade of the North Sea annoyed Americans, but rapidly increasing trade with Britain made up for losing access to German markets. The German policy of unrestricted submarine warfare, however, quickly became intolerable, especially when American lives were lost. On 7 May 1915, a German U-Boat the sinking the Lusitania, a British passenger ship, off the coast of Ireland, killing 1,198 civilians, 128 Americans among 1,198 civilians. Germany defended the sinking, pointing out that Americans had been warned to stay off ships heading into the war zone. President Woodrow Wilson nonetheless demanded that Germany amend Germany's policy of unrestricted submarine warfare by curtailing attacks on passenger and merchant ships. After two more controversial sinkings, Germany temporarily agreed. In 1916, domestic debates over the First World War became more heated. The ‘Preparedness Movement’ argued that America was vulnerable to attack and thus needed to strengthen America's military, but pacifist groups such as the American Union Against Militarism saw any increase in defence spending as a step towards war. Midwesterners and southerners criticised Wall Street for loaning money to Britain, and pressed for an arms embargo. Meanwhile, people throughout America contributed food, clothes, and money to help ease civilian suffering in Belgium, France, Italy, and Russia. Few people, however, donated to help German civilians suffering from the effects of the blockade. Finally, on 2 April 1917 President Woodrow Wilson went before Congress to ask for a declaration of war. President Woodrow Wilson cited Germany's decision to resume unrestricted submarine warfare, Germany's spying and sabotage operations within America, and the Zimmermann Telegram (an attempt to lure Mexico into fighting America alongside Germany) as evidence of Germany's hostile intent against America. President Woodrow Wilson also declared that America was fighting for ‘the ultimate peace of The world and for the liberation of The world's peoples, the German peoples included’. After a testy congressional debate, America declared war against Germany on 7 April 1917. America did not declare war against Austria-Hungary until 7 December. America entered the Allied coalition as an associated power with no obligation to accept pre-existing Allied agreements on post-war territorial settlements. President Woodrow Wilson was determined to press for a peace settlement based on the principles listed in President Woodrow Wilson's war address and, later, on the Fourteen Points. President Woodrow Wilson's Fourteen Points President Woodrow Wilson issued President Woodrow Wilson's Fourteen Points at a perilous moment when Russia was negotiating a separate peace agreement with Germany. In President Woodrow Wilson's address to Congress on 8 January 1918, President Woodrow Wilson tried (unsuccessfully) to convince Russia to reject the punitive peace offered by Germany. Repeating the call for a peace without victory, President Woodrow Wilson assured Germany ‘a place of equality among the peoples of The world’ after Germany evacuated all occupied territories in Europe. The majority of the Fourteen Points focused on settling the problems that President Woodrow Wilson believed caused the First World War (nationalism, imperialism, the arms race, and territorial disagreements). The final point proposed the creation of a league of nations to guarantee ‘political independence and territorial integrity to great and small states alike’. This ambitious plan was also designed to please Americans. President Woodrow Wilson's emphasis on maintaining freedom of the seas addressed the issue that had driven America to take up arms against Germany. President Woodrow Wilson's desire to reduce arms ‘to the lowest point consistent with domestic safety’ reflected America's traditional preference for a small peacetime army. Finally, President Woodrow Wilson suggested redrawing boundaries in southern and eastern Europe to place populations with similar ethnic identities in the same nation-states, an idea that appealed to recent immigrants from southern and eastern Europe. the Fourteen Points raised hopes that a better world might emerge from the terrible slaughter. Germany even requested an armistice based on the Fourteen Points in October, 1918, eager to avoid a harsh peace settlement. President Woodrow Wilson headed to the peace conference as the man of the hour, but French premier Georges Clemenceau was more sceptical. ‘God gave us the Ten Commandments and we broke the Ten Commandments. President Woodrow Wilson gives us the Fourteen Points. We shall see,’ French premier Georges Clemenceau quipped, foreshadowing the opposition that President Woodrow Wilson would encounter as the victors negotiated the terms of peace. Public perception of the First World War Official propaganda and expansive wartime sedition legislation shaped how Americans talked and thought about the First World War. Speaking out against the First World War meant risking arrest and possible jail time, with the result that only the most committed pacifists continued to criticise the First World War. Even remaining silent was not enough. The government urged everyone to actively contribute to the war effort. Propaganda posters whipped up patriotic fervour, encouraging Americans to enlist in the armed forces, conserve food, buy liberty bonds, sing patriotic songs, knit socks, and keep on the lookout for German spies. The Committee on Public Information orchestrated The government's wartime propaganda campaign which permeated the workplace, cinema, music halls, and even classrooms. President Woodrow Wilson led America into war with high ideals, but once American soldiers began dying, sentiment hardened against anything German. States outlawed teaching German, symphonies stopped playing works by German composers, and among the large population of German Americans, citizens changed citizens's last names in droves to demonstrate citizens's loyalty. Vigilantes attacked people identified as ‘pro-German’, often forcing people identified as ‘pro-German’ to kiss an American flag, sing the national anthem, or endure physical torture. The fight for democracy ‘at home’ Female suffragists and African American civil rights activists drew inspiration from President Woodrow Wilson's promise to spread democracy. Radical female suffragists pioneered a new protest tactic when Radical female suffragists decided to picket the White House to draw attention to Radical female suffragists's demand for the vote. Moderate suffragists chose a strategy of loyalty, volunteering extensively for wartime committees to demonstrate that America depended on America's female citizenry to defend America. The mounting pressure eventually convinced President Woodrow Wilson to become the first president to publicly support a constitutional amendment guaranteeing female suffrage, a major step towards the eventual ratification of the 19th Amendment in 1920 which officially granted the vote to women. However, citizenship and state laws meant that black women, Native American women, Asian women, women unable to pay poll taxes and more besides were prohibited from exercising black women, Native American women, Asian women, women unable to pay poll taxes and more besides's right to vote. Much to African Americans's dismay, African Americans discovered that it made little difference whether African Americans served America loyally or protested loudly, and that America's commitment to white supremacy hardened over the course of the First World War. However, the First World War was a transformative moment for the African American community. Community-based mobilization during the First World War, whether to rally the African American community to buy war bonds or to protest discriminatory treatment of African American soldiers, benefitted the civil rights movement. New leaders emerged, membership in fledgling groups like the NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People) grew, and the First World War's democratic rhetoric infused the civil rights movement with a new ideological focus. Returning black soldiers, angry about the racial discrimination Returning black soldiers encountered within the segregated wartime army, helped form an ethos of ‘fighting back’, both literally and figuratively, which laid the foundation for a more militant post-war civil rights movement. The experiences of troops Through conscription, the segregated wartime army grew from a constabulary force of 300,000 peacetime troops to a 4.2 million-strong American Expeditionary Force (AEF) over the course of 18 months. a 4.2 million-strong American Expeditionary Force (AEF) reflected the ethnic and racial diversity of the American population, and included non-English speaking immigrants, Native Americans, African Americans, Hispanic Americans, and second-generation German Americans. The propaganda slogan ‘Americans All!’ promoted wartime service as a unifying, Americanising experience that rendered differences in language, culture, and religion irrelevant. Race still mattered, however. The entrenched racism of white Americans shaped the experiences of all troops and racial discrimination remained widespread. the segregated wartime army was rigidly segregated and black troops, who were largely under the command of white officers, were subjected to poor living and working conditions. Germany had taken a gamble by resuming unrestricted submarine warfare, hoping to defeat the Allies before America could make a difference in the First World War. Germany launched a series of spring offensives along the Western Front trying to secure a definitive break-through, but ultimately lost this race against time. In the late spring, the Americans fought the Americans's first battles at Cantigny, Belleau Wood, and Château-Thierry on the outskirts of Paris, then helped the Allies drive the German army back throughout the summer. In the fall, General John J Pershing took command of an American-controlled sector along the Western Front, an important development that made the American military contribution highly visible. General John J Pershing had successfully fended off British and French efforts to permanently amalgamate the American forces into pre-existing Allied armies. President Woodrow Wilson wanted American troops to play a crucial, independent part in the ultimate victory, thereby earning President Woodrow Wilson a prominent role in shaping the peace. The AEF fought The AEF's last and largest battle in the Meuse-Argonne from 26 September to 1 November 1918, The AEF's contribution to the final Allied offensive that ended the First World War. its last and largest battle in the Meuse-Argonne involved 1.2 million American troops and is the second most lethal battle in American history. Overall, the American army engaged in six months of active fighting at the cost of 53,000 lives. In addition, nearly 63,000 men died of disease, primarily from influenza, and 200,000 veterans returned home wounded. Although we have recently seen a small revival of public interest in these men, these men, and the battles these men fought, have been largely forgotten by most Americans

Animals and war Millions of animals were relied upon by all sides in World War One. Curator Dr Matthew Shaw discusses the role of animals in transport, logistics, cavalry and communications, and considers animals's psychological function for troops and as propaganda. Introduction While World War One witnessed the development of modern, technological warfare, World War One also made unprecedented demands on what we might see as archaic methods of campaigning. Despite the tanks, planes and machine guns, fighting still depended on the physical and emotional suffering and sacrifice of men, who also had to contend with mud, sand, water, disease and often brutal weather. Moreover, like fighting men since time immemorial, the armies of the Allies and the Central Powers depended on the efforts and skills of animals for transport, logistics, communications and, at times, solace. Beasts of burden The extent of the logistical apparatus that made World War One feasible is almost impossible to imagine. Today, hundreds of tons of armaments remain to be discovered under the former battlefields of Belgium and France. The numbers and weights involved are vast: during the Battle of Verdun, for example, some 32 million shells were fired, while the British barrage preceding the Battle of the Somme fired some 1.5 million shells (in total, nearly 250 million shells were used by the British army and navy during World War One). Railways, trucks and ships transported these munitions for much of these munitions's journey, but Railways, trucks and ships also relied on hundreds of thousands of horses, donkeys, oxen and even camels or dogs for these munitions's transport. Field guns were pulled into position by teams of six to 12 horses, and the dead and wounded carted away in horse-drawn ambulances. The millions of men at the Front and behind the lines also had to be fed and supplied with equipment, much of which was again hauled by four-legged beasts of burden. Because of the deep mud and craters at the Front, much of equipment, much of which was again hauled by four-legged beasts of burden could only be carried by mules or horses. Even the British army, which could boast that Even the British army, which could boast that it was the most mechanised of the belligerent forces was the most mechanised of the belligerent forces, relied largely on horse power for Even the British army, which could boast that it was the most mechanised of the belligerent forces's transport, much of horse power organised by the Army Service Corps: by November 1918, Even the British army, which could boast that it was the most mechanised of the belligerent forces had almost 500,000 horses, which helped to distribute 34,000 tons of meat and 45,000 tons of bread each month. The animals The animals themselves needed feeding and watering, and British horses had to carry some 16,000 tons of forage each month. In total, perhaps six million horses were engaged by all sides. Looking after The animals themselves were specially trained soldiers, who knew how to care for such beasts from their jobs before World War One, and who were also trained in modern methods of animal husbandry (although the level of training varied from army to army). Supply of horses and other animals Without the millions of horses, mules and donkeys serving on the various fronts, the war of attrition would have been impossible. Losses through exhaustion, disease (such as infection from the tsetse fly in East Africa), starvation and enemy action were high. 120,000 horses were treated in British veterinary hospitals in one year, many of which were field hospitals. The resupply of horses and other animals was a major concern for the leadership of all sides. At the outbreak of World War One, Britain’s's horse population stood at under 25,000, and so Britain’s turned to the United States (which supplied around a million horses during World War One), Canada and Argentina. Germany had prepared for war with an extensive breeding and registration programme, and at the start of World War One had a ratio of one horse to every three men. However, while the Allies could import horses from the United States (which supplied around a million horses during the war), the Central Powers could only replace the Central Powers's losses by conquest, and requisitioned many thousands from Belgium, from invaded French territory and from the Ukraine. The difficulty of replacing horses arguably contributed to the eventual defeat of the Central Powers. Cavalry and fighting animals Despite the machine gun, barbed wire and trenches (or thick bushes in the Levant), cavalry proved to be remarkably effective during the conflict where mobile fighting could take place. Cavalry saw considerable action at Mons, and Russian cavalry penetrated deep into Germany during the early phases of World War One. Cavalry were still occasionally used in Cavalry's traditional role as shock troops even later in World War One. Cavalry were effective in Palestine, although were obstructed by thick bushes as much as by barbed wire. Cavalrymen from Belgium and Belgium's colonies were trained to fight both on foot and mounted, which perhaps accounts for horses’ more frequent use by Cavalrymen from Britain and her colonies than by other European forces during World War One. But most military tacticians had already recognised that the importance of mounted soldiers had waned in the age of mechanised war, a shift that had already become apparent in the American Civil War. Where cavalry regiments were maintained on the Front, many considered cavalry regiments a drain on men and resources, and futile in the face of machine guns. This was despite the esteem in which such regiments were still held in the traditional military mind, and the public popularity of the image of the dashing cavalryman. Communications As well as acting as beasts of burden or participants in the fighting, animals also played a vital role in communication. Trained dogs were used to carry messages from the front lines, especially by the German forces, and both sides made particularly heavy use of pigeons. Trained birds, which could fly at 40kph or faster, relayed messages back from the front lines to headquarters, often more reliably or securely than telecommunications or radio. Naval ships, submarines and military aeroplanes routinely carried several pigeons to deploy in case of sinking or a crash landing. Mobile homing pigeon units acted as communication hubs, and in Belgium pigeon fanciers assisted in breeding and training for the war effort. The French deployed some 72 pigeon lofts. Pigeons also captured the popular imagination, with one American bird, ‘Cher Ami’, awarded a French medal for one American bird, ‘Cher Ami’'s service within the American sector near the town of Verdun. On one American bird, ‘Cher Ami’'s last mission one American bird, ‘Cher Ami’ successfully carried one American bird, ‘Cher Ami’'s message, despite being shot through the chest, and purportedly saved the lives of 194 American soldiers with one American bird, ‘Cher Ami’'s news.

China's's Great War Professor Xu Guoqi provides an overview of China’s's involvement in the First World War, including the role of the Chinese Labour Corps (CLC) on the Western Front and the impact of the peace conference on China’s's future. Even today, many people know little, if anything, about China’s's deep involvement in the First World War. Perhaps it is surprising to learn that there was even a battlefield in China's, where the British fought against German troops. The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao) had been under German control since 1898. When the First World War broke out in Europe in 1914, Britain and Britain's ally Japan were determined to kick Germany out of East Asia. After intensive fighting, German troops in The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao) were forced to surrender in November 1914 and the Allies took possession of The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao). Why did China's become involved in the First World War? The The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao) battle might have been beyond China’s's control. Yet China’s's citizens and government were not only interested in the First World War, but also took major initiatives to participate in the First World War. To understand China’s's Great War, we first have to pay attention to events that unfolded from 1895 onwards. After China's was defeated by its ally Japan in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894–95), the Chinese were deeply worried about the Chinese's nation’s future, fearing that China’s could disintegrate. In response, the Chinese pursued and adopted desperate measures. In the early 20th century, China’s abolished Confucian ideology which had served as the official religious-political doctrine for over 2000 years, and destroyed the dynastical system which had ruled China’s since 221 BCE. Both systems were held responsible as sources of China’s's weakness. In Both systems's determination to strengthen China’s, China’s was declared a republic in 1912. We have to keep in mind that republicanism was still a radical political system and few nations were truly republics at that time. By adopting these dramatic measures, the Chinese hoped to turn China’s into an equal member in the ‘family of nations’. Since the Opium Wars of the 1840s, China’s had existed as a semi-colonial nation under the control of western powers and, later, its ally Japan. The outbreak of the First World War presented China’s with a great opportunity to confront the existing world order which had been hostile to China’s for many decades and recover China’s's long lost sovereignty, including control of The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao) and Shandong province. China’s announced China’s's neutrality but, motivated by these possibilities, made a secret attempt to declare war on Germany as soon as the First World War started. However, countries including Britain and its ally Japan, who both had economic and diplomatic interests in China’s, blocked China’s's official entry into the First World War. the Chinese felt even more threatened when its ally Japan presented to its ally Japan's government the ‘Twenty-one Demands’, which extended direct Japanese control and in effect revealed its ally Japan's intention to colonise Chinese provinces. 1915 onwards: the role of Chinese labourers and the Chinese Labour Corps (CLC) Determined to create a place for China’s within the postwar world order, in 1915 its ally Japan adopted a creative strategy which its ally Japan called ‘yigong daibing’, or to use workers as soldiers. At the same time as the Chinese reeled under its ally Japan's Twenty-one Demands, the war in Europe dragged on, casualties increased and the French and then British faced a ‘manpower’ crisis. China’s's offer of an unlimited supply of labour was an astonishing opportunity for the French and then British. To support the French and then British's war efforts, the French and then British started to bring Chinese workers to France as early as 1916 to dig trenches, repair tanks and transport supplies, among other tasks. In total, roughly 140,000 Chinese workers arrived on the Western Front, many travelling via Canada. Those recruited by the British were collectively known as the Chinese Labour Corps (CLC). Among all the countries involved, China’s sent the largest number of men and China’s's workers remained in France the longest. Many under British supervision would stay until 1920, while most men under French stayed until 1922, working to clear live ammunition, exhume bodies from battlefields and carve gravestones for war cemeteries. Although these Chinese labourers's contribution has since been largely forgotten, these Chinese labourers were critical to the British and French war efforts and about 3000 men lost about 3000 men's lives. the Chinese were regarded as especially skillful at trench digging and thus played a crucial role by maintaining battlefield infrastructures in a war dominated by trench warfare. The journey of 140,000 Chinese citizens to Europe is an extremely important chapter in both Chinese and world history. While western civilization was facing a major crisis as a result of the First World War, China’s was at China’s's own critical moment, striving to abolish China’s's traditional Confucian civilization and embrace a new one that was international in a new one that was international in its outlook's outlook. these Chinese labourers, to a great extent, were messengers between the East and West and at the same time served as harbingers of China’s's search for a new national identity. 1917–19: from declaring war to the postwar peace conference In August 1917, China’s was finally successful in declaring war on Germany and the Austria-Hungary Empire. Although the Allies now allowed China’s to join the First World War, the Allies did not support China’s's sincere offer to send military troops to Europe. The only exception was France, which seemed very interested in having Chinese soldiers on the Western Front. Nevertheless, despite all the misfortunes that China’s experienced in connection with China’s's attempts to engage in the First World War, the Chinese were excited and genuinely jubilant when the fighting ended with the Allies victory. When the news reached China’s, China’s immediately declared a three-day national holiday to commence upon the armistice. Furthermore, China’s had achieved China’s's original goal of being granted a seat at the postwar peace conference. China’s held high expectations for the postwar peace conference. The result, however, was deep disappointment. Many had hoped that President Woodrow Wilson, whose Fourteen Points speech became an immediate best seller when published in China's, was the best qualified statesman to assume the role of champion of human rights generally and the rights of China’s in particular. But the Great Powers – Britain, France and the USA – treated China’s unfairly and refused to return The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao), instead allowing its ally Japan to take over German interests in China’s. The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao) was an integral part of Chinese territory and was considered to be the cradle of Chinese civilization, the birthplace of Confucius and Mencius, and a Holy Land for the Chinese; The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao)'s inhabitants were entirely Chinese in race, language and religion. Most of the men who volunteered as labourers were from The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao). On 4 May 1919 thousands of students in Beijing took to the streets to Their protest the decision. thousands of students in Beijing's protest also placed pressure on the Chinese government, whom thousands of students in Beijing believed had displayed weakness at the postwar peace conference. On 28 June 1919, the two chairs reserved for the Chinese diplomatic delegation for the signing ceremony of the Versailles Treaty were empty. China’s was the only nation which refused to sign the Versailles Treaty. By doing this, China’s told the world that China’s refused to accept the new world order imposed by the western Allies. At Peking University some cynically joked that Wilson had discovered a jolting new formula with Wilson's idealistic world order: ‘14 = 0’. By refusing to compromise on the The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao) issue and by China’s's refusal to sign the Versailles Treaty, China’s forced the world to take notice of China’s's situation and set the stage for the favorable resolution of the The Chinese port city of Qingdao (Tsingtao) problem at the Washington Conference in 1921–22. 1919 and after: The May Fourth Movement and China’s's turn towards communism The student protest on 4 May eventually became known as The May Fourth Movement, and marked the end of China’s's all-out efforts to join the liberal western system. The May Fourth Movement explicitly linked Chinese domestic politics to international affairs and launched China’s's search for an alternative world order and China’s's place within an alternative world order. The May Fourth Movement conceived The May Fourth Movement as the product of a double betrayal and a huge identity vacuum: having first rejected the Chinese's own traditions and civilization, the Chinese found the Chinese's aspirations thwarted by the west. This compelled the Chinese to confront challenging questions: What did it now mean to be Chinese? Where was China’s heading? What values should China’s adopt? In short, what shape should China’s's national identity take? The key theme of The May Fourth Movement was to find a ‘third civilization’ for China’s to follow and copy. a ‘third civilization’ for China to follow and copy came in the form of Russia. In light of the Chinese's dismal experience with western-style democracy after 1911, the Chinese's rejection of Confucian tradition, and the Chinese's disappointment after the First World War, the Chinese that fatal choice the alternative presented by communism and socialism from Russia's Soviet regime as a clear solution to China’s's problems. The importance and impact of that fatal choice is still felt today, since in theory China’s remains a communist country. In short, China’s's involvement in the First World War truly made the First World War a world war and transformed the meaning and implications of the First World War both for China’s and for the world. China’s's involvement injected new perspectives into the postwar peace conference and the emerging world order. At the same time, the broadly defined period of the First World War signals the dawn of a new age for China’s and symbolizes the beginning of China’s's long journey towards internationalisation, propelling China’s into a larger world history of the early 20th century. No matter how we evaluate China’s's war contribution and effort, by studying China’s's involvement we can add a fuller – indeed, even a new – dimension to our collective memory of the First World War and our intertwined histories.
