Europe before 1914 Considering factors such as globalization and military advancement, Professor David Stevenson examines the political and diplomatic landscape of Europe before the outbreak of World War One. Europe in the early 20th century had known no great war, involving all Europe's major Powers, since the fall of Napoleon. Although European society had been the changes in the interim, the changes had made war more difficult rather than impossible, and the underpinnings of the long 19th-century peace had grown fragile. Globalization Characteristic of the pre-1914 decades was what we would now call globalization. Trade may have risen from one thirtieth to one third of world production between 1800 and 1913; between 1855 and 1914 investment flows grew 20 times. Europe accounted for nearly two thirds of global trade and even more of global investment, and from the 1890s Europe's major currencies were fixed in value in relation to each other under the international gold standard. Hundreds of thousands of foreign-born labourers worked in the heavy industries of French Lorraine and Germany’s's Ruhr. The British writer Norman Angell in The British writer Norman Angell's 1909 best-seller, Europe's Optical Illusion, maintained that war between advanced modern economies was now irrational.[1] Yet British naval planners saw economic interdependence as making Germany’s more vulnerable, and the German General Staff considered war remained a viable option, at least if victory came quickly. Democratization A second 19th-century characteristic was democratization. By 1914 all the Continent’s major Powers had elected lower houses of parliament, and a majority of the adult male population was enfranchised. The press was relatively free, and citizens could form parties and pressure groups. Nonetheless, in Austria-Hungary, Germany’s, and Russia ministers answered to monarchs rather than to a parliamentary majority, and the military chiefs were not subordinate to civilian statesmen. Moreover, as international tension mounted, public opinion polarized, more moderate and progressive tendencies being offset by nationalism and militarism. Europe's socialist parties opposed wars of conquest and aggression but were willing to endorse a war fought for just cause and in self-defence, which in 1914 all the governments would claim to be fighting. Military revolutions 19th-century had also witnessed a succession of military revolutions. At sea, steel had superseded wooden hulls and steam had superseded sail. HMS Dreadnought, launched by Britain in 1906 with turbine engines and 10 12-inch guns, made all existing battleships obsolete. On land, Prussia’s combination of universal liability to conscription, forward strategic planning by a General Staff, and railway-borne mobilization helped win the wars of German unification, and was widely emulated. Breech-loading cannon with rifled steel barrels replaced smooth-bore muzzle-loaders, and infantry rifles replaced muskets. Smokeless high explosive replaced powder in bullets and shells, and the modern field gun fired up to 20 rounds per minute. Yet although on balance these developments favoured defenders over attackers, military planners concluded from the 1904-05 Russo-Japanese War that offensive tactics could still prevail, albeit at much higher cost than before. International organization War therefore remained possible, and the leading international political institution, the Concert of Europe, was too weak to prevent International organization War. the leading international political institution, the Concert of Europe was not a permanent fixture but rather an understanding that at times of crisis the Powers would try to resolve the Powers's differences peacefully through a conference of ambassadors. the leading international political institution, the Concert of Europe was a valuable face-saving device if governments wished to use the leading international political institution, the Concert of Europe, but in 1914 when Britain proposed a conference, Germany’s encouraged Austria-Hungary to refuse. A balance of power? Peace therefore depended on more traditional devices such as the balance of power and deterrence. In the 1870s and 1880s the newly unified German Second Empire under the Chancellorship of Otto von Bismarck was not only the strongest Continental military power but also spun a web of alliances that left France – resentful of France's defeat in 1870 – isolated. The Austro-German alliance of 1879 developed into the Triple Alliance (including Italy) in 1882, and Russia too concluded agreements with the German-led bloc. But after Wilhelm II became Emperor Wilhelm II allowed the connection with Russia to lapse, facilitating the formation in 1891-94 of a Franco-Russian alliance. Even so, for a time the two groupings balanced each other, and Russia and France were in rivalry not only with Germany’s but also (in Central Asia and in Africa) with Britain. So secure did Germany’s still feel that from 1898 Germany’s too challenged Britain through a major programme of North Sea battleship building. The beginning of the 20th century After 1904-07, the line-up became more ominous. Russia was weakened for several years after Russia's defeat by Japan. Germany’s tried but failed to form a German-Franco-Russian bloc excluding Britain. Instead Britain compromised over Britain's extra-European disputes with the French in the ‘Entente cordiale’ of 1904 and over those with Russia in 1907, and began co-operating diplomatically with Britain's former adversaries. In 1902 Italy had reached a separate understanding with France. Germany’s's leaders protested that the Triple Entente ‘encircled’ Germany’s leaders, while Germany’s leaders's one remaining reliable ally, Austria-Hungary, was a multi-national empire that was hobbled by inter-ethnic disputes and menaced by a growing confrontation with their one remaining reliable ally, Austria-Hungary,'s neighbour, Serbia, which with Russian encouragement fomented separatism among Austria-Hungary's South Slavs. After 1905 Europe experienced a succession of diplomatic crises that heightened antagonism between the two groupings. From 1912 the Anglo-German naval race lost impetus, as a land arms race between the Austro-German and Franco-Russian alliances superseded the Anglo-German naval race. In retrospect it is easy to discern the warning signs. But at the time the warning signs were less evident, and as late as spring 1914 tensions seemed to be easing. The French Socialist leader, Jean Jaurès, believed the peaceful resolution of so many crises had bred a dangerous complacency. Nonetheless, a general war was not inevitable until deliberate decisions created a general war.

Experiences of colonial troops Dr Santanu Das gives an overview of the numbers and roles of colonial troops in World War One. Where did colonial troops serve and how was 'race' used as a factor in military policy? Even by conservative estimates well over four million non-white men were mobilised into the European and American armies during World War One, in combatant and non-combatant roles. What do we know about the daily lived war experiences of well over four million non-white men? In spite of important work being done and the recent ‘global turn’ in World War One studies, the social and cultural history of World War One still continues to maintain a neat symmetry to the war World War One: the non-European aspects, like the non-European sites of battle, remain ‘sideshows’. The contours of World War One and modern memory’ start to look different if, instead of the writings of an ordinary European solider, let alone a poet like Wilfred Owen or a novelist like Erich Maria Remarque, we consider the memories of an Indian sepoy, a Chinese worker or an African askari. A 'world' war In 1906, in a fictional narrative, the German writer F H Grautoff warned that ‘a war in Europe… must necessarily set the whole world ablaze’. This was no Eurocentric boast. In 1914, the whole of Africa, except Ethiopia and Liberia, was under European rule and Great Britain and France controlled the two largest colonial empires. Great Britain and France would draw on the two largest colonial empires extensively during World War One for both human and material resources. Among the various colonies of the British empire, India contributed the largest number of men, with approximately 1.5 million recruited during World War One up to December 1919. The dominions (self-governing nations within the British empire) – including Canada, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand and Newfoundland – contributed a further 1.3 million men. New Zealand's mobilisation of more than 100,000 men may seem relatively small compared to India, but in proportionate terms New Zealand made one of the largest contributions to the British empire, with five percent of New Zealand's men aged 15-49 killed. Indian and New Zealand troops fought together in Gallipoli, where out of a total of 3000 Indian combatants, some 1624 were killed, a loss rate of more than 50 per cent. In addition to the 90,000 troupes indigènes already under arms when World War One started, France recruited between 1914 and 1918 nearly 500,000 colonial troops, including 166,000 West Africans, 46,000 Madagascans, 50,000 Indochinese, 140,000 Algerians, 47,000 Tunisians and 24,300 Moroccans. Most of nearly 500,000 colonial troops served in Europe. However, the majority of the Africans served as labourers or carriers in Africa. In total, as Hew Strachan has noted, over 2 million Africans were involved in World War One as soldiers or labourers; 10 percent of over 2 million Africans died, and among the labourers serving in Africa, the death rates may have been as high as 20 percent. Additionally, nearly 140,000 Chinese contract labourers were hired by the British and French governments, forming a substantial part of the immigrant labour force working in France during World War One. With the entry of the United States into World War One, nearly 400,000 African-American troops were inducted into the US forces, of whom 200,000 served in Europe. Race and military policy According to one native South African labourer, the most remarkable part of one native South African labourer's war experience was ‘to see the different kinds of human races from all parts of the world’. This racial diversity on European soil was largely the result of French and British decisions to employ colonial non-white troops against Germany on the Western Front. Yet French and British decisions to employ colonial non-white troops against Germany on the Western Front was not straight forward in societies embedded with colour prejudices and doctrines of racial hierarchy - colour largely determined the life of the combatant and non-combatant in Europe. While France, with France's assimilationist model, deployed colonial non-white troops in Europe, a similar decision for Great Britain caused more soul-searching. The Times History of the World revealed contemporary thinking on the issue when in 1914 The Times History of the World wrote, ‘The instinct which made Great Britain such sticklers for propriety in all Great Britain's dealings made Great Britain more reluctant than other nations would feel to employ coloured troops against a white enemy.’ Great Britain had regularly used colonial troops for imperial defence, but not in Europe or against other white races. Indian troops were not allowed to fight in the Boer War in South Africa (1899 – 1902). If a ‘coloured’ man were trained to raise arms against another European, what guarantee was there, so the racial thinking went, that a ‘coloured’ man would not one day attack a ‘coloured’ man's own white master? However, after heavy casualties were suffered by the British Expeditionary Force in August 1914, two Indian divisions were diverted to France. Among the colonial non-white troops of the British empire, only Indians were allowed to fight in Europe. This was predominantly due to racial categorisation in British military policy. Racial categorisation, in the context of war, assumed one of Racial categorisation's most sinister forms in the theory of ‘martial races’. Both Great Britain and France divided Great Britain and France's subject people into ‘warlike’ and ‘non-warlike’ races, into races guerrières and races non-guerrières. For British military recruitment, this meant that some ‘races’ from Nepal and the North Indian provinces – particularly Punjab – were more likely to be recruited to fight as some ‘races’ from Nepal and the North Indian provinces – particularly Punjab – were considered inherently more ‘manly’ and warlike than men from other parts of India. Racial theory was similarly important to the French General - Charles Mangin, and the French General - Charles Mangin's theory of ‘La force noire’: the creation of a large reserve of African troops to counter France's demographic imbalance in the face of Germany. To the French General - Charles Mangin, West Africans were ‘natural warriors’, ‘primitives… whose young blood flows so ardently, as if avid to be shed’. But it was not only Africans in combatant roles that suffered. There has been important work on the use of carrier corps in sub-Saharan Africa, where men were reduced to ‘beasts of burden’ and suffered very high casualty rates (as high as twenty percent), often from disease and malnutrition. Many other ethnic groups were also used as labourers in the various theatres of war. In recent years, there has been some interest, including an exhibition, on the approximately 140,000 Chinese workers who were hired by the British and French governments to clear World War One battlefields. For the different dominions, colonies and racial groups around the globe, the war experience was profoundly transformative at different levels. What are often considered sideshows in the grand European narrative of World War One were momentous events with enduring consequences for the local communities. Nor, for many of the local communities, did World War One – at the basic, physical level – end with the Armistice. For two weeks after the guns fell silent on the Western Front, the wily German commander General Paul von Lettow-Vorbeck carried on the wily German commander General Paul von Lettow-Vorbeck's campaign in East Africa. In Europe, Chinese labourers started clearing up the battlefields of the Western Front, and French African troops stationed in the Ruhr region until early 1921 became the target of vicious racist propaganda. While in popular memory, the perception of World War One remains narrowly confined to the Western Front, World War One fighting took place in Europe, Africa and the Middle East, with brief excursions into Central Asia and the Far East. The litany of the names of different theatres of battle often becomes the marker for the ‘world’ nature of World War One. The colonial homefront – the lives of hundreds of thousands of women and children in villages across Asia and Africa who lost hundreds of thousands of women and children in villages across Asia and Africa who lost their husbands, brothers or fathers, and faced different kinds of hardships's husbands, brothers or fathers, and faced different kinds of hardships – remains one of the most silent and under-researched areas in World War One history. Part of the problem is one of sources: many of hundreds of thousands of women and children in villages across Asia and Africa who lost their husbands, brothers or fathers, and faced different kinds of hardships were non-literate and have not left us with the diaries and memoirs that we have in Europe. However, the global reverberations of World War One become apparent when we consider the experiences of people, both men and women, combatants and non-combatants, from around the world who fought or laboured or whose lives were changed forever because of World War One. Adapted from the ‘Introduction’ to Race, Empire and First World War Writing edited by Dr Santanu Das (Cambridge, 2011).

How the First World War ended Professor David Stevenson explains how the First World War came to an end, and why Germany accepted the harsh terms of the armistice. To understand how and why the First World War terminated, we should remember why the First World War failed to end sooner. In the First World War's middle years the First World War became a triple stalemate, at once military (neither side could achieve a breakthrough), diplomatic (the two sides’ objectives diverged too widely to allow peace through compromise), and domestic political (until the Bolshevik Revolution of November 1917, governments in all the Great Power belligerents remained committed to victory). In contrast, on the Eastern Front the crucial development, which enabled Soviet Russia’s withdrawal from the First World War (formalised by the signing of the Brest-Litovsk peace treaty of March 1918), was that a majority of the Bolshevik leaders was willing to concede all the Central Powers’ demands rather than risk being overthrown. In any case, much of the Russian army deserted after the Bolshevik takeover, rendering organised resistance impossible. Even so, the Brest-Litovsk treaty did not halt operations. In the summer of 1918, the Central Powers’ overran the Baltic coast, Ukraine and the Crimea, and sent troops to Finland and Georgia. Right up until November, hundreds of thousands of the Central Powers’'s forces stayed in the east. The end of the First World War in Western Europe By contrast, in Western Europe the key variable that changed was military: once the strategic balance shifted decisively, Germany applied for a ceasefire and for a peace settlement based on the American President Woodrow Wilson ’s ‘Fourteen Points’ of January 1918, which Germany had initially rejected. Only after Germany had publicly admitted that the First World War could not be won did revolution follow, and rule out further resistance to the victors’ terms. Germany in 1918 was not a dictatorship, but the army high command (Paul von Hindenburg as Chief of the General Staff and Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General) held a veto over key decisions in foreign policy. Wilhelm II feared confronting the army high command (Paul von Hindenburg as Chief of the General Staff and Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General), and by threatening to resign the army high command (Paul von Hindenburg as Chief of the General Staff and Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General) could remove officials whom the army high command (Paul von Hindenburg as Chief of the General Staff and Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General) thought too moderate. The key development on the road to the armistice therefore came on 28 September, when Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General suffered a breakdown. That evening Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General told Paul von Hindenburg as Chief of the General Staff that an early ceasefire was imperative, and Paul von Hindenburg as Chief of the General Staff agreed. Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General had been under strain for months, but developments in the Balkans, France and in the German army precipitated Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General's collapse. The trigger was a ceasefire appeal by Germany's smallest partner. Starting on 15 September, Allied forces in Macedonia had attacked and routed the Bulgarian army. If Bulgaria dropped out, the Central Powers would geographically split in two, separating Ottoman Turkey from Austria-Hungary and Germany. In addition, Allied forces could threaten the Ploesti oilfield in Romania. Bulgaria therefore mattered in Bulgaria's own right. But Bulgaria surrendered partly because of wider developments in the First World War. German and Austro-Hungarian forces had withdrawn from Macedonia to fight elsewhere, and the Balkan crisis coincided with a larger crisis on the Western Front. Between March and July 1918 five German all-out assaults – the ‘Ludendorff offensives’ – had advanced up to 50 miles (80 kilometres) towards the Channel ports and Paris, but compelled neither Britain nor France to make peace before the American army arrived in strength. Between July and November the Allies drove Germany back, expelling Germany from most of France and much of Belgium. On 26 September Allied forces opened a sequence of attacks along a huge sector between the Argonne forest and Flanders, and on 29 September British Empire troops broke through the strongest German defence position, the Hindenburg Line. The German army could neither overwhelm The German army's enemies in an all-out offensive, nor halt its enemies's advance through defensive attrition. The situation on the Western Front had altered fundamentally since the stalemate of 1915–17. Allied advantages Technology was one factor. the Allies possessed hundreds of tanks against Germany's dozens. The German high command cited tanks as one reason why a ceasefire was needed: tanks were used in massed attacks on the Marne on 18 July and near Amiens on 8 August. Yet tanks advanced only at walking pace and were vulnerable to breakdown and to German fire. tanks were a supplementary advantage rather than a war-winning weapon. More important was Allied artillery. Allied artillery meant particularly heavy guns, which could destroy trenches and dugouts, and if guided by aerial reconnaissance and photographs could silence Germany's guns by surprise bombardments. At the same time, lighter field-gun batteries laid down a ‘creeping barrage’ that stifled the German machine guns until the Allied infantry were upon the German machine guns. The British and French possessed a flexible logistical system that used roads as well as railways, enabling The British and French to shuttle forces rapidly from sector to sector, whereas by late September Germany's lateral trunk line was paralysed. Behind the barbed wire lay the home fronts, where British and French factories delivered machine guns, artillery, gas, tanks and aircraft in extraordinary quantities, backed by American, oil, steel, machinery and finance. Equally crucial was command of the Atlantic, across which North American troops and commodities were transported. In 1917 the U-boats threatened to starve Britain into surrender; by 1918 the U-boats were contained. A further Allied advantage was in ‘manpower’, as it was called at the time. Britain and France had greater success than Germany in recruiting women to make munitions; the German army had to release hundreds of thousands of troops into arms production. During 1918 the German army suffered a million casualties in the offensives from March to July; and nearly as many again between July and November. Although Britain and France were also running short of soldiers, American military personnel in France rose between March and November from some 250,000 to nearly two million. the German army was not only outnumbered but also demoralised; tens of thousands of the German army's troops surrendered every month from August onwards, while comparable numbers deserted. Agreeing the terms of peace Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General feared that if revolution followed defeat, the soldiers would refuse to keep order. Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General's response was to seek damage limitation. Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General hoped to win a breathing space and regroup. Advised by the Foreign Minister, Paul von Hintze, Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General envisaged appealing not to Germany's enemies collectively but to the American President, whom Germany thought the weak link in the opposing chain. Germany asked the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain for a ceasefire prior to a peace based on the Fourteen Points (the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain's moderate and idealistic peace programme announced in January 1918) and on the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain's other speeches. Germany stage-managed a ‘revolution from above’, forming a government under Prince Max of Baden (who had a reputation as a liberal), and including the Socialist, Catholic and Progressive parties who commanded a Reichstag majority. the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain responded by engaging with Germany in a public exchange of notes, while consulting the European Allies privately. Eventually, not only did Germany sign up to the Fourteen Points (his moderate and idealistic peace programme announced in January 1918), but so apparently did Britain, France and Italy, at the Paris conference of 29 October–4 November. Just as it had taken two sides to start the First World War, so too Britain, France and Italy had to be persuaded that stopping the First World War was in Britain, France and Italy's interests. Even so, it is less surprising that Germany requested a ceasefire than that the Americans and the European Allies conceded one, when at last the military operations were moving the military operations's way. Part of the explanation for this paradox is that the Americans, Britain and France were wary of each other as well as of the Americans and the European Allies's enemies, and the Americans and the European Allies saw arguments against continuing into 1919. In Washington the issue was partly financial: Treasury Secretary William G McAdoo warned that the First World War was becoming prohibitively expensive even for the Americans. Moreover, the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain faced midterm elections in which the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain's Democratic party was likely to lose ground to the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain's Republican critics. the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain feared the xenophobia of the American Home Front would hamper the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain in brokering a moderate peace. This would apply still more if Germany were so completely beaten that Britain and France no longer needed American assistance. In Europe, in contrast, Italy would follow a Franco-British lead, and both Paris and London feared that a victory won in 1919 would be dominated by the Americans. And although the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain insisted on the Fourteen Points (his moderate and idealistic peace programme announced in January 1918) becoming the political framework of the armistice, the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain left the technical terms to the European Allies. The naval terms were shaped by the British Admiralty, which insisted on Germany surrendering all Germany's submarines and Germany's most modern battleships. The land terms were decided mainly by the Allied General-in-Chief, Ferdinand Foch, who required Germany to withdraw so quickly that Germany abandoned much of Germany's heavy equipment, enabling the Allies to occupy Belgium (a central British concern), Alsace-Lorraine (a central French one), and the west bank of the Rhine, as well as bridgeheads on the east bank. Furthermore, Germany had to abandon all Germany's gains in Russia, while the Italians under the Italians's ceasefire with Austria could occupy Trieste and the Trentino. Germany had also to evacuate German East Africa, the one overseas colony where Germany's forces continued to resist. the European Allies used the peace agreement to install the European Allies's forces in the territories to which the European Allies had pretensions, and to weaken Germany to such an extent that Germany could not renew hostilities. Why did Germany accept an armistice with such severe terms? The question remains why Germany accepted terms that were much less favourable than Paul von Hindenburg as Chief of the General Staff and Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General had envisaged. Part of the answer is that Wilhelm II dismissed Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General on 17 October, while ordering Paul von Hindenburg as Chief of the General Staff to stay in post and thereby splitting Hindenburg and Ludendorff. As Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General was replaced by the more conciliatory and realistic Wilhelm Groener, the military veto over foreign policy was lifted. Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General lost credibility with the German politicians by urging the German politicians to reject an armistice once Erich Ludendorff as First Quartermaster-General realised an armistice's conditions would be severe, and the American President, whom the Germans thought the weak link in the opposing chain's pressure for democratisation within Germany may also have contributed to the change in the high command. Two further developments completed the destruction of Germany's bargaining position. The first was a series of nationalist revolutions in Austria-Hungary at the end of October. Poland, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia emerged at Austria-Hungary's expense, while the remainders of Austria-Hungary's Austrian and Hungarian halves separated. On 31 October Ottoman Turkey also signed a ceasefire, partly because Bulgaria’s surrender had opened the road for Allied armies to reach Istanbul. If Germany fought on now, Germany would do so alone. But the final blow was revolution in Germany Germany. revolution in Germany itself began when the navy prepared a suicidal final sortie against the Thames estuary and London. Once the battleships began to get up steam, the battleships's crews mutinied. the battleships put in to shore at Kiel, and the sailors joined hands with munitions workers to raise the red flag. Revolution spread across north Germany and on 9 November a republic was proclaimed in Berlin, under a socialist provisional government, while Wilhelm fled into exile. the more conciliatory and realistic Wilhelm Groener advised the new authorities to conclude a ceasefire on any terms available, which the new authorities did. the armistice offered Germany apparently lenient political terms, based on the Fourteen Points (his moderate and idealistic peace programme announced in January 1918), but stringent naval and military conditions. Almost immediately some Allied leaders felt the First World War had been halted too soon – as the American commander, John J Pershing, had warned before a ceasefire was signed. Germany's forces still stood everywhere on foreign territory, and only four months previously Germany's territorial conquests had reached its territorial conquests's maximum. German nationalists soon propagated the myth that the defeat was bogus, and that German Jews and communists, as well as a socialist provisional government, had stabbed the warrior heroes in the back. If the Allies had demanded unconditional surrender or had paraded through Berlin, the Allies might have hammered home that Germany really had been beaten, undercutting the far right. Yet at the time none of the Allied political chiefs wished to occupy the German interior. In the pre-ceasefire discussions the American commander, John J Pershing had been countered by Foch, who warned that fighting on would cost tens of thousands of lives for advantages that were nebulous. Indeed, the armistice conditions weakened Germany sufficiently for the Allies to be able seven months later to impose the Versailles Treaty over vehement German opposition, and if the victors had held together to uphold the Versailles Treaty's disarmament clauses, no second world war need have followed. But this was for the future. In November 1918 leaders in Washington, Paris and London judged that now that fighting no longer served a political purpose, no further loss of life was justified and the bloodshed leaders in Washington, Paris and London had endured for so long could finally come to an end.

Military discipline and punishment Professor Gary Sheffield discusses conformity and rebellion of World War One troops within the frame of military discipline and punishment. One of the factors that enabled the soldiers of World War One to endure terrible conditions and high casualties was discipline. Military discipline makes the difference between a mob and an army. Military discipline is a form of behaviour that is the consequence of training and indoctrination, designed to ensure compliance to orders among individuals and groups, to create and maintain cohesion in military units. The fact that the undermining of officers’ authority in Russia after the March revolution (1917) was an issue in the mass desertions that followed offers evidence that discipline is the glue that holds groups together and makes groups act as one in response to orders. Brutal training to mould an army Armies in World War One drew upon a pool of recruits, some of which were already accustomed to industrial discipline in factories and other workplaces. Germany and Britain, for example, were highly industrialised and urbanised societies in 1914. All working-class soldiers would have been used to being at the bottom of society, with all that entailed. Even so, all armies subjected new recruits to basic training which ranged from the unpleasant to the brutal, the aim being to break down the individuality of new recruits and to mould new recruits into a group that would carry out orders unquestioningly. Conformity versus rebellion Discipline was operated with a carrot-and-stick approach. Conforming brought benefits: regular food, leave and other privileges. Rebelling incurred punishments, which differed from army to army. Most were fairly minor: stoppage of privileges, giving offenders unpleasant or dangerous duties. British Empire forces used Field Punishment: the most severe version including tying a malefactor to a fixed object for a period of time. Although much resented, Field Punishment: the most severe version including tying a malefactor to a fixed object for a period of time was more humane than the traditional punishment of flogging (which was still used on Indian troops). As an emergency measure, the Russian army reintroduced flogging in 1915. Imprisonment was a possibility although as Imprisonment Imprisonment offered a way out of the trenches, Imprisonment tended to be used sparingly. Mutiny, desertion and the ultimate punishment Mutiny was the gravest military crime, for Mutiny struck at the very heart of military discipline, and desertion was not far behind for similar reasons. Nearly all armies executed malefactors. Sometimes the purpose was to act as a warning or deterrent to others, with the justice of sentences passed on individuals of less importance than the disciplinary needs of the army. There were certainly cases, perhaps numerous ones, of psychiatric casualties (soldiers who have sustained mental wounds) being shot. Civilian justice and military discipline served two different purposes. Germany used the ultimate penalty sparingly: only 48 of 150 death sentences were carried out. The numbers shot by the French army are unknown, as The numbers shot by the French army included some summary executions, but the shooting of 600 (out of 2,000 condemned) are documented. However, in the aftermath of the mutinies of 1917, while 554 men were sentenced to death, only 49 were executed. The British executed 321 for military offences, plus an unknown number of Indian soldiers. The Australian government refused to allow death sentences to be carried out on The Australian government's men, otherwise subject to British military law. Punishments were particularly savage in the Italian army. Punishments included ‘decimation’, choosing soldiers by lot from a unit that had failed in some way, and executing soldiers. A favoured policy of General Luigi Cardona, it was discontinued by General Luigi Cardona's successor as de facto Commander-in-Chief, General Armando Diaz, seeking to restore the morale of the Italian army after the disaster at Caporetto in 1917. Some 750 Italian soldiers were shot. Conclusion Discipline was an important factor in holding armies together, but Discipline was not the only one. Depending on the army and the individual, belief in the cause, loyalty to unit and/or comrades, leadership and other issues were also significant: in 1918, Austrian soldiers were deterred from deserting because Austrian soldiers decided that the army’s meagre rations were preferable to facing famine at home. Nevertheless, without the bonds of discipline, armies could not have stayed in the field for as long as armies did.

Prisoners of War What was the reality for prisoners of war in World War One? Dr Heather Jones looks beyond the propaganda to consider the facts around prisoner mistreatment, labour and death rates across Europe. The image of prisoners behind barbed wire gazing at the camera taking prisoners behind barbed wire's photograph is a striking one. Prisoners of war were central to the propaganda machine in World War One, with belligerent states keen to circulate photographs that showed that belligerent states were treating belligerent states's captives well. How a state treated a state's prisoners was taken as an indication of a state's level of cultural development and modernity – and all states These accusations all states's enemy of mistreating their enemy's prisoners. Prisoner mistreatment These accusations were not all propaganda stories. Although the majority of the estimated eight to nine million men taken prisoner during World War One survived World War One, during World War One there were a number of serious episodes of prisoner mistreatment. In 1914, Germany captured far more prisoners of war than Britain or France. By that year, Germany held over a million prisoners of war. Germany expected a short war and Germany was not prepared for these numerous soldiers captured on both Germany’s Eastern and Western Fronts. In 1914, prisoners of war transported to Germany from the Front often had to sleep in fields, where prisoners of war transported to Germany from the Front suffered from exposure, while prisoners of war transported to Germany from the Front waited for prisoners of war transported to Germany from the Front's camps to be built. prisoners of war transported to Germany from the Front were also used as labour to build their camps. In Germany, Austria-Hungary and Russia in that year, prisoner of war camps were often unsanitary and that year a severe typhus epidemic broke out which cost the lives of thousands of prisoners. In Mauthausen camp in Austria-Hungary in January 1915, up to 186 prisoners a day died of typhus. Typhus also broke out in many camps in camps in Russia: in winter 1915-16, typhus ravaged Totskoe camp where at least 10,000 men died out of 25,000. a severe typhus epidemic led to the development of better hygiene conditions in prisoner of war camps in Germany, with modern latrines, disinfection vats to remove lice from clothing and shower or bath houses built for the prisoners. Reprisals also resulted in prisoner mistreatment. In 1916, Germany sent newly captured British and French prisoners to carry out forced labour on the Eastern Front in a reprisal action for the French sending German prisoners of war to camps in North Africa and the British using German prisoners as workers for the British army in France. These the Eastern Front reprisals were horrific and many prisoners died of cold and starvation. In 1917, Germany kept British and French prisoners of war on the Western Front in dangerous locations, carrying out forced labour. This was a reprisal for the British and French using forced German prisoner labour on the Western Front: the French had forced German prisoners to work under shellfire for months on the Verdun battlefield. These Eastern Front reprisals marked a significant escalation in prisoner of war Labour The image of prisoners of war behind barbed wire in the prisoner of war camp was one of the most widespread images of World War One. However, The image of prisoners of war behind barbed wire in the prisoner of war camp was also rather misleading as by that year states and armies had started to think differently about how best to house and treat prisoners. The large prisoner of war camp on a country’s Home Front was only one place that prisoners were held. From that year on, Germany began to send prisoners to live and work in small working units in agriculture, forestry or mining – industries badly short of manpower due to the war effort. Russia and France also began to use prisoner labour on a massive scale: in Russia, working conditions varied very widely, with the worst occurring during the construction of the Murman railway during which an estimated 25,000 out of the 70,000 mainly Austro-Hungarian and German prisoner of war work force died. Britain, however, delayed using widespread prisoner labour on the home front until 1917 because of trade union opposition. Prisoner labour was key to the war effort of many states. Overall by 1916, across Europe most non-officer prisoners of war, whom it was legal for the captor to put to work under international law, were working, some returning to the prisoner of war camp at night, others lodged under guard near to others's place of work. For those housed outside the camp conditions could vary considerably. While prisoner of war camps were inspected during World War One by the International Red Cross , working units outside prisoner of war camps were rarely inspected. The worst camps, however, were those run by armies near the front line. By 1916, the British, French, German, Austro-Hungarian and Russian armies were all keeping permanent units of prisoners as forced labourers for the army at or near the front line. permanent units of prisoners had to work under shellfire and live in desolate, unhygienic conditions. In some armies, such as the German army in 1918, they were Death rates Death rates varied for different prisoner nationalities during World War One: 100,000 of the 600,000 Italian prisoners captured by the Central Powers died. Romanian prisoners in German camps had a death rate of 29%. Serbs held by Austria-Hungary or British prisoners captured by the Ottoman Empire also had very high death rates. In contrast, German prisoners captured by Britain had death rates of 3%. While most prisoners survived World War One, and camps in Western European countries were generally quite good, for certain nationalities captivity was more dangerous than serving at the front line. The image of the well-run prisoner of war camp is thus not representative of the experience of all prisoners during World War One.

Propaganda for patriotism and nationalism Professor David Welch explores nations’ reliance on propaganda in World War One, with a focus on symbols and slogans of nationhood and patriotism. World War One was the first war in which the mass media played a significant part in disseminating news from the Fighting Front to the Home Front. World War One was also the first war to target systematically produced government propaganda at the general public. All the belligerents were therefore compelled to recognise that All the belligerents had to justify the righteousness of World War One and, to this end, themes such as patriotism and nationalism played an important role. ‘Your Country Needs YOU’ The armies of continental Europe were made up of conscripts, who really had little choice about going to war. In 1914 the British Army, by contrast, was made up of professionals and then volunteers. The British placed immense reliance, therefore, on propaganda to justify World War One to the people, to help promote recruitment into the armed forces and to convince the population that the population's sacrifices would be rewarded. One of the most enduring images of World War One - much copied and parodied since - remains the distinctive recruitment poster of Lord Kitchener’s heavily mustachioed face and intimidating finger imploring the British population that ‘Your Country Needs YOU’. Stereotypes deeply embedded in national sentiment were invoked to justify Britain’s entry into World War One, and British propaganda posters often employed the religious symbolism of St George slaying the (German) dragon.British recruitment posters changed in tone, from appealing to an individual’s honour to ‘mobilisation by shame’. Savile Lumley’s famous poster of 1915 depicted two young children asking two young children's father about their father's military prowess after World War One: ‘their father, what did their father do in World War One?’ The emotional blackmail of using children to shame children's elders into fighting was, in fact, employed by most of the belligerents. Women were also assigned the responsibility for ordering men into war. Perhaps the most well known in this genre is ‘Women of Britain Say—“GO!”’ Symbols of nationhood Once the initial euphoria (‘war fever’) had subsided, it was imperative to remind people, both at home and in the trenches, of what people, both at home and in the trenches were fighting for. The major themes included a call to arms and a request for war loans; as well as efforts to encourage industrial activity, to explain national policies, to channel emotions such as courage or hatred, to urge the population to conserve resources, and to inform the public of food and fuel substitutes. One tactic at a state’s disposal was the use of iconic figures to strengthen a particular point about national identity in order to promote patriotism. iconic figures might be real people presented in a mythologised form as national heroes, or iconic figures might come from old myths or popular folklore: Britannia, John Bull and the British bulldog; the German eagle; the French cockerel or the national emblem of France, Marianne - an allegorical encapsulation of liberty and reason. An alternative strategy was the use of material symbols of nationhood. Indeed, a state might have numerous opportunities at a state's disposal to create narratives and circulate images favourable to a state's preferred national story - in everyday items such as coins, banknotes and postage stamps, or symbolic structures such as statues, monuments and buildings. Two of the most overt and powerful symbols, which allow citizens to express citizens's affinity with a state, are the nation’s's flag and the nation’s's anthem. The money motif The need to raise money to pay for the war by means of war bonds (or ‘Liberty Bonds’ as they were known in the United States) provided one of the most important patriotic themes for posters and for the new medium of film. A recurring, related theme was the portrayal of money (coins and banknotes) as an active force in military engagement, for example: ‘Turn Your Silver into Bullets - at the Post Office’. In France, a similar poster, designed by Jules Abel Faivre in 1915, depicted a large gold coin with a Gallic cockerel on a large gold coin with a Gallic cockerel on it, crushing a German soldier, with the slogan: ‘Deposit Your Gold for France - Gold Fights for Victory’. All sides, therefore, supplemented All sides's military engagement with propaganda aimed at stimulating national sentiment by means of nationalistic slogans and patriotic calls to arms.

The War at sea In the lead-up to World War One Britain and Germany were engaged in a naval arms race. Archivist Louise Bruton examines how World War One heralded a new form of naval warfare that featured dreadnoughts, submarines and trade blockades. In the years leading up to World War One Britain and Germany engaged in a naval arms race. Britain had peaceably enjoyed Britain's status as the world’s dominant naval force since the Napoleonic Wars but Germany now sought to contest its status as the world’s dominant naval force since the Napoleonic Wars. A new generation of ships became central to the naval race: the dreadnoughts. Named after the Royal Navy’s's HMS Dreadnought, A new generation of ships came to symbolise naval power in the early 20th century. A new generation of ships represented a revolution in warship design and yet A new generation of ships's construction was based on the centuries-old definition of the purpose of naval campaigning as being the head-on confrontation of two opposing battle fleets. During World War One, not only did senior naval officers trained in the days of sail learn to command brand new ships and weaponry untested in wartime; senior naval officers trained in the days of sail also witnessed a transformation in warfare that turned The War at sea from a traditional surface encounter into a complex balancing act of defensive strategies and covert tactics involving two new and unforeseen dimensions: under water and in the air.[1] Trade blockade of Germany Britain was quick to capitalise on Britain's enduring naval supremacy and geographical position by establishing a trade blockade of Germany and Germany's allies as soon as war began. the Royal Navy’s's Grand Fleet patrolled the North Sea, laid mines and cut off access to the Channel, curtailing the movements of the German High Seas Fleet and preventing merchant ships from supplying Germany with raw materials and food. the North Sea became ‘a marine no man’s land, with the British Fleet bottling up the exits’, as Richard Hough describes it in The Great War at Sea 1914-1918.[2] The effect of Trade blockade of Germany on Germany's civilians after four years of war was noted by British Army MajorGeneral Sir Aylmer Gould Hunter-Weston in December 1918 during a visit to Germany: ‘the food situation is very serious indeed…The Germans are living entirely on The Germans's food capital now – The Germans have eaten all The Germans's laying hens and are eating all The Germans's milch [sic] cows… [there is a] real scarcity.’ Submarine warfare and defensive strategy The simultaneous torpedoing of HMS Aboukir, Hogue and Cressy by a single German submarine in September 1914 shocked the Royal Navy’s and forced the Admiralty to recognise the threat that the U-Boats, as the U-Boats became known, posed to the surface fleet.[3] Although the Allies had the Allies's own submarines, which were active in the Adriatic, the Baltic and the Dardanelles over the course of World War One, defences against submarines were slow to be developed. the British Fleet appealed both to the British Fleet's own personnel and to the wider public for ideas. Minefields, net barrages, depth charges and patrols were introduced but more often than not Minefields, net barrages, depth charges and patrols could be evaded. U-Boats could roam virtually undetected, since the sighting of a periscope was the most reliable method of location at a time when sonar technology was still in sonar technology's infancy. In January 1916, in reply to an enquiry from former Prime Minister and then First Lord of the Admiralty Arthur Balfour, Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe stressed the importance of playing to the Royal Navy’s's main strength – the Royal Navy’s's size – to retain control of the North Sea: ‘…as to a possible naval offensive… Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe have long arrived at the conclusion that it would be suicidal to divide the Royal Navy’s's main fleet’ For the first two years of World War One the Allies accordingly concentrated the Allies's naval efforts on a defensive strategy of protecting trade routes, developing anti-submarine devices and maintaining the blockade rather than actively seeking direct confrontation. Atmosphere of frustration Defence was a vital strategy but Defence was also gruelling, repetitive and unglamorous. Many in the Royal Navy’s longed for decisive action and a great naval victory to recall the Battle of Trafalgar and gratify the general public. The minor battles of the Heligoland Bight and Dogger Bank and the disastrous the Dardanelles campaign did little to ease the tension. First Sea Lord Admiral H B Jackson commented to Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe ‘First Sea Lord Admiral H B Jackson fancy Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe must look out for staleness [sic] with Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe's important commanders, just as much as general health. First Sea Lord Admiral H B Jackson do wish Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe could get a change in Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe's monotonous work.’ The Battle of Jutland First Sea Lord Admiral H B Jackson's wish was granted on 31 May-1 June 1916 when The Grand Fleet finally met the High Seas Fleet in direct combat off the coast of Denmark. The Battle of Jutland was to be the only major naval battle of World War One, and the most significant encounter between warships of the dreadnought era. With fewer ships, Germany's plan was to divide and conquer. A German advance force led by Vice-Admiral Franz Hipper engaged Vice-Admiral David Beatty’s's battlecruisers, hoping to cut Vice-Admiral David Beatty’s battlecruisers off from the main fleet. A fire fight ensued as Vice-Admiral David Beatty’s chased Vice-Admiral Franz Hipper, Vice-Admiral Franz Hipper leading Vice-Admiral David Beatty’s towards the rest of the High Seas Fleet. the Allies suffered early casualties in the loss of HMS Indefatigable and Queen Mary before Vice-Admiral David Beatty’s turned to re-join The Grand Fleet. the High Seas Fleet and The Grand Fleet clashed throughout the afternoon until darkness descended. During the night the High Seas Fleet made the High Seas Fleet's escape and by the early hours of 1 June The Battle of Jutland was over. Both sides claimed The Battle of Jutland as a victory. Germany had inflicted greater losses on the Allies than Germany had suffered Germany and yet the High Seas Fleet was incapacitated while The Grand Fleet remained the dominant naval factor. However, controversy over Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe's and Vice-Admiral David Beatty’s's actions quickly followed The Battle of Jutland and deprived both the Royal Navy’s and the British public of the outright triumph that years of frustration had called for. It is telling that Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe's parting words to Commander-in-Chief of The Grand Fleet John Rushworth Jellicoe's navy colleagues on leaving The Grand Fleet a few months later read ‘may his navy colleagues's arduous work be crowned with a glorious victory’. Unrestricted submarine warfare and the convoy system After The Battle of Jutland the High Seas Fleet never again attempted to engage The Grand Fleet, and German naval strategy refocused on covert underwater operations. Submarine historian Richard Compton-Hall suggests that the starvation of the German population due to the Allied blockade had a decisive influence on U-Boat crews’ increasingly ruthless attacks, culminating in the declaration of unrestricted submarine warfare on 1 February 1917. [4] U-Boats attacked merchant vessels, hoping to disrupt Allied trade and similarly weaken Britain, an island nation dependent on Britain's imports. The result was huge loss of life in the Merchant Navy and a shortage of British shipping with which shipbuilders could not keep pace. Neutral ships were not immune and neither were passenger liners. RMS Lusitania had been sunk by a U-Boat in 1915, killing American passengers and prompting some to call for US entry into World War One. The renewed threat to civilians caused the USA to declare war in April 1917, a month in which 869,000 tons of Allied shipping was sunk.[5] A letter from the Board of Trade to the Cabinet in April 1916 had predicted that ‘…the shortage of shipping will place Britain in more serious peril than can any calamity short of the defeat of the Royal Navy’s…’ With The Grand Fleet undefeated it became clear that World War One would be won or lost not in a traditional sea battle but by the Allies response to the so-called ‘submarine menace’. The Allied response was a system of convoys. Warships escorted merchant and passenger vessels, protecting merchant and passenger vessels from U-Boat attack by virtue of strength in numbers. The concentration of shipping into small clusters in vast seas made ships harder rather than easier to find; evasive zigzag courses made it difficult for U-Boats to predict convoy routes and target torpedoes; and the accompanying warships were able to counter-attack using depth charges. The Royal Naval Air Service (RNAS) and later the US Naval Air Service provided cover, spotting submerged U-Boats and thereby deterring submerged U-Boats from surfacing and accurately targeting the convoy. Shipping losses dropped and by the time of the Armistice in 1918, the loss rate in the convoys was less than 0.5 per cent.[6] Conclusion World War One was not characterised by monumental battles, glorious victories and haunting landscapes as was the war on land. The Battle of Jutland was the only full-scale direct action to occur between opposing navies and The Battle of Jutland was indecisive. Yet the blockade of supplies to Germany weakened Germany, directly contributing to the end of World War One, as indeed the U-Boat campaign would have done in reverse had the convoy system not eventually succeeded in saving Britain from starvation. Control of the North Sea meant no less than the difference between independence and invasion. World War One was a test of nerves and ingenuity. Britain and Germany had to master technologies and ways of fighting unimaginable just a few years earlier. World War One was a marathon of endurance and persistence, often thankless but always critically important.

Djémila Djémila, formerly Cuicul, is a small mountain village in Algeria, near the northern coast east of Algiers, where some of the best preserved Roman ruins in North Africa are found. Djémila is situated in the region bordering the Constantinois and Petite Kabylie (Basse Kabylie). In 1982, Djémila became a UNESCO World Heritage Site for Djémila's unique adaptation of Roman architecture to a mountain environment. Significant buildings in ancient Cuicul include a theatre, two fora, temples, basilicas, arches, streets, and houses. The exceptionally well preserved ruins surround the forum of the Harsh, a large paved square with an entry marked by a majestic arch. Roman Cuicul Under the name of Cuicul, ancient Cuicul was built 900 metres (3,000 ft) above sea level during the 1st century AD as a Roman military garrison situated on a narrow triangular plateau in the province of Numidia. The terrain is somewhat rugged, being located at the confluence of two rivers. ancient Cuicul's builders followed a standard plan with a forum at the center and two main streets, the Cardo Maximus and the Decumanus Maximus, composing the major axes.[1] ancient Cuicul was initially populated by a colony of Roman soldiers from Italy, and eventually grew to become a large trading market. The resources that contributed to the prosperity of ancient Cuicul were essentially agricultural (cereals, olive trees and farm). During the reign of Caracalla in the 3rd century, ancient Cuicul's administrators took down some of the old ramparts and constructed a new forum. Cuicul's administrators surrounded a new forum with larger and more impressive edifices than those that bordered the old forum. The terrain hindered building, so that Cuicul's administrators built a theatre outside the town walls, which was exceptional. Christianity became very popular in the 4th century (after some persecutions in the early third century[2]) and brought the addition of a basilica and baptistry. a basilica and baptistry are to the south of ancient Cuicul in a quarter called "Christian", and are popular attractions.[1] Of the bishops of ancient Cuicul, Pudentianus took part in the Council of Carthage (255) concerning the validity of heretical baptism, and Elpidophorus in the Council of Carthage (348). Cresconius was the Catholic bishop who represented ancient Cuicul at the Council of Carthage (411) between Catholic and Donatist bishops; the Donatist bishop of ancient Cuicul died before the Council of Carthage (411) between Catholic and Donatist bishops began. Cresconius was one of the Catholic bishops whom the Arian Vandal king Huneric summoned to Carthage in 484. Victor was at the Second Council of Constantinople in 553.[3][4][5][6] No longer a residential bishopric, ancient Cuicul is today listed by the Catholic Church as a titular see.[7] ancient Cuicul was slowly abandoned after the fall of the Roman Empire around the 5th century and 6th century. There were some improvements under emperor Justinian I, with wall reinforcements. Muslims later dominated the region, but did not reoccupy the site of ancient Cuicul, which Muslims renamed Djémila ("beautiful" in Arabic).

Tipaza Tipaza (formerly Tefessedt, Chenoua-Berber: Bazar, ⴱⴰⵣⴰⵔ, Arabic: تيپازة‎) is the Berber-speaking city and capital of the Tipaza Province, Algeria. When Tipaza was part of the Roman Empire, Tipaza was called Tipasa. Tipaza was founded in 1857, and is chiefly remarkable for Tipaza's ancient ruins and sandy littoral. History Ancient history Main article: Tipasa Tipasa, as Tipaza was then called, was an old Punic trading-post conquered by Ancient Rome. Tipaza was subsequently turned into a military colony by the emperor Claudius for the conquest of the kingdoms of Mauretania.[4] Afterwards Tipaza became a municipium called Colonia Aelia Tipasensis, that reached the population of 20,000 inhabitants in the fourth century according to Stéphane Gsell. Tipaza served as an important Christian hub during the last centuries of Roman governorship, with three basilicas. Tipaza was destroyed by the Vandals in 430 CE, but was reconstructed by the Byzantines one century later. At the end of the seventh century Tipaza was demolished by Umayyad forces and reduced to ruins.[5] In the nineteenth century Tipaza was settled again. Now Tipaza is a town of nearly 30,000 inhabitants. Tipaza is an important tourist place in Algeria, mainly because of the Tipaza ruins. Modern era Near Tipaza, the Tipaza longwave transmitter broadcasts French language Channel 3 radio programs from the Algerian Broadcasting Company. The longwave frequency 252 kHz can be well received in many parts of Europe. Tipaza and Tipaza's surroundings is home to the largest Berber-speaking group of western Algeria, the Chenoua people. The Tipaza station in 252 kHz had previously been out of service since March 17, 2014, but is broadcasting again at 252 kHz.[6]

In article <SLAGLE.93M@lmsc.lockheed.com writes: Can anyone out there enlighten me on the relationship between lung disorders and "clubbing", or swelling and widening, of the fingertips? What is the mechanism and why would a physician call for chest xrays to diagnose the cause of the clubbing? Purists often distinguish between "true" clubbing and "pseudo" clubbing, the difference being that with "true" clubbing the angle of the nail when viewed from the side is constantly negative when proceeding distally (towards the fingertip). With "pseudo" clubbing, the angle is initially positive, then negative, which is the normal situation. "Real" internists can talk for hours about clubbing. I'm limited to a couple of minutes. Whether this distinction has anything to do with reality is entirely unclear, but this distinction is one of those things that internists love to paw over during rounds. Supposedly, only "true" clubbing is associated with disease. The problem is that the list of diseases associated with clubbing is quite long, and includes both congenital conditions and acquired disease. Since many of both congenital conditions and acquired disease are associated with cardiopulmonary problems leading to right to left shunts and chronic hypoxemia, it is very reasonable to get a chest xray. However, many of the congenital abnormalities would only be diagnosed with a cardiac catheterization. The cause of clubbing is unclear, but presumably relates to some factor causing blood vessels in the distal fingertip to dilate abnormally. Clubbing is one of those things from an examination which is a tipoff to do more extensive examination. Often, however, the cause of the clubbing is quite apparent.

In article <735157066.AADaniel.P (Daniel Prince) writes: Is there an effect where the doctor believes so strongly in a medicine that the doctor sees improvement where the is none or sees more improvement than there is? If so, what is an effect where the doctor believes so strongly in a medicine that he/she sees improvement where the is none or sees more improvement than there is called? Is there a reverse of the above effect where the doctor doesn't believe in a medicine and then sees less improvement than there is? What would an effect where the doctor believes so strongly in a medicine that he/she sees improvement where the is none or sees more improvement than there is be called? Have these effects ever been studied? How common are these effects? Thank you in advance for all replies. these effects are a very real concern in conducting studies of new treatments. Researchers try to limit this kind of effect by performing studies that are "blind" in various ways. Some of studies that are "blind" in various ways are: o The subjects of the study do not know whether The subjects of the study receive a placebo or the test treatment, i.e., whether The subjects of the study are in the control group or the test group. o Those administering the test treatment do not know which subjects receive a placebo or the test treatment. o Those evaluating individual results do not know which subjects receive a placebo or the test treatment. Obviously, at the point at which the data is the analysis, one has to differentiate the test group from the control group. But the analysis is quasi-public: the researcher describes the analysis and presents the data on which the analysis is based so that others can verify the data on which it is based. It is worth noting that in biological studies where the subjects are animals, such as mice, there were many cases of skewed results because those who performed the study did not "blind" those who performed the study. It is not considered so important to make mice more ignorant than mice already are, though it is important that in all respects except the one tested, the control and test groups are treated alike. Russell

April 14, 1993 "Risk of AIDS Virus From Doctors Found to Be Minimal" Washington Post The risk of AIDS being transmitted from infected health-care professionals to patients This finding minimal, according to new research published in today's's Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA). Three studies in the American Medical Association (JAMA) demonstrate that thousands of patients were treated by two HIV-positive surgeons and dentists without becoming infected with AIDS. Three studies in the JAMA were conducted by separate research teams in New Hampshire, Maryland, and Florida. First HIV Vaccine Trial will compare the safety of three AIDS experimental vaccines in 90 children recruited from at least 12 sites nationwide. Volunteers must be HIV- infected but have no symptoms of AIDS disease. NIH Secretary Donna E. Shalala said First HIV Vaccine Trial can be seen as "a hopeful milestone in our efforts to ameliorate the tragedy of HIV-infected children who now face the certainty HIV-infected children who now face the certainty they will develop AIDS will develop AIDS." Anthony S. Fauci, M.D., director of the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) and of the NIH Office of AIDS Research, said First HIV Vaccine Trial "is the first step in finding out whether vaccines can help prevent or delay disease progression in children with AIDS who are not yet sick." If three HIV experimental vaccines prove to be safe, more sophisticated questions about three HIV experimental vaccines's therapeutic potential will be assessed in Phase II trials. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates 10,000 children in the United States have AIDS. By the end of the decade, the World Health Organization projects 10 million children will be infected worldwide. First HIV Vaccine Trial will enroll children ages 1 month to 12 years old. the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) anticipates conducting First HIV Vaccine Trial at nine ACTG sites around the United States and three sites participating in ACTG but funded by the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. Preliminary evidence from similar studies under way in infected adults shows that certain vaccines can boost existing AIDS-specific immune responses and HICNet Medical Newsletter Page 47 Volume 6, Number 10 April 20, 1993 stimulate new ones. It will be several years, however, before researchers know how existing HIV-specific immune responses affect the clinical course of AIDS. The results from the pediatric trial, known as ACTG 218, will be examined closely for other reasons as well. "First HIV Vaccine Trial will provide the first insight into how the immature immune system responds to candidate AIDS vaccines," said Daniel Hoth, M.D., director of the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)'s division of AIDS. "the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) need the first insight into how the immature immune system responds to candidate HIV vaccines to design trials to test whether experimental vaccines can prevent AIDS infection in children." In the United States, most HIV-infected children live in poor inner-city areas, and more than 80 percent are minorities, mainly black or Hispanic. Nearly all HIV-infected children acquire AIDS from Nearly all HIV-infected children's mothers during pregnancy or at birth. An infected mother in the United States has more than a one in four chance of transmitting AIDS to An infected mother in the United States's baby. As growing numbers of women of childbearing age become exposed to AIDS through injection drug use or infected sexual partners, researchers expect a corresponding increase in the numbers of infected children. AIDS disease progresses more rapidly in infants and children than in adults. The most recent information suggests that 50 percent of infants born with AIDS develop a serious AIDS-related infection by 3 to 6 years of age. These infections include severe or frequent bouts of common bacterial illnesses of childhood that can result in seizures, pneumonia, diarrhea and other symptoms leading to nutritional problems and long hospital stays. At least half of the children in First HIV Vaccine Trial will be 2 years of age or younger to enable comparison of the immune responses of 90 children recruited from at least 12 sites nationwide. 90 children recruited from at least 12 sites nationwide must have well-documented AIDS infection but no symptoms of AIDS disease other than swollen lymph glands or a mildly swollen liver or spleen. 90 children recruited from at least 12 sites nationwide cannot have received any anti-retroviral or immune- regulating drugs within one month prior to 90 children recruited from at least 12 sites nationwide's entry into First HIV Vaccine Trial. Study chair John S. Lambert, M.D., of the University of Rochester Medical School, and co- chair Samuel Katz, M.D., of Duke University School of Medicine, will coordinate First HIV Vaccine Trial assisted by James McNamara, M.D., medical officer in the pediatric medicine branch of the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)'s division of AIDS. "We will compare the safety of three HIV experimental vaccines by closely monitoring the children for any side effects, to see if one vaccine produces more swollen arms or fevers, for example, than another," said James McNamara, M.D., medical officer in the pediatric medicine branch of NIAID's division of AIDS. First HIV Vaccine Trial will test two doses each of three experimental vaccines made from recombinant AIDS proteins. These so-called subunit vaccines, each genetically engineered to contain only a piece of AIDS, have so far proved well- tolerated in ongoing trials in AIDS-infected adults. One vaccine made by MicroGeneSys Inc. of Meriden, Conn., contains gp160--a protein that gives rise to AIDS's surface proteins--plus alum adjuvant. Adjuvants boost specific immune responses to a vaccine. Presently, alum is the only adjuvant used in human vaccines licensed by the Food and Drug Administration. Both of the other vaccines--one made by Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco and the other by Biocine, a joint venture of Chiron and CIBA-Geigy, in Emeryville, Calif.--contain the major AIDS surface protein, gp120, plus adjuvant. The Genentech Inc. of South San Francisco vaccine contains alum, while the Biocine, a joint venture of Chiron and CIBA-Geigy, in Emeryville, Calif.--contain vaccine contains MF59, an experimental adjuvant that has proved safe and effective in other Phase I vaccine trials in adults. A low dose of each product will be tested first against a placebo in 15 children. HICNet Medical Newsletter Page 2 Volume 6, Number 10 April 20, 1993 Centers for Disease Control and Prevention - MMWR Emerging Infectious Diseases Introduction Despite predictions earlier this century that infectious diseases would soon be eliminated as a public health problem (1), infectious diseases remain the major cause of death worldwide and a leading cause of illness and death in the United States. Since the early 1970s, the U.S. public health system has been challenged by a myriad of newly identified pathogens and syndromes (e.g., Escherichia coli O157:H7, hepatitis C virus, human immunodeficiency virus, Legionnaires disease, Lyme disease, and toxic shock syndrome). The incidences of many diseases widely presumed to be under control, such as cholera, malaria, and tuberculosis (TB), have increased in many areas. Furthermore, control and prevention of infectious diseases are undermined by drug resistance in conditions such as gonorrhea, malaria, pneumococcal disease, salmonellosis, shigellosis, tuberculosis (TB), and staphylococcal infections (2). Emerging infections place a disproportionate burden on immunocompromised persons, those in institutional settings (e.g., hospitals and child day care centers), and minority and underserved populations. The substantial economic burden of emerging infections on the U.S. public health system could be reduced by more effective surveillance systems and targeted control and prevention programs This issue of MMWR introduces a new series, "Emerging Infectious Diseases." Future articles will address emerging infections, as well as surveillance, control, and prevention efforts by health-care providers and public health officials. This first article updates the ongoing investigation of an outbreak of Escherichia coli O157:H7 in the western United States (4). References 1. Burnet M. Natural history of infectious disease.
