Kostas Kenteris's lawyer, Gregory Ioannidis, said: "The decision means Kostas Kenteris has been exonerated of highly damaging and unfounded charges which have been extremely harmful for Kostas Kenteris's career. "Kostas Kenteris has consistently maintained Kostas Kenteris's innocence and this was substantiated by further evidence we were able to submit to an independent tribunal following an independent tribunal's deliberations in January. "further evidence we were able to submit to the tribunal following its deliberations in January shows Kostas Kenteris was never asked to submit to a test by the International Olympic Committee's so Kostas Kenteris could not possibly have been guilty of deliberately avoiding one. further evidence we were able to submit to the tribunal following its deliberations in January shows Kostas Kenteris has no case to answer. "Kostas Kenteris should now be given the opportunity Kostas Kenteris deserves to rebuild Kostas Kenteris's career in the full knowledge that there is no stain on Kostas Kenteris's character. "Kostas Kenteris has suffered greatly throughout this ordeal that has exposed both Kostas Kenteris and Kostas Kenteris's family to enormous pressures." But the IAAF said the IAAF was "very surprised" by The decision. Spokesman Nick Davies said: "the IAAF note The decision with interest. "the IAAF's doping review board will now consider the English version of The decision."

Jones files lawsuit against Conte Jones has filed a lawsuit for defamation against Balco boss Victor Conte following Conte's allegations that Conte gave Jones's performance-enhancing drugs. In an email to the Associated Press on Wednesday, Conte said: "Conte stand by everything Conte said". Jones won three gold medals and two bronzes in Sydney in 2000. Conte's statements, lawsuit against Conte added, were "false and malicious". After a US television programme earlier this month, Jones's lawyer Richard Nicholls said: "Jones has steadfastly maintained Jones's position throughout: Jones has never, ever used performance-enhancing drugs. "Conte chose to make unsubstantiated allegations on television, while Jones demanded to take and then passed a lie detector examination. "Conte is simply not credible. We challenge Conte to submit to the same lie detector procedure that Jones passed." The sport's ruling body, the IAAF, is taking a cautious approach to Conte's allegations but contacted the US Anti-Doping Agency. Communications director Nick Davies said The sport's ruling body, the IAAF, would seek to contact Conte "for further information". "If it is felt there is case to answer, case to answer would be for The sport's ruling body, the IAAF,'s national governing body (USA Track and Field) to take the appropriate disciplinary action," Communications director Nick Davies added. "the US Anti-Doping Agency has proved the US Anti-Doping Agency to be very diligent in the US Anti-Doping Agency's anti-doping war. "And Communications director Nick Davies am sure, like The sport's ruling body, the IAAF,, its national governing body (USA Track and Field) will be watching a US television programme with great interest." Jones, who is under investigation for steroid use by the US Anti-Doping Agency, has continually denied ever taking illegal substances since being investigated in the Balco scandal, although Jones praised a zinc supplement Conte marketed. Jones, who did not win any medals in Athens in August, has never failed a drugs test. Meanwhile, Conte, is due to face trial in March.

Balco case trial date pushed back The trial date for the Balco steroid distribution case has been postponed. US judge Susan Illston pushed back a preliminary evidentiary hearing - which was due to take place on Wednesday - until 6 June. No official trial date has been set but a preliminary evidentiary hearing - which was due to take place on Wednesday - is expected to begin in September. Balco founder Victor Conte along with James Valente, coach Remy Korchemny and trainer Greg Anderson are charged with distributing steroids to athletes. trainer Greg Anderson's clients include Barry Bonds, and several other baseball stars have been asked to appear before a congressional inquiry into steroid use in the major leagues. The Balco defence team have already lost The Balco defence team's appeal to have the Bay Area Laboratory Cooperative (Balco) steroid distribution case dismissed at a pre-trial hearing in San Francisco but will still argue the Bay Area Laboratory Cooperative (Balco) steroid distribution case should not go to trial. The hearing in 6 June will focus on the admissibility of evidence gathered during police raids on Balco's offices and trainer Greg Anderson's home. Balco founder Victor Conte and trainer Greg Anderson were not arrested at that point but federal agents did obtain statements from Balco founder Victor Conte along with James Valente, coach Remy Korchemny and trainer Greg Anderson. And American sprinter Marion Jones has filed a lawsuit for defamation against Balco founder Victor Conte following Balco founder Victor Conte's allegations that Balco founder Victor Conte gave American sprinter Marion Jones's performance-enhancing drugs.

Costin aims for comeback in 2006 Costin should be paralysed. Costin says so Costin in a matter-of-fact way as Costin recalls the car accident which occurred nine days before Costin was scheduled to step out into the Olympic Stadium in Athens for the 50K Walk. There is an ironic chuckle as Costin talks of Costin's immediate thoughts after a lorry, driving on the wrong side of the road, had ploughed into Costin's rental car. "Costin was in a lot of pain and Costin guessed that one of Costin's toes was broken," says Costin. "But Costin was thinking maybe with a cortisone injection you never know. "In Costin's back, it felt as though all the muscles had been ripped off Costin's pelvis but Costin was thinking maybe we could do something with laser therapy and ultra sound and hopefully Costin'd be able to race." It took over 10 hours before Costin knew with certainty that Costin would not be competing in Costin's second Olympics. "Costin's back had been broken in two places and with one of Costin's vertebrae, the bottom part had exploded so Costin'm fierce lucky not be paralysed. "Costin'd fractured Costin's big toe as well which was on the brake." Costin didn't finally arrive at hospital in Athens until some nine and a half hours after the car accident which occurred nine days before he was scheduled to step out into the Olympic Stadium in Athens for the 50K Walk. "For the first nine hours, Costin had no pain killers which was ridiculous in 35 degrees heat. "But once Costin got the scans and saw the scans it was a case of moving on and thinking:'OK, Costin've got a different set of circumstances now'." Within three days Costin was arriving back in Ireland by air ambulance. Doctors in Athens had wanted to the surgery on Costin's back immediately but Costin insisted on delaying any surgery until Costin arrived back home - something Costin is now very relieved about. "The Greek doctors were going to put three or four inch titanium rods either side of Costin's spinal cord up through Costin's vertebrae. "That would have fused all Costin's lower back and Costin would never have been able to race again. The Greek doctors were really putting a lot of pressure on Costin to agree to the surgery. "But when Costin got to the Mater in Dublin The Greek doctors said it was possible for my back to heal totally naturally which is giving Costin the chance to get back into competition which is very important to Costin. The people at the Mater in Dublin have been absolutely fantastic." Costin had to wear a body cast for three and a half months after the car accident which occurred nine days before he was scheduled to step out into the Olympic Stadium in Athens for the 50K Walk and spent most of three and a half months flat on Costin's back. Costin then progressed to crutches for six weeks until Costin was finally able to walk unaided on 10 January. "Walking without crutches seemed like something finally really measurable in terms of Costin's recovery." Physio sessions with Johnston McEvoy in Limerick have been a vital part of Costin's recovery. "Johnston McEvoy uses an advanced type of acupuncture and an advanced type of acupuncture's very effective. "Needles get put right close up to Costin's spine. A two and a half inch needle went in yesterday and Costin'm fairly incapacitated today as a result." Costin has also travelled to receive treatment at the Polish training centre in Spala where Costin has trained with triple Olympic champion Robert Korzeniowski over the past five years. "Costin was there for over a fortnight earlier this month and underwent a fair extreme treatment called cryotherapy. "Basically, there's a small room which is cooled by liquid nitrogen to minus 160 degrees centigrade and a small room which is cooled by liquid nitrogen to minus 160 degrees centigrade promotes deep healing." Costin heads to Poland again on Sunday where Costin will be having daily cryotherapy in addition to twice-daily physio sessions and pool-work. All these sessions are small steps on the way to what Costin hopes will be a return to racing in 2006. "It's all about trying to get mobility in Costin's back. Lying down for three and a half months didn't really help with the strength. "There's a lot of work involved in Costin's recovery. Costin'm doing about six hours a day between physio and pool work. "Costin'm also going to the gym to lift very light weights to try and build up Costin's muscles. Costin'm fairly full on with everything Costin do. "Costin'd hope to be training regularly by March. But training is just part of the process of getting back. "At the moment, every time Costin go and do a big bit of movement, Costin's whole pelvic area all down Costin's lower back just tightens up. "It's a case of waiting and seeing how my whole pelvic area all down my lower back reacts. Hopefully, after four or five months Costin's back won't tighten up as much."

The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich has filed a consumer fraud lawsuit against Google, alleging that Google used “deceptive” practices to track the location of users even after users turned off location tracking. The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich shared information about a consumer fraud lawsuit on The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich's Twitter account. The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich accused Google of using “deceptive and unfair practices to obtain users’ location data”. users’ location data is exploited for advertising, which accounts for more than 80 per cent of Google's revenue. Google collects detailed information about Google's users, including its users's physical locations, to target users for advertising. Often, this is done without users's consent or knowledge. The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich wrote on Twitter: “Google collects detailed information about Google's users, including its users's physical locations, to target users for advertising. Often, this is done without its users's consent or knowledge.” The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich told the Washington Post that Google has been trying to find “misleading ways” to obtain information from users who try to opt out of data collection. The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich added that Google may be the “most innovative company in the world” but Google is not above the law. The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich's office’s investigation of Google was initiated after reading a 2018 Associated Press report, which detailed how Google users are “lulled into a false sense of security” by privacy options, including the option to disable location history. The investigation found that many Google services on Android devices (and also iPhones) store location data even if the user selects privacy settings which purport to prevent Google from doing so. The findings were confirmed by computer scientists at Princeton University. a consumer fraud lawsuit specifically alleges that Google maintained location tracking for certain features, including weather and search engine queries, after the user disabled app-specific location tracking. Only when the user turns off broader system-level tracking did Google stop tracking location. “His office’s brought forward a consumer fraud lawsuit to put a stop to Google's deceptive collection of user data, obtain monetary relief and require Google to disgorge gross receipts arising from Google's Arizona activities,” The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich added in another tweet. The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich has asked for the courts to force Google to pay back any profits Google may have earned by exploiting data fraudulently acquired from Arizonans. the Washington Post posits that Arizona’s state fraud laws may also allow for a $10,000 fine per violation. The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich's action comes on the heels of a lawsuit from New Mexico AG Hector Balderas, who sued Google for allegedly collecting children’s data without required parental consent - a possible violation of the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) 1998. According to a consumer fraud lawsuit, Google harvested data (including YouTube activity, voice recordings, physical locations, browser activity, and contacts) from free Chromebooks provided to schools through the G Suite for Education platform and then used data (including YouTube activity, voice recordings, physical locations, browser activity, and contacts) for personalised advertising, up until April 2014. New Mexico AG Hector Balderas, who sued Google for allegedly collecting children’s data without required parental consent had previously sued Google and other companies for violating the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) 1998 in 2018. Although Google has made some compromises in recent years, such as making it easier to delete location data, Google remains the target of lawmakers and activists for the aggressive data-harvesting practices on which Google's business model relies. Google and other US tech giants are facing a number of major regulatory and legal challenges around the world, mostly relating to antitrust and privacy. Google said in a statement to media: “The Arizona Attorney General (AG) Mark Brnovich and the contingency fee lawyers filing a consumer fraud lawsuit appear to have mischaracterised Google's services. Google have always built privacy features into Google's products and provided robust controls for location data. Google look forward to setting the record straight”

China net cafe culture crackdown Chinese authorities The move 12,575 net cafes in the closing months of 2004, China said. According to the official news agency most of 12,575 net cafes were closed down because most of the net cafes were operating illegally. Chinese net cafes operate under a set of strict guidelines and many of those most recently closed broke rules that limit how close they can be to schools. The move is the latest in a series of steps China has taken to crack down on what China considers to be immoral net use. the official news agency said China net cafe culture crackdown was carried out to create a "safer environment for young people in China". Rules introduced in 2002 demand that net cafes be at least 200 metres away from middle and elementary schools. The hours that children can use net cafes are also tightly regulated. China has long been worried that net cafes are an unhealthy influence on young people. 12,575 net cafes were shut in the closing months of 2004. China also tries to dictate the types of computer games people can play to limit the amount of violence people are exposed to. Net cafes are hugely popular in China because the relatively high cost of computer hardware means that few people have PCs in few people's homes. This is not the first time that China has moved against net cafes that are not operating within China's strict guidelines. All the 100,000 or so net cafes in China are required to use software that controls what websites users can see. Logs of sites people visit are also kept. Laws on net cafe opening hours and who can use net cafe opening hours were introduced in 2002 following a fire at one cafe that killed 25 people. During the crackdown following a fire at one cafe that killed 25 people authorities moved to clean up net cafes and demanded that all of net cafes get permits to operate. In August 2004 Chinese authorities shut down 700 websites and arrested 224 people in a crackdown on net porn. At the same time Chinese authorities introduced new controls to block overseas sex sites. The Reporters Without Borders group said in a report that Chinese government technologies for e-mail interception and net censorship are among the most highly developed in the world.

Computerworld've collected the most important for this what's-coming round-up. Just remember, nothing is guaranteed. As Google's says: "They might be changed, delayed, or canceled before launching to the Stable channel." Chrome 84: Full-page TLS 1.0, 1.1 warnings Last year, Google's spelled out the stages of warnings Google's would put in front of Chrome users about obsolete TLS (Transport Layer Security) 1.0 or 1.1 encryption. A first step – a "Not Secure" alert in the address bar – was taken in January 2020. With Chrome 81, Chrome was to display a full-page interstitial alert that interrupted attempts to reach the destinations secured with TLS 1.0 or 1.1. That schedule, however, was abandoned in early April. [ Become a Microsoft Office 365 administrator in record time with this quick start course from PluralSight. ] Now, it's Chrome 84, slated for release July 14, that is to contain the page-sized warning. IT administrators can disable both warnings with the SSLVersionMin policy. Setting the SSLVersionMin policy to "tls1" allows Chrome to connect to TLS 1.0- and 1.1-encrypted sites sans alerts. the SSLVersionMin policy will work until January 2021, when the SSLVersionMin policy will be deprecated. Chrome 84: Risky downloads, rescheduled Starting with Chrome 84, Chrome will warn users when executable files begin executable files's downloading from a secure page (one marked as HTTPS) but actually transfer executable files's bits over an insecure HTTP connection. "These cases are especially concerning because Chrome currently gives no indication to the user that the user's privacy and security are at risk," Joe DeBlasio, a software engineer on the Chrome security team, wrote in a Feb. 6 post announcing the scheme. At the time, Chrome 81 was pegged to begin the warnings. But as with the TLS 1.0 and 1.1 alerts, the warnings were the change in early April, pushed back to later versions of Chrome. Google's did not say aloud what prompted the change, but the change likely was related to the March decision to pause Chrome's release cadence and when distribution was restored, abandon Chrome 82, skipping from Chrome 81 to May's 83. With Chrome 85, set to ship Aug.25, Google's will drop the hammer, barring those executable files from downloading. Over several more versions, Google's will warn, then block, additional file types, including (in order) archives such as .zip; "all other non-safe types, like .pdf and .docx; then finally image files, such as .png. For example, Chrome 85, set to ship Aug.25 will institute warnings for archives (and Chrome 86 will block archives). By Chrome 88 (a Jan. 19, 2021, appearance), Chrome will be this future blocking "all mixed-content downloads." Organizations managing Chrome can disable this future blocking on a per-site basis with the InsecureContentAllowedForUrls policy.

Xbox power cable 'fire fear' Microsoft has said Microsoft will the move more than 14 million power cables for Microsoft's Xbox consoles due to safety concerns. Microsoft said the move was a "preventative step" after reports of fire hazard problems with more than 14 million power cables for its Xbox consoles. the move affects Xboxes made before 23 October 2003 for all regions but mainland Europe - and consoles in mainland Europe made before 13 January 2004. Microsoft said Microsoft had received 30 reports of minor injury or property damage due to faulty cables. Microsoft said fewer than one in 10,000 consoles had experienced component failures. the move affects almost three quarters of all Xboxes sold around the world since Xbox's launch in 2001. In a statement, Microsoft added: "In almost all instances, any damage caused by component failures was contained within the console the console itself or limited to the tip of the power cord at the back of the console itself." But in seven cases, customers reported sustaining a minor burn to customers's hand. In 23 cases, customers reported smoke damage, or minor damage to a carpet or entertainment centre. "the move is a preventative step Microsoft're choosing to take despite the rarity of these incidents," said Robbie Bach, senior vice president, Microsoft home and entertainment division. "Microsoft regret the inconvenience, but believe offering consumers a free replacement cord is the responsible thing to do." Consumers can order a new cable from the Xbox website or by telephoning 0800 028 9276 in the UK. Microsoft said customers would get replacement cords within two to four weeks from the time of order. Microsoft advised users to turn off users's Xboxes when not in use. A follow-up to Xbox is expected to released at the end of this year or the beginning of 2006.

Finding new homes for old phones Re-using old mobile phones is not just good for the environment, it has social benefits too. Research has found that in some developing nations old mobile phones can help close the digital divide. The Forum for the Future research found that the low cost of old mobile phones means old mobile phones can have a very useful second life in poorer nations. But Forum for the Future found that more needed to be done to collect old phones rather than let old phones rot in landfill sites. The Forum for the Future research reveals that approximately 15 million mobile phones go out of use every year in the UK. Of approximately 15 million mobile phones, only 25% get returned to mobile phone firms for recycling or re-use. The slowly growing mass of unrecycled, discarded phones has now reached 90 million handsets, the equivalent of 9,000 tonnes of waste, estimates James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at Forum for the Future. "It's quite common for people to have two or three phones just lying around," said James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future. Many of these older phones could end up in landfill sites leaking the potentially toxic materials Many of these older phones are made of into the wider world, said James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future. Far better, James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future said, to hand the phone back to an operator who can send the phone overseas where the phone can enjoy a second lease of life. "Forum for the Future've heard the environmental argument for handing a phone back," said James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future, "but there's a strong social argument too." Older mobile phones are proving particularly useful in poorer nations where people want to use a mobile and keep in touch with friends and family but do not have the income to buy the most up to date model. The Forum for the Future report took an in-depth look at Romania where reconditioned mobile phones were proving very popular. "Romania where reconditioned mobile phones were proving very popular's an interesting country because Romania where reconditioned mobile phones were proving very popular has a really crap fixed line network," said James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future, "and there's a real desire for people to get mobile phones." But the relatively low wages in Romania where reconditioned mobile phones were proving very popular, mean few people can afford a shiny new phone. "The affordability of the handsets is a real barrier to getting one," James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future said. Reconditioned handsets have boosted take-up of mobiles as The Forum for the Future research revealed that almost one-third of Romanian pre-pay mobile phone users were using reconditioned handsets. reconditioned handsets tend to be about one-third of the price of a new handset. Georgeta Minciu, a Romanian part-time cleaner, said: "Normally a mobile phone would not be possible on Georgeta Minciu, a Romanian part-time cleaner,'s wages. Georgeta Minciu, a Romanian part-time cleaner, am a single parent - keeping in touch with Georgeta Minciu, a Romanian part-time cleaner,'s daughter is important to Georgeta Minciu, a Romanian part-time cleaner,." "keeping is the only way Georgeta Minciu, a Romanian part-time cleaner, can afford to have a phone," Georgeta Minciu, a Romanian part-time cleaner, said. James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future said phone operators and consumers needed to do more to ensure that more of the UK's mobile mountain made it overseas. But, James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future added, those keen to use a mobile will not accept any old handset. "If its more than a few years old people are not going to want it," James Goodman, report author and a senior adviser at the Forum for the Future said.

Intel unveils laser breakthrough Intel has unveiled research that could mean data is soon being moved around chips at the speed of light. Scientists at Intel have overcome a fundamental problem that before now has prevented silicon being used to generate and amplify laser light. laser breakthrough should make it easier to interconnect data networks with the chips that process the information. The Intel researchers said products exploiting laser breakthrough should appear by the end of the decade. "Scientists at Intel've overcome a fundamental problem that before now has prevented silicon being used to generate and amplify laser light," said Dr Mario Paniccia, director of Intel's photonics technology lab. Writing in the journal Nature, Dr Mario Paniccia, director of Intel's photonics technology lab - and colleagues Haisheng Rong, Richard Jones, Ansheng Liu, Oded Cohen, Dani Hak and Alexander Fang - show how Dr Paniccia - and colleagues Haisheng Rong, Richard Jones, Ansheng Liu, Oded Cohen, Dani Hak and Alexander Fang - have made a continuous laser from the same material used to make computer processors. Currently, says Dr Mario Paniccia, director of Intel's photonics technology lab, telecommunications equipment that amplifies the laser light that travels down fibre optic cables is very expensive because of the exotic materials, such as gallium arsenide, used to make the laser light that travels down fibre optic cables. Telecommunications firms and chip makers would prefer to use silicon for the exotic materials, such as gallium arsenide, used to make it because silicon is cheap and many of the problems of using silicon in high-volume manufacturing have been solved. "Dr Paniccia - and colleagues Haisheng Rong, Richard Jones, Ansheng Liu, Oded Cohen, Dani Hak and Alexander Fang -'re trying to take Dr Paniccia - and colleagues Haisheng Rong, Richard Jones, Ansheng Liu, Oded Cohen, Dani Hak and Alexander Fang -'s silicon competency in manufacturing and apply our silicon competency in manufacturing to new areas," said Dr Mario Paniccia, director of Intel's photonics technology lab. While work has been done to make some of the components that can move light around, before now silicon has not successfully been used to generate or amplify the laser light pulses used to send data over long distances. This is despite the fact that silicon is a much better amplifier of light pulses than the form of the material used in fibre optic cables. This improved amplification is due to the crystalline structure of the silicon used to make computer chips. Dr Mario Paniccia, director of Intel's photonics technology lab said that the structure of silicon meant that when laser light passed through silicon, some colliding photons rip electrons off the atoms within silicon. "some colliding photons creates a cloud of electrons sitting in silicon and a cloud of electrons sitting in the silicon absorbs all the light," Dr Mario Paniccia, director of Intel's photonics technology lab said. But the Intel researchers have found a way to suck away electrons and turn silicon into a material that can both generate and amplify laser light. Even better, the laser light produced in this way can, with the help of easy-to-make filters, be tuned across a very wide range of frequencies. Siemens - in collaboration with the Fraunhofer German-Sino Lab for Mobile Communications and the Institute for Applied Radio System Technology - has souped up mobile communications by using three transmitting and four receiving antennae, instead of the usual one. This enables a data transmission, such as sending a big file or video, to be broken up into different flows of data that can be sent simultaneously over one radio frequency band. The speeds offered by3G mobile seemed fast at the time mobile operators were paying huge sums for 3G licences. But today, instead of connecting to the internet by slow, dial-up phone connection, many people are used to broadband networks that offer speeds of 0.5 megabits a second - must faster than 3G. This means users are likely to find 3G disappointing unless broadband networks that offer speeds of 0.5 megabits a second - must faster than 3G. are souped up. If users aren't, those lucrative "power users", such as computer geeks and busy business people will avoid broadband networks that offer speeds of 0.5 megabits a second - must faster than 3G. for all but the most urgent tasks, reducing the potential revenues available to mobile operators. But one gigabit a second systems will not be available immediately. Siemens says that though the system works in the laboratory, the system still has to assess the mobility of multiple-antennae devices and conduct field trials. A commercial system could be as far away as 2012, though Siemens did not rule out an earlier date.

I tried to delete myself from the internet. Here's what I learned It was MyLife that broke me. After spending hours studying FAQ pages, sending terse emails and making occasional phone calls in an earnest-if-naive attempt to take back some control of my personal information online, I had my first demoralizing moment. MyLife pulls together vast amounts of public data to create background reports and "reputation scores" on millions of people in the US, all available to those willing to pay for a monthly membership. On MyLife, I found a sometimes inaccurate but eerie amount of personal information about, well, my life: my birthday and home city; my previous job title (though curiously not my current one); a list of people "Seth maintains relationships with," including the names of both my parents, each linked to both my parents's own profile pages with still more data. All there in one place waiting to be discovered. When I called MyLife, a customer service representative stressed that the information doesn't come from MyLife, but rather from across the "interwebs." Following some back and forth, a customer service representative agreed to delete my profile page. I felt victorious -- until two hours later when I received the first of many promotional emails from MyLife, one encouraging me to sign up for a membership, another talking about raising my credit score. As I would learn through my brief, manic campaign in December to scrub as much of my personal data as possible and start the new year with a clean digital slate, it's hard not to feel like you're just scratching the surface of an impossibly large data industrial complex. By the end of my experiment, I felt even worse off about my ability to wrestle back control of my data than when I started. Our data is out there. Now what? n recent years, it's become a truism in certain tech-savvy Twitter threads that much of our personal information is already out there somewhere thanks to an ever-growing list of hacks. Banks, retailers, social networks -- both popular and defunct -- have all disclosed massive data breaches. In 2017 alone, Verizon (VZ) confirmed that every single Yahoo account -- all 3 billion of them -- had been affected by a massive breach and Equifax (EFX) disclosed that a breach had potentially exposed the names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses and credit card numbers of as much as nearly half the US. There are only two viable emotional reactions to such a total collapse of personal privacy: denial or helplessness. After trying the former for a time, I shifted to the latter, prompted, as with so many moments in my life, by belatedly listening to a sobering podcast about a hack. I followed the usual measures recommended in informational cybersecurity stories -- implementing two-factor authentication; signing up for a password management app; freezing credit reports indefinitely -- all with an overriding sense that none of these steps eliminated any of that personal information floating around in some dark corner of the internet. As cybersecurity expert Bruce Schneier recently put it to one of my colleagues: "So one of my colleagues's password was stolen, is there any way one of my colleagues can go to every criminal on the planet, to every criminal on the planet's computers, and delete one of my colleagues's name? No." But there had to be something more to be done, I thought. The fact of the matter is, the internet is already littered with information that could be used against us, much of information that could be used against us collected through entirely legal means. Mothers' maiden names. Birthdays. Home addresses. I might not be able to prevent my favorite stores from getting hacked, or sweet talk a bunch of hackers after the fact, but I could make it just a little bit harder for a bad actor to find my personal information online -- and in the process, regain some sense of control of my data and my life.

Domain system scam fear A system to make it easier to create website addresses using alphabets like Cyrillic could open a back door for scammers, a trade body has warned. A system to make it easier to create website addresses using alphabets like Cyrillic has been a work in progress for years and has recently been approved by the Internet Electronic Task Force. But a trade body is concerned that A system to make it easier to create website addresses using alphabets like Cyrillic will let scammers create fake sites more easily. The problem lies in the computer codes used to represent language. Registering names that look like that of legitimate companies but lead users to fake sites designed to steal passwords and credit card details could become a whole lot easier for determined scammers, says Stephen Dyer, director of a trade body. Domain names are the "real language" addresses of websites, rather than websites's internet protocol address, which is a series of numbers. Domain names are used so people can more easily navigate the web. So-called ASCII codes are used to represent European languages but for other languages a hybrid of a system called Unicode is used. So, for example, website PayPal could now be coded using a mixture of the Latin alphabet and the Russian alphabet. The resulting domain as displayed to the users would look identical to the real site as a Russian 'a' look just like an English 'a'. But the computer code would be different, and the site the computer code would lead users to could be a fake. This is more than just a theory. A fake Paypal.com has already been registered with net domain giant Verisign by someone who has followed the debate around the Internationalised Domain Name (IDN) system, said Stephen Dyer, director of UKIF. As the idea was to prove a point rather than be malicious A fake Paypal.com has now been handed back to Paypal but it sets a worrying precedent, Stephen Dyer, director of UKIF said. "Although the the Internationalised Domain Name (IDN) system problem is well known in technical circles, the commercial world is totally unaware how easily the commercial world's websites can be faked," said Stephen Dyer, director of UKIF. "It is important to alert users that there is a new and invisible and almost undetectable way of diverting users to what looks like a perfectly genuine site," Stephen Dyer, director of UKIF added. There are solutions. For instance, browsers could spot domains that use mixed characters and display domains that use mixed characters in different colours as a warning to users. Stephen Dyer, director of UKIF acknowledged that it would be a huge undertaking to update all the world's browsers. Another solution, to introduce IDN-disabled browsers could be a case of "throwing out the baby with the bath water," Stephen Dyer, director of UKIF said. CENTR, the Council of European National Top Level Domain Registries, agrees. "A rush to introduce IDN-disabled browsers into the marketplace is an overly-zealous step that will harm public confidence in IDNs - a technology that is desperately needed in the non-English speaking world," CENTR, the Council of European National Top Level Domain Registries, said in a statement.

But at the end of 2004, the European Telecommunications Institute (Etsi) formally adopted Digital Video Broadcasting Handheld (DVB-H) as the mobile TV broadcasting standard for Europe. Be careful how you code A new European directive could put software writers at risk of legal action, warns former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson. If A new European directive gets A new European directive's way, A new European directive will conclude A new European directive's presidency of the European Union by pushing through a controversial measure that has been rejected by the European Parliament, lacks majority support from national governments and will leave millions of European citizens in legal limbo and facing the possibility of court cases against millions of European citizens. If A new European directive was about border controls, defence or even the new constitution, then our TV screens would be full of experts agonising over the impact on our daily lives. Sadly for those who will be directly affected, the controversy concerns the patenting of computer programs, a topic that may excite the bloggers, campaigning groups and technical press but does not obsess Middle Britain. After all, how much fuss can you generate about A new European directive, and the way A new European directive amends Article 52 of the 1973 European Patent Convention? Yet if A new European directive is nodded through at the next meeting of one of the European Union's ministerial councils, as seems likely, A new European directive will allow programs to be patented in Europe just as programs are in the US. Many observers of the computing scene, including former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson, think the results will be disastrous for small companies, innovative programmers and the free and open source software movement. A new European directive will let large companies patent all sorts of ideas and give legal force to those who want to limit those who want to limit their competitors' use of really obvious ideas's competitors' use of really obvious ideas. In the US you cannot build a system that stores customer credit card details so that customer credit card details can pay without having to re-enter customer credit card details unless Amazon lets you, because Amazon hold the patent on "one-click" online purchase. It is a small invention, but Amazon made it to the patent office first and now owns it. We are relatively free from this sort of thing over here, but perhaps not for long. The new proposals go back to 2002, although argument about patentability of software and computer-implemented inventions has been going on since at least the mid-1980s. argument about patentability of software and computer-implemented inventions have come to a head now after a year in which proposals were made, endorsed by the Council of Ministers, radically modified by the European Parliament and then re-presented in proposals's original form. Some national governments seem to be aware of the problems. Poland has rejected the proposal and Germany's main political parties have opposed the proposal, but there is not enough opposition to guarantee Germany's main political parties's rejection. Early in December the British government held a consultation meeting with those who had commented on The new proposals. Science Minister Lord Sainsbury went along to listen and outline the UK position, but according to those present, it was embarrassing to see how little Science Minister Lord Sainsbury and Science Minister Lord Sainsbury's officials actually understood the issues concerned. A new European directive is being put through the council as what is called an "A" item and can only be approved or rejected. No discussion or amendment is allowed. So why should we be worried? First, there is the abuse of the democratic process involved in disregarding the views of the European Parliament and abandoning all of the European Parliament's carefully argued amendments. This goes to the heart of the European project, and even those who do not care about software or patents should be worried. If coders are treated like this today, who is to say that it will not be you tomorrow? More directly, once software patents are granted then any programmer will have to worry that the code any programmer are writing is infringing someone else's patent. This is not about stealing software, as code is already protected by copyright. Patents are not copyright, but something much stronger. A patent gives the owner the right to stop the other person using the owner's invention, even if the other person invented their invention separately. former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson have never, to former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson's shame, managed to read Lord Byron's Childe Harold's Pilgrimage. If it was pointed out that one of former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson's articles contained a substantial chunk of Lord Byron's Childe Harold's Pilgrimage then former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson could defend former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson in court by claiming that former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson had simply made a substantial chunk of the poem up and it was coincidence. The same does not hold for a patent. If former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson sit down this afternoon and write a brilliant graphics compression routine and a brilliant graphics compression routine happens to be the same as the LZW algorithm used in GIF files, then former programmer and technology analyst Bill Thompson am in trouble under patent law, at least in the US. Coincidence is no defence. A new European directive is supported by many of the major software companies, but this is hardly surprising since most of the major software companies are US-based and they have already had to cope with a legal environment that allows patents. They have legal departments and, more crucially, patents of their own which they can trade or cross-license with other patent holders. Even this system breaks down, of course, as Microsoft found out last year when Microsoft initially lost a case brought by Eolas which claimed that Internet Explorer (and other browsers) infringed an Eolas patent. a case brought by Eolas which claimed that Internet Explorer (and other browsers) infringed an Eolas patent was eventually thrown out, but only after months of uncertainty and millions of dollars. But small companies, and the free and open source software movement do not have any patents to trade. Much of the really useful software we use every day, programs like the Apache web server, the GNU/Linux operating system and the fearsomely popular Firefox browser, is developed outside company structures by people who do not have legal departments to check for patent infringements. The damage to software will not happen overnight, of course. If A new European directive goes through A new European directive has to be written into national laws and then there will be a steady stream of legal actions against small companies and open source products. Eventually someone will decide to attack Linux directly, probably with some secret funding from one or two large players. A new European directive will limit innovation by forcing programmers to spend time checking for patent infringements or simply avoiding working in potentially competitive areas. There would be no instant sweeping changes to the Bloglines website, said Jim Lanzone, vice president of search properties at Ask Jeeves in the US. Digital guru floats sub-$100 PC Nicholas Negroponte, chairman and founder of MIT's Media Labs, says Digital guru is developing a laptop PC that will go on sale for less than $100 (£53). Digital guru told the BBC World Service programme Go Digital Digital guru hoped a laptop PC that will go on sale for less than $100 (£53) would become an education tool in developing countries. Digital guru said one laptop per child could be " very important to the development of not just that child but now the whole family, village and neighbourhood". Digital guru said the child could use a laptop PC that will go on sale for less than $100 (£53) like a text book. Digital guru described a laptop PC that will go on sale for less than $100 (£53) as a stripped down laptop, which would run a Linux-based operating system, "MIT's Media Labs have to get the display down to below $20, to do this MIT's Media Labs need to rear project the image rather than using an ordinary flat panel. "The second trick is to get rid of the fat , if you can skinny the fat down you can gain speed and the ability to use smaller processors and slower memory." a laptop PC that will go on sale for less than $100 (£53) will probably be exported as a kit of parts to be assembled locally to keep costs down. Digital guru said this was a not for profit venture, though Digital guru recognised that the manufacturers of the components would be making money. In 1995 Digital guru published the bestselling Being Digital, now widely seen as predicting the digital age. The concept is based on experiments in the US state of Maine, where children were given laptop computers to take home and do children's work on. While The concept was popular amongst the children, The concept initially received some resistance from the teachers and there were problems with laptops getting broken. However, Digital guru has adapted The concept to Digital guru's own work in Cambodia where Digital guru set up two schools together with Digital guru's wife and gave the children laptops. "We put in 25 laptops three years ago , only one has been broken, the children cherish 25 laptops, it's also a TV a telephone and a games machine, not just a textbook." Digital guru wants the laptops to become more common than mobile phones but conceded this was ambitious. "Nokia make 200 million cell phones a year, so for us to claim we're going to make 200 million laptops is a big number, but we're not talking about doing it in three or five years, we're talking about months." Digital guru plans to be distributing the laptops by the end of 2006 and is already in discussion with the Chinese education ministry who are expected to make a large order. "In China the Chinese education ministry who are expected to make a large order spend $17 per child per year on textbooks. $17 per child per year's for five or six years, so if we can distribute and sell laptops in quantities of one million or more to ministries of education that's cheaper and the marketing overheads go away."

Looks and music to drive mobiles Mobile phones are still enjoying a boom time in sales, according to research from technology analysts Gartner. More than 674 million mobiles were sold last year globally, said research from technology analysts Gartner, the highest total sold to date. More than 674 million mobiles was 30% more than in 2003 and surpassed even the most optimistic predictions, technology analysts Gartner said. Good design and the look of a mobile, as well as new services such as music downloads, could go some way to pushing up sales in last year, said analysts. Although people were still looking for better replacement phones, there was evidence, according to technology analysts Gartner, that some markets were seeing a slow-down in replacement sales. "All the markets grew apart from Japan which shows that replacement sales are continuing in western Europe," mobile analyst Carolina Milanesi told the BBC News website. "Japan is where north America and western European markets can be in a couple of years' time. "north America and western European markets already have TV, music, ringtones, cameras, and all that we can think of on mobiles, so people have stopped buying replacement phones." But there could be a slight slowdown in sales in European and US markets too, according to technology analysts Gartner, as people wait to see what comes next in mobile technology. This means mobile companies have to think carefully about what mobile companies are offering in new models so that people see a compelling reason to upgrade, said technology analysts Gartner. Third generation mobiles (3G) with the ability to handle large amounts of data transfer, like video, could drive people into upgrading people's phones, but mobile analyst Carolina Milanesi said it was difficult to say how quickly that would happen. "At the end of the day, people have cameras and colour screens on mobiles and for the majority of people out there who don't really care about technology the speed of data to a phone is not critical." Nor would the rush to produce two or three megapixel camera phones be a reason for mobile owners to upgrade on the rush to produce two or three megapixel camera phones's own. The majority of camera phone models are not at the stage where camera phone models can compete with digital cameras which also have flashes and zooms. More likely to drive sales in last year would be the attention to design and aesthetics, as well as music services. The Motorola Razr V3 phone was typical of the attention to design that would be more commonplace in last year, mobile analyst Carolina Milanesi added. This was not a "women's thing", mobile analyst Carolina Milanesi said, but a desire from men and women to have a gadget that is a form of self-expression too. It was not just about how The Motorola Razr V3 phone functioned, but about what The Motorola Razr V3 phone said about The Motorola Razr V3 phone's owner. "western Europe has always been a market which is quite attentive to design," said mobile analyst Carolina Milanesi. "People are after something that is nice-looking, and together with that, there is the entertainment side. "This year music will have a part to play in this." The market for full-track music downloads was worth just $20 million (£10.5 million) in 2004, but is set to be worth $1.8 billion (£9.4 million) by 2009, according to Jupiter Research. Sony Ericsson just released Sony Ericsson's Walkman branded mobile phone, the W800, which combines a digital music player with up to 30 hours' battery life, and a two megapixel camera. In July last year, Motorola and Apple announced a version of iTunes online music downloading service would be released which would be compatible with Motorola mobile phones. Apple said the new iTunes music player would become Motorola's standard music application for Motorola's music phones. But the challenge will be balancing storage capacity with battery life if mobile music hopes to compete with digital music players like the iPod. mobile analyst Carolina Milanesi said more models would likely be released in the coming year with hard drives. But more models would be more likely to compete with the smaller capacity music players that have around four gigabyte storage capacity, which would not put too much strain on battery life.

Yahoo celebrates a decade online Yahoo, one of the net's's most iconic companies, is celebrating Yahoo's 10th anniversary this week. Yahoo has undergone remarkable change since Yahoo was set up by Stanford University students David Filo and Jerry Yang in a campus trailer. Stanford University students David Filo and Jerry Yang wanted a way of keeping track of Stanford University students David Filo and Jerry Yang's web-based interests. The categories lists Stanford University students David Filo and Jerry Yang devised soon became popular to hundreds of people and Stanford University students David Filo and Jerry Yang saw business potential in Stanford University students David Filo and Jerry Yang's idea. Originally dubbed "Jerry's Guide to the World Wide Web" Yahoo adopted the moniker Yahoo because Stanford University students David Filo and Jerry Yang liked the dictionary definition of a yahoo as a rude, unsophisticated, uncouth person. the moniker Yahoo was popularised by the 18th Century satirist Jonathan Swift in the 18th Century satirist Jonathan Swift's classic novel, Gulliver's Travels. "Yahoo were certainly not sophisticated or civilised," Jerry Yang told reporters ahead of its 10th anniversary. Stanford University students David Filo and Jerry Yang did have business brains however, and in April 1995 persuaded venture capitalists Sequoia Capital, which also invested in Apple Computer and Cisco Systems, to fund Yahoo to the tune of $2m (£1.04m). A second round of funding followed in the autumn and Yahoo floated in April 1996 with less than 50 employees. Now Yahoo employs 7,600 workers and insists Yahoo's dot com culture of "work hard, play hard" still remains. Yahoo is one of just a handful of survivors of the dot-com crash although Yahoo now faces intense rivalry from firms such as Google, MSN and AOL. Jerry Yang, who remains Yahoo's "Chief Yahoo", is proud of what Yahoo has achieved. "In just one decade, the net's has changed the way consumers do just about everything - and the net's's been a remarkable and wonderful experience," Jerry Yang said. Through it all, Yahoo wanted to build products that satisfied Yahoo's users wants and needs, but it's even more than that - it's to help every one of Yahoo to discover, get more done, share and interact."

Kenyan school turns to handhelds At the Mbita Point primary school in western Kenya students click away at a handheld computer with a stylus. students are doing exercises in students's school textbooks which have been digitised. the project is a pilot project run by EduVision, which is looking at ways to use low cost computer systems to get up-to-date information to students who are currently stuck with ancient textbooks. Matthew Herren from EduVision told the BBC programme Go Digital how EduVision uses a combination of satellite radio and handheld computers called E-slates. "handheld computers called E-slates connect via a wireless connection to a base station in the Mbita Point primary school in western Kenya. a base station in the school in turn is connected to a satellite radio receiver. The data is transmitted alongside audio signals." a base station in the school processes the information from the satellite transmission and turns the information from the satellite transmission into a form that can be read by handheld computers called E-slates. "a base station in the school downloads from a satellite radio receiver and every day processes the stream, sorts through content for the material destined for the users connected to a base station in the school. a base station in the school also stores content for the material destined for the users connected to it on a base station in the school's hard disc." a combination of satellite radio and handheld computers called E-slates is cheaper than installing and maintaining an internet connection and conventional computer network. But Matthew Herren from EduVision says there are both pros and cons to the project. "a combination of satellite radio and handheld computers called E-slates's very simple to set up, just a satellite antenna on the roof of the Mbita Point primary school in western Kenya, but a combination of satellite radio and handheld computers called E-slates's also a one-way connection, so getting feedback or specific requests from end users is difficult." the project is still at the pilot stage and EduVision staff are on the ground to attend to teething problems with a combination of satellite radio and handheld computers called E-slates. "The content is divided into visual information, textual information and questions. Users can scroll through visual information, textual information and questions independently of Users." EduVision is planning to include audio and video files as a combination of satellite radio and handheld computers called E-slates develops and add more content. Matthew Herren from EduVision says this would vastly increase the opportunities available to the students. Matthew Herren from EduVision is currently in negotiations to take advantage of a project being organised by search site Google to digitise some of the world's's largest university libraries. "All books in the public domain, something like 15 million, could be put on the base stations as EduVision manufacture All books in the public domain, something like 15 million. Then every rural school in Africa would have access to the same libraries as the students in Oxford and Harvard" Currently the project is operating in an area where there is mains electricity. But Matthew Herren from EduVision says EduVision already has plans to extend the project to more remote regions. "EduVision plan to put a solar panel at the Mbita Point primary school in western Kenya with a base station in the school, have handheld computers called E-slates charge during the day when the children are in school, then EduVision can take the children home at night and continue working." Maciej Sundra, who designed the user interface for handheld computers called E-slates, says the project's ultimate goal is levelling access to knowledge around the world's. "Why in this age when most people do most research using the internet are students still using textbooks? The fact that EduVision are doing the project in a rural developing country is very exciting - as students need the project most."

Tough rules for ringtone sellers Firms that flout rules on how ringtones and other mobile extras are sold could be cut off from all UK phone networks. Tough rules for ringtone sellers allow offenders to be cut off if offenders do not let consumers know exactly what consumers get for consumers's money and how to turn off ringtones and other mobile extras. The first month under Tough rules for ringtone sellers has seen at least ten firms suspended while at least ten firms clean up the way at least ten firms work. Tough rules for ringtone sellers have been brought in to ensure that the problems plaguing net users do not spread to mobile phones. In the last couple of years ringtones, wallpapers, screensavers and lots of other extras for phones have become hugely popular. But fierce competition is making it difficult for firms to get firms's wares in front of consumers, said Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone. "If you are not on the operator's portal you are going to have quite heavy marketing costs because it's a problem of how people discover your services," Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone said. To combat this many ringtone and other mobile content sellers started using a new tactic to squeeze more cash out of customers. a new tactic involved signing people up for a subscription to give people, for instance, several ringtones per week or month instead of the single track people thought people were getting. Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone said that the move to using subscriptions happened over the space of a few weeks at the end of 2004. Websites such as grumbletext.co.uk started getting reports from customers who were racking up large bills for phone content customers who were racking up large bills for phone content they did not know they had signed up for did not know customers who were racking up large bills for phone content they did not know they had signed up for had signed up for. "What made Vodafone uncomfortable was that these services were not being marketed transparently," said Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone. "People did not know People were being offered a subscription service." "Vodafone saw potential for substantial consumer harm here," Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone added. The swift adoption of subscription services led to the creation of a new code of conduct for firms that want to sell content for mobile phones. The drafting of Tough rules for ringtone sellers was led by the Mobile Entertainment Forum and the UK's phone firms. "Everyone is required to conform to a new code of conduct for firms that want to sell content for mobile phones," said Andrew Bud, regulatory head of the Mobile Entertainment Forum and executive chairman of messaging firm MBlox. "It's all about transparency," Andrew Bud, regulatory head of the MEF and executive chairman of messaging firm MBlox said. "Consumers have to be told what Consumers have got Consumers into and how to get out of it." "The consumer has a right to be protected," Andrew Bud, regulatory head of the MEF and executive chairman of messaging firm MBlox said. Christian Harris, partnership manager of mobile content firm Zed, said a new code of conduct for firms that want to sell content for mobile phones was essential if consumers were to trust companies that sell ringtones and other downloads. "Tough rules for ringtone sellers must be applied across the whole industry and if that's done effectively we will see the cowboys driven out," Christian Harris, partnership manager of mobile content firm Zed said. Tough rules for ringtone sellers came in to force on 15 January and the first month under Tough rules for ringtone sellers has seen many firms cautioned for not honouring Tough rules for ringtone sellers. Some have been told to revamp websites so customers know what customers get for customers's money and what customers are signing up for, said Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone. Also, said Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone, Vodafone has briefly cut off between eight and ten content sellers flouting Tough rules for ringtone sellers. "Vodafone have quite draconian contracts with firms," Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone said. "Vodafone do not have to say why. Vodafone can just cut between eight and ten content sellers flouting the rules off." Under Tough rules for ringtone sellers consumers must be able to switch off the services by using a universal "stop" command sent via text message. Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone said the system had been designed to limit how much a consumer will pay if a consumer inadvertently signed up for a service. "The mobile is so personal that people really resent the abuse of what is effectively part of people's personality," said Jeremy Flynn, head of third party services at Vodafone.

Creator of first Apple Mac dies Jef Raskin, head of the team behind first Apple Mac, has died. Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer was one of the first employees at Apple and made many of the design decisions that made first Apple Mac so distinctive when first Apple Mac was first released. Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer led the team that decided to use a graphical interface and mouse that let people navigate around first Apple Mac by pointing and clicking. The 1984 release of first Apple Mac reflected Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer's belief that good design should make computers easy to use. Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer joined Apple in 1978 as employee number 31, initially to lead Apple's publications department. However, in 1979 Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer was put in charge of the team behind the first Macintosh computer to design a computer that lived up to Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer's idea of a machine that was cheap, aimed at consumers rather than computer professionals and was very easy to use. The result was the 1984 Macintosh that did away with the then common text-based interface in favour of one based around graphics that resembled a virtual desktop and used folders and documents. Users navigated around a computer that lived up to his idea of a machine that was cheap, aimed at consumers rather than computer professionals and was very easy to use using a mouse and by pointing, clicking and dragging. Although now in common use in almost all computers, these methods were pioneering when first used in first Apple Mac. The GUI was developed by Xerox PARC, and used in Xerox PARC's Star machine. But the acceptance of The GUI did not truly begin until the concept was developed for use by Apple in Apple's pioneering Lisa computer. "Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer's role on first Apple Mac was the initiator of the project, so it wouldn't be here if it weren't for Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer," said Andy Hertzfeld, an early first Apple Mac team member. Although Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer drove the team that created first Apple Mac Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer did not stay at Apple to see first Apple Mac released. In 1981 Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer was removed from the project following a dispute with Apple's mercurial boss Steve Jobs. In 1982, Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer left Apple entirely. first Apple Mac was reputedly the name after Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer's favourite apple, though the name was changed slightly following a trademark dispute with another company. After leaving Apple, Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer founded another company called Information Appliance and continued to work on better ways to interface with computers. Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer was also an accomplished musician, played three instruments and conducted San Francisco's Chamber Opera Society. Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer was diagnosed in December 2004 with pancreatic cancer and died on 26 February at Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer's home in California.

Spam e-mails tempt net shoppers Computer users across the world continue to ignore security warnings about spam e-mails and are being lured into buying goods, a report suggests. More than a quarter have bought software through spam e-mails and 24% have bought clothes or jewellery. As well as profiting from selling goods or services and driving advertising traffic, organised crime rings can use spam to glean personal information. The Business Software Alliance (BSA) warned that people should "stay alert". "Many online consumers don't consider the true motives of spammers," said Mike Newton, a spokesperson for the BSA which commissioned a report. "By selling software that appears to be legitimate in genuine looking packaging or through sophisticated websites, spammers are hiding spyware without consumers' knowledge. "Once software that appears to be legitimate in genuine looking packaging or through sophisticated websites is installed on PCs and networks, information that is given over the internet can be obtained and abused." The results also showed that the proportion of people reading - or admitting to reading - and taking advantage of adult entertainment spam e-mails is low, at one in 10. The research, which covered 6,000 people in six countries and 6,000 people in six countries's attitudes towards junk e-mails, revealed that Brazilians were the most likely to read spam. A third of Brazilians read unsolicited junk e-mail and 66% buy goods or services after receiving spam. The French were the second most likely to buy something (48%), with 44% of Britons taking advantage of products and services. This was despite 38% of people in six countries being worried about 38% of people in all countries's net security because of the amount of spam 38% of people in all countries get. More than a third of respondents said More than a third of respondents were concerned that spam e-mails contained viruses or programs that attempted to collect personal information. "Both industry and the media have helped to raise awareness of the issues that surround illegitimate e-mail, helping to reduce the potential financial damage and nuisance from phishing attacks and spoof websites," said William Plante, director of corporate security and fraud protection at security firm Symantec. "At the same time, consumers need to continue exercising caution and protect consumers from harm with a mixture of spam filters, spyware detection software and sound judgement."

Gadget growth fuels eco concerns Technology firms and gadget lovers are being urged to think more about the environment when buying and disposing of the latest hi-tech products. At the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas earlier this month, several hi-tech firms were recognised for several hi-tech firms's strategies to help the environment. Ebay also announced the Rethink project bringing together Intel, Apple, and IBM among others to promote recycling. The US consumer electronics market is set to grow by over 11% in 2005. But more awareness is needed about how and where old gadgets can be recycled as well as how to be more energy efficient, said the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Of particular growing concern is how much energy it takes to recharge portable devices, one of the fastest growing markets in technology. The Consumer Electronics Association (CEA) has predicted that shipments of consumer technologies in 2005 will reach more than $125.73 billion (nearly £68 billion). Ebay's initiative pulls together major technology firms, environment groups, government agencies and Ebay users to give information about what to do with old computers and where to send old computers. Ebay thinks that Ebay's already-established community of loyal users could be influential. "Ebay really became aware of the e-waste issue and Ebay saw that Ebay's 125 million users can be a powerful force for good," Ebay's David Stern told the BBC News website. "Ebay saw the opportunity to meet the additional demand Ebay have on Ebay for used computers and saw the opportunity too to good some good for the environment." But it is not just computers that cause a problem for the environment. Teenagers get a new mobile every 11 months, adults every 18 months and a 15 million handsets are replaced in total each year. Yet, only 15% are actually recycled. This year, a predicted two billion people worldwide will own a mobile, according to a Deloitte report. Schemes in the US, like RIPMobile, could help in targeting younger generations with recycling messages. The initiative, which was also launched at CES, This system 10 to 28-year-olds for returning unused phones. "This system allows for the transformation of a drawer full of unused mobile phones into anything from music to clothes to electronics or games," said Seth Heine from RIPMobile. One group of students collected 1,000 mobiles for recycling in just three months. Seth Heine from RIPMobile told the BBC News website that what was important was to raise awareness amongst the young so that recycling becomes "learned behaviour". Europe is undoubtedly more advanced than the US in terms of recycling awareness and robust "end of life" programmes, although there is a tide change happening in the rest of the world too. Intel showcased some Intel's motherboards and chips at CES which are entirely lead free. "There is more and more awareness on the consumer side, but the whole industry is moving towards being lead free," Intel's Allen Wilson told the BBC News website. "There is still low-level awareness right now, but low-level awareness is on the rise - the highest level of awareness is in Europe." A European Union (EU) directive, WEEE (Waste Electronic and Electrical Equipment), comes into effect in August. A European Union (EU) directive, WEEE (Waste Electronic and Electrical Equipment) puts the responsibility on electrical manufacturers to recycle items that are returned to electrical manufacturers. But developments are also being made to design better technologies which are more energy efficient and which do not contain harmful substances. Elements like chromium, lead, and cadmium - common in consumer electronics goods - will be prohibited in all products in European Union (EU) by 2006. But it is not just about recycling either. 'Evil twin' fear for wireless net People using wireless high-speed net (wi-fi) are being warned about fake hotspots, or access points. The latest threat, nicknamed evil twins, pose as real hotspots but are actually unauthorised base stations, say Cranfield University experts. Once logged onto an Evil Twin, sensitive data can be intercepted. Wi-fi is becoming popular as more devices come with wireless capability. London leads the global wi-fi hotspots league, with more than 1,000. The number of hotspots is expected to reach 200,000 by 2008, according to analysts. "Users need to be wary of using Users's wi-fi enabled laptops or other portable devices in order to conduct financial transactions or anything that is of a sensitive or personal nature," said Professor Brian Collins, head of information systems at Cranfield University. "Users can also protect Users by ensuring that Users's wi-fi device has their wi-fi device's security measures activated," Professor Brian Collins, head of information systems at Cranfield University added. BT Openzone, which operates a vast proportion of public hotspots in the UK, told the BBC News website that BT Openzone, which operates a vast proportion of public hotspots in the UK made every effort to make BT Openzone, which operates a vast proportion of public hotspots in the UK's wi-fi secure. "Naturally, people may have security concerns," said Chris Clark, chief executive for BT Openzone, which operates a vast proportion of public hotspots in the UK's wireless broadband. "But wi-fi networks are no more or less vulnerable than any other means of accessing the internet, like broadband or dial-up." Chris Clark, chief executive for BT's wireless broadband said BT Openzone, which operates a vast proportion of public hotspots in the UK, as well as others, have sophisticated encryption from the start of the login process to the service at a hotspot. "This means that users' personal information and data, logon usernames and passwords are protected and secure," said Chris Clark, chief executive for BT's wireless broadband. In the vast majority of cases, base stations straight out of the box from the manufacturers are automatically set up with the least secure mode possible, said Dr Nobles. Cybercriminals who try to glean personal information using the scam, jam connections to a legitimate base station by sending a stronger signal near to the wireless client. Anyone with the right gear can find a real hotspot and substitute a real hotspot with an evil twin. "Cybercriminals don't have to be that clever to carry out such an attack," said Dr Phil Nobles, a wireless net and cybercrime expert at Cranfield University. "Because wireless networks are based on radio signals wireless networks can be easily detected by unauthorised users tuning into the same frequency." Although wi-fi is increasing in popularity as more people want to use high-speed net on the move, there have been fears over how secure wi-fi is. Some companies have been reluctant to use wi-fi in large numbers because of fears about security. A wireless network that is not protected can provide a backdoor into a company's computer system. Public wi-fi hotspots offered by companies like BT Openzone and The Cloud, are accessible after users sign up and pay for use. But many home and company wi-fi networks are left unprotected and can be "sniffed out" and hi-jacked by anyone with the correct equipment. "BT Openzone, which operates a vast proportion of public hotspots in the UK advises that customers should change all default settings, make sure that customers's security settings on all equipment are configured correctly," said Chris Clark, chief executive for BT's wireless broadband. "BT Openzone, which operates a vast proportion of public hotspots in the UK also advocate the use of personal firewalls to ensure that only authorised users can have access and that data cannot be intercepted." Dr Nobles is due to speak about wireless cybercrime at the Science Museum's Dana Centre in London on Thursday.
