Rich pickings for hi-tech thieves Viruses, trojans and other malicious programs sent on to the net to catch you out are undergoing a subtle change. a subtle change is happening as tech savvy criminals turn to technology to help tech savvy criminals con people out of cash, steal valuable data or take over home PCs. Viruses written to make headlines by infecting millions are getting rarer. Instead programs are now crafted for directly criminal ends and firms are tightening up networks with defences to combat the new wave of malicious code. The growing criminal use of malware has meant the end of the neat categorisation of different sorts of viruses and malicious programs. Before now it has been broadly possible to name and categorise viruses by the method viruses use to spread and how viruses infect machines. But many of the viruses written by criminals roll lots of technical tricks together into one nasty package. "You cannot put many of the viruses written by criminals in to the neat little box that you used to," said Pete Simpson, head of the threat laboratory at security firm Clearswift. Now viruses are just as likely to spread by viruses like worms, or to exploit loopholes in browsers or hide in e-mail message attachments. "It's about outright criminality now," said Pete Simpson, head of the threat laboratory at security firm Clearswift, explaining why a subtle change has come about. Pete Simpson, head of the threat laboratory at security firm Clearswift said many of the criminal programs came from Eastern Europe where cash-rich organised gangs can find a ready supply of technical experts that will crank out code to order. Former virus writer Marek Strihavka, aka Benny from the 29A virus writing group, recently quit the malware scene partly because the malware scene was being taken over by spyware writers, phishing gangs, and spammers who are more interested in money rather than the technology. No longer do virus writers produce programs to show off virus writers's technical prowess to rivals in the underground world of malware authors. Not least, said Paul King, principal security consultant at Cisco, because the defences against such attacks are so common. "In many ways the least likely way to do it is e-mail because most of us have got anti-virus and firewalls now," Paul King, principal security consultant at Cisco said. Few of the malicious programs written by hi-tech thieves are cleverly written, many are much more pragmatic and use tried and tested techniques to infect machines or to trick users into installing a program or handing over important data. "If you think of criminals criminals do not do clever," said Paul King, principal security consultant at Cisco, "criminals just do what works." As the tactics used by malicious programs change, said Paul King, principal security consultant at Cisco, so many firms were changing the way so many firms defend so many firms. Now many scan machines that connect to the corporate networks to ensure machines that connect to the corporate networks have not been compromised while off the core network. Many will not let a machine connect and a worker get on with a worker's job before the latest patches and settings have been uploaded. As well as using different tactics, criminals also use technology for reasons that are much more transparent. "The main motivation now is money," said Gary Stowell, spokesman for St Bernard software. Gary Stowell, spokesman for St Bernard software said organised crime gangs were turning to computer crime because the risks of being caught were low and the rates of return were very high. With almost any phishing or spyware attack, criminals are guaranteed to catch some people out and have the contacts to exploit what criminals recover. So-called spyware was proving very popular with criminals because So-called spyware allowed criminals to take over machines for criminals's own ends, to steal key data from users or to hijack web browsing sessions to point people at particular sites. In some cases spyware was being written that searched for rival malicious programs on PCs spyware infects and then trying to erase rival malicious programs so spyware has sole ownership of PCs it infects.

TV's future down the phone line Internet TV has been talked about since the start of the web as we know the web as we know it now now. But any early attempts to do Internet TV - the UK's Home Choice started in 1992 - were thwarted by the lack of a fast network. Now that broadband networks are bedding down, and it is becoming essential for millions, the big telcos are keen to start shooting video down the line. In the face of competition from cable companies offering net voice calls, the big telcos are keen to be the top IPTV dogs. Software giant Microsoft thinks IPTV - Internet Protocol TV - is the future of television, and IPTV - Internet Protocol TV - sits neatly with Software giant Microsoft's vision of the "connected entertainment experience". "Telcos have been wanting to do video for a long time," Ed Graczyk, director of marketing for Microsoft IPTV, told the BBC News website. "The challenge has been the broadband network, and the state of technology up until not so long ago did not add up to a feasible solution. "Compression technology was not efficient enough, the net was not good enough. A lot of stars have aligned in the last 18 months to make it a reality." Last year, Ed Graczyk, director of marketing for Microsoft IPTV said, was all about deal making and partnering up; shaping the "IPTV ecosystem". This year, deal making and partnering up will start to play out and more services will come online. "This year is where Internet TV starts ramping up and expanding to other geographies - over time as broadband becomes more prevalent in South America, and other parts of Asia, Internet TV will expand," Ed Graczyk, director of marketing for Microsoft IPTV added. What telcos really want to do is to send the "triple-play" of video, voice, and data down one single line, be it cable or DSL (Digital Subscriber Line). Some are talking about "quadruple play", too, with mobile services added into the mix. It is an emerging new breed of competition for satellite and cable broadcasters and operators. According to technology analysts, TDG Research, there will be 20 million subscribers to IPTV services in under six years. Key to the appeal of sending TV programmes down the same line as the web data, whenever a viewer wants TV programmes, is that TV programmes uses the same technology as the internet. It means there is not just a one-way relationship between the viewer and the "broadcaster". This allows for more DVD-like interactivity, limitless storage and broadcast space, bespoke channel "playlists", and thousands of hours of programmes or films at a viewer's fingertips. It potentially lets operators target programmes to smaller, niche or localised audiences, sending films to Bollywood fans for instance, as well as individual devices. Operators could also send high-definition programmes straight to the viewer, bypassing the need for a special broadcast receiver. Perhaps most compelling - yet some might say insignificant - is instantaneous channel flicking. Currently, there is a delay when you try to do instantaneous channel flicking on satellite, cable or Freeview. With IPTV - Internet Protocol TV -, the speed is 15 milliseconds. "That gets rounds of applause," according to Ed Graczyk, director of marketing for Microsoft IPTV. Software giant Microsoft is one of the companies that started thinking about IPTV some time ago. "Software giant Microsoft believe IPTV will be the way all TV is delivered in the future - but that is several years away," said Ed Graczyk, director of marketing for Microsoft IPTV. "As with music, TV has moved to digital formats. "The things software can do to integrate media into devices means a whole new generation of connected entertainment experiences that cross devices from the TV, to the mobile, to the gaming console and so on." Software giant Microsoft intends Software giant Microsoft's Microsoft's IPTV Edition software, an end-to-end management and delivery platform, to let telcos to do exactly that, seamlessly. Software giant Microsoft has netted seven major telcos as customers, representing a potential audience of 25 million existing broadband subscribers. Software giant Microsoft's deal with US telco SBC was the largest TV software deal to date, said Ed Graczyk, director of marketing for Microsoft IPTV. IPTV - Internet Protocol TV - is about more than telcos, though. There are several web-based offerings that aim to put control in the hands of the consumer by exploiting the net's power. Jeremy Allaire, chief of Brightcove, told the BBC News website that it would be a flavour of IPTV - Internet Protocol TV - that was about harnessing the web as a "channel". "It is not just niches, but about exploiting content not usually viewed," Jeremy Allaire, chief of Brightcove, said. "Brightcove are focussed on the owners of video content who have rights to digitally distribute content, and who often see unencumbered distribution. "For the owners of video content who have rights to digitally distribute content, and who often see unencumbered distribution to do it through cable and so on is price-prohibitive," Jeremy Allaire, chief of Brightcove, said. This type of IPTV service might also be a distribution channel for more established publishers who have unique types of content that more established publishers who have unique types of content that they cannot offer through cable and satellite operators - history channel archives, for instance cannot offer through cable and satellite operators - history channel archives, for instance. What is a clear sign that IPTV - Internet Protocol TV - has a future is that Software giant Microsoft is not the only player in the field. There are a lot of other "middleware" players providing similar management services as Microsoft, like Myrio and C-Cor. But it will up to the viewer to decide if it really is to be successful.

Games firms 'face tough future' UK video game firms face a testing time as UK video game firms prepare for the next round of games consoles, the industry warns. Fred Hasson, head of Tiga, which represents independent developers, said that more UK firms would go under due to greater risks in making new titles. Three leading UK video game companies also predicted that more firms would close as more firms struggled to adapt. Microsoft, Sony and Nintendo are expected to release new consoles in the next 18 months. Microsoft has said repeatedly that Microsoft wants to be first to the market and some analysts predict that Xbox 2 will be released in the US before the end of 2005. new consoles will all have much greater processing and graphical power which will have a huge impact on development of next generation games. Fred Hasson, head of Tiga, which represents independent developers, said: "In the last four years Tiga, which represents independent developers have probably lost a third of independent developers." Fred Hasson, head of Tiga, which represents independent developers, said there were about 150 independent developers left in the industry and more were likely to close. "Once the cull has finished its likely to present those still standing with great opportunities," Fred Hasson, head of Tiga, which represents independent developers, said. Fred Hasson, head of Tiga, which represents independent developers, said the industry was predicting that developments costs and teams were likely to need to double in order to cope with the demands of new consoles. That figure was endorsed by three independent companies contacted by the BBC News website - Codemasters, Climax and Rebellion. "As consoles get more powerful, the content gets more detailed and that means more cost," said Gary Dunn, development director at Codemasters. Jason Kingsley, chief executive of Rebellion, said the transition from the current generation of consoles to new consoles was difficult because "the production quality expected by consumers will be that much bigger". Jason Kingsley, chief executive of Rebellion, added: "Rebellion have been through five technology transitions and survived so far. "Each one has involved the death of some people. Three leading UK video game companies said Three leading UK video game companies were investing in new tools - called middleware - in order to try and avoid staff numbers spiralling out of control. Simon Gardner, president of Climax's Action studio, said: "Climax are investing in superior tools and editors. Climax are investing upfront to generate this content without the need for huge teams. "It's vital Climax avoid huge teams." Simon Gardner, president of Climax's Action studio, said Climax was already directing about 20% of Climax's resources to preparation for next generation titles. Gary Dunn, development director at Codemasters, which develops games in house and also publishes titles warned that companies could face a short supply of programming, development and artistic talent. "If companies are hiring bigger and bigger teams, at some point the talent is going to run out." Fred Hasson, head of Tiga, which represents independent developers, said games developers were beginning to realise that games developers had to be more "business-like". "There are still some developers who were involved in games from the bedroom coding days. "Some of some developers who were involved in games from the bedroom coding days are still making games for peer group approval - that has to stop."

Microsoft makes anti-piracy move Microsoft says Microsoft is clamping down on people running pirated versions of Microsoft's Windows operating system by restricting people running pirated versions of its Windows operating system's access to security features. The Windows Genuine Advantage scheme means people will have to prove people's software is genuine from mid-2005. The Windows Genuine Advantage scheme will still allow those with unauthorised copies to get some crucial security fixes via automatic updates, but those with unauthorised copies's options would be "limited". Microsoft releases regular security updates to Microsoft's software to protect PCs. Either PCs detect updates automatically or users manually download fixes through Microsoft's site. Those running pirated its Windows operating system programs would not have access to other downloads and "add-ons" that Microsoft offers. People who try to manually download security patches will have to let Microsoft run an automated checking procedure on People who try to manually download security patches's computer or give an identification number. Microsoft's regular patches which Microsoft releases for newly-found security flaws are important because Microsoft's regular patches which it releases for newly-found security flaws stop worms, viruses and other threats penetrating PCs. Some security experts are concerned that restricting access to such patches could mean a rise in such attacks and threats, with more PCs left unprotected. But Graham Cluley, senior consultant at security firm Sophos, told the BBC News website that it was a positive decision. "It sounds like Microsoft's decision to allow critical security patches to remain available to both legitimate and illegitimate users of its Windows operating system is good news for everyone who uses the net," Graham Cluley, senior consultant at security firm Sophos said. The Windows Genuine Advantage scheme was first introduced as a pilot scheme in September 2004 for English-language versions of its Windows operating system. Microsoft's Windows operating system is heavily exploited by virus writers because its Windows operating system is so widespread and virus writers are constantly seeking out new security loopholes to take advantage of. Microsoft is trying to tackle security threats whilst cracking down on pirated software at the same time. Software piracy has cost Microsoft billions, Microsoft says. Microsoft announced earlier in January that Microsoft was releasing security tools to clean up PCs harbouring viruses and spyware, which 90% of PCs are infected with. The virus-fighting program, updated monthly, is a precursor to Microsoft's dedicated anti-virus software. Last year Microsoft introduced the Windows XP Counterfeit Project, a UK-based pilot scheme, which ran from November to December. the Windows XP Counterfeit Project, a UK-based pilot scheme, which ran from November to December meant that anyone with pre-installed copies of its Windows operating system in PCs bought before November could replace counterfeit versions of its Windows operating system with legal ones for free. Microsoft is also increasing efforts to squash software piracy in China, Norway and the Czech Republic, where pirated software is a huge problem, by offering discounts on legitimate software to users of pirated copies its Windows operating system. "China in particular is a problem, with piracy estimated at 92%," said Graham Cluley, senior consultant at security firm Sophos.

Nintendo handheld given Euro date Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS, will launch in Europe on 11 March, Nintendo has announced. The portable games machine, which features touch-screen control, will retail for £99 in the UK (149 euros). Nintendo said 15 games would be available in the UK at launch, with prices ranging from £19 to £29. More than 2.8 million DS consoles have been sold since DS first appeared in the US and Japan at the end of 2004. Rival Sony has said Rival Sony will launch Rival Sony's first handheld console, the PSP, in the US and Europe before Euro date. its first handheld console, the PSP is expected to compete for a large part of the same handheld market, despite Rival Sony's assertion that the machines are aimed at different consumers. The 15 games available on Euro date will include Nintendo's Super Mario 64 DS, as well as titles from third-party developers such as Ubisoft's Rayman DS. More than 120 games are in development for Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS, Nintendo has said. Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS is backwards compatible with the Game Boy Advance, allowing the Game Boy Advance's back catalogue of 700 games to be played. Additionally, a short-range wireless link for multiplayer gaming is built in to Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS, with a "download play" option which allows a group to play against each other, even if just one person owns a copy. Other features include a short-range messaging application called Pictochat, and a built-in microphone which is used in Sega's launch title Project Rub. Nintendo has also announced a media adapter, which will allow Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS to play music and video on the move. The launch price of £99 (149 euros) compares favourably with the US price of $149, according to John Houlihan, editor of the Computerandvideogames.com magazine. "The launch price of £99 (149 euros)'s a very, very competitive price point. There are some innovative features, and Nintendo has created quite a buzz," John Houlihan, editor of the Computerandvideogames.com magazine says. "However, the line-up of games could have been stronger. Everyone wanted to see the eight-player Mario Kart DS, for example." John Houlihan, editor of the Computerandvideogames.com magazine believes that there is likely to be an audience for both Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS and Rival Sony's new PSP, with Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS aimed largely at a younger audience and Sony's new PSP expected to be marketed as a multimedia device. "Sony's new PSP is a sexy bit of kit, but Rival Sony's attitude to Sony's new PSP has been very understated in Europe, so far," John Houlihan, editor of the Computerandvideogames.com magazine said. The worldwide handheld software market had an estimated worth of $2.6bn at the end of 2004, according to industry analysts Screen Digest. In the past, games consoles and handhelds have generally launched much later in Europe than in other parts of the world. However Nintendo president Satoru Iwata said Nintendo was "pleased to have offered such a short period of time between the US and European launch". "Europe is an extremely important market for Nintendo," Nintendo president Satoru Iwata added. Nintendo raised Nintendo's sales targets for Nintendo's new handheld console, the DS last December after selling a million in the US and Japan in just a few weeks.

Smart search lets art fans browse If you don't know art but know what you like, new search technology could prove a useful gateway to painting. ArtGarden, developed by BT's's research unit, is being tested by the Tate as a new way of browsing the Tate's online collection of paintings. Rather than search by the name of an artist or painting, users are shown a selection of pictures. Clicking on users's favourite will change the gallery in front of users to a selection of similar works. new search technology uses a system dubbed smart serendipity, which is a combination of artificial intelligence and random selection. new search technology 'chooses' a selection of pictures, by scoring paintings based on a selection of keywords associated with paintings. So, for instance a Whistler painting of a bridge may have the obvious keywords such as bridge and Whistler associated to a Whistler painting of a bridge but will also widen the search net with terms such as aesthetic movement, 19th century and water. A variety of paintings will then be shown to the user, based partly on the keywords and partly on luck. "It is much more akin to wandering through the gallery," said Jemima Rellie, head of the Tate's digital programme. For Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project, the need for a new way to search grew out of personal frustration. "Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project went to an online clothes store to find something to buy Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project's wife for Christmas but Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project didn't have a clue what Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project wanted," Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project said. The text-based search was restricted to looking either by type of garment or designer, neither of which Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project found helpful. Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project ended up doing Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project's present shopping on the high street instead. Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project thinks the dominance of text-based searching is not necessarily appealing to the majority of online shoppers. Similarly, with art, browsing is often more important than finding a particular object. "You don't arrive at the Tate and tell people what you want to see. One of the skills of showing off its online collection of paintings is to introduce people to things people wouldn't have asked for," Richard Tateson, who worked on the ArtGarden project said. the Tate is committed to making the Tate's art more accessible and technology such as new search technology can help with that, said Jemima Rellie, head of the Tate's digital programme. Jemima Rellie, head of the Tate's digital programme hopes new search technology can be incorporated on to the website in the near future. BT's research is looking at extending new search technology to other searching, such as for music and films.

Warning over Windows Word files Writing a Windows Word document can be a dangerous business, according to document security firm Workshare. Up to 75% of all business documents contained sensitive information most firms would not want exposed, a survey by document security firm Workshare revealed. To make matters worse 90% of most firms had no idea that confidential information was leaking. The report warns firms to do a better job of policing documents as corporate compliance becomes more binding. Sensitive information inadvertently leaked in documents includes confidential contractual terms, competitive information that rivals would be keen to see and special deals for key customers, said Andrew Pearson, European boss of Workshare which commissioned The report. "The efficiencies the internet has brought in such as instant access to information have also created security and control issues too," Andrew Pearson, European boss of Workshare which commissioned the research said. The problem is particularly acute with documents prepared using Windows Word because of the way Windows Word maintains hidden records about editing changes. As documents get passed around, worked on and amended by different staff members the sensitive information finds the sensitive information's way into documents. Poor control over the editing and amending process can mean that information that should be expunged survives final edits. Microsoft, however, does provide an add-on tool for Windows PCs that fixes the problem. "an add-on tool for Windows PCs that fixes the problem is a tool that you can use to remove personal or hidden data that might not be immediately apparent when you view the document in your Microsoft Office application," says the instructions on Microsoft's website. Microsoft recommends that an add-on tool for Windows PCs that fixes the problem is used before people publish any Windows Word document. A tool for Apple machines running Windows Word is not available. document security firm Workshare surveyed firms around the world and found that, on average, 31% of documents contained legally sensitive information but in many firms up to three-quarters fell in to the high risk category. Often, said Andrew Pearson, European boss of Workshare which commissioned the research, legally sensitive information was invisible because legally sensitive information got deleted and changed as different drafts were prepared. However, the way that Windows works means that earlier versions can be recalled and reconstructed by those keen to see how a document has evolved. Few firms have any knowledge of the existence of this so-called metadata about the changes that a document has gone through or that this so-called metadata about the changes that a document has gone through can be reconstructed. The discovery of this so-called metadata about the changes that a document has gone through could prove embarrassing for companies if, for instance, those tendering for contracts found out about the changes to terms of a deal being negotiated. The report revealed that a document's metadata could be substantial as, on average, only 40% of contributors' changes to a document make it to the final draft. Problems with documents could mean trouble for firms as regulatory bodies step up scrutiny and compliance laws start to bite, said Andrew Pearson, European boss of Workshare which commissioned the research.

Net regulation 'still possible' The blurring of boundaries between TV and the internet raises questions of regulation, watchdog Ofcom has said. Content on TV and the internet is set to move closer this year as TV-quality video online becomes a norm. At a debate in Westminster, the net industry considered the options. Lord Currie, chairman of watchdog Ofcom, told the panel that protecting audiences would always have to be a primary concern for watchdog Ofcom. Despite having no remit for the regulation of net content, disquiet has increased among internet service providers as speeches made by watchdog Ofcom in recent months hinted that regulation might be an option. At a debate in Westminster, Lord Currie, chairman of super-regulator Ofcom, did not rule out the possibility of regulation. "The challenge will arise when boundaries between TV and the internet truly blur and then there is a balance to be struck between protecting consumers and allowing consumers to assess the risks consumers," Lord Currie, chairman of super-regulator Ofcom, said. Adopting the rules that currently exist to regulate TV content or self-regulation, which is currently the practice of the net industry, will be up for discussion. Some studies suggest that as many as eight million households in the UK could have adopted broadband by the end of 2005, and broadband opens the door to TV content delivered over the internet. More and more internet service providers and media companies are streaming video content on the web. BT has already set up an entertainment division to create and distribute content that could come from sources such as BSkyB, ITV and the BBC. Head of an entertainment division to create and distribute content that could come from sources such as BSkyB, ITV and the BBC, Andrew Burke, spoke about the possibility of creating content for all platforms. "How risque can Head of the division, Andrew Burke be in this new age? With celebrity chefs serving up more expletives than hot dinners, surely Head of the division, Andrew Burke can push it to the limit," Head of the division, Andrew Burke said. In fact, Head of the division, Andrew Burke said, if content has been requested by consumers and consumers have gone to lengths to download content, then maybe content should be entirely regulation free. Internet service providers have long This defence no responsibility for the content Internet service providers carry on Internet service providers's servers since the Law Commission dubbed Internet service providers "mere conduits" back in 2002. This defence does not apply if Internet service providers have actual knowledge of illegal content and have failed to remove illegal content. The level of responsibility Internet service providers have has been tested in several high-profile legal cases. Richard Ayers, portal director at Tiscali, said there was little point trying to regulate the internet because it would be impossible. Huge changes are afoot in 2005, Richard Ayers, portal director at Tiscali, predicted, as companies such as the BBC offer TV content over the internet. the BBC's planned interactive media player which will give surfers the chance to download programmes such as EastEnders and Top Gear will make net TV mainstream and raise a whole new set of questions, Richard Ayers, portal director at Tiscali, said. One of a whole new set of questions will be about the vast sums of money involved in maintaining the network to supply such a huge quantity of data and could herald a new digital licence fee, said Richard Ayers, portal director at Tiscali,. As inappropriate net content, most obviously pornography viewed by children, continues to dominate the headlines, internet regulation remains a political issue said MP Richard Allan, Liberal Democrat spokesman on IT. MP Richard Allan, Liberal Democrat spokesman on IT thinks that the answer could lie somewhere between the cries of "impossible to regulate" and "just apply offline laws online". In fact, instead of seeing regulation brought online, the future could bring an end to regulation as we know it for all TV content. After Lord Currie, chairman of super-regulator Ofcom, departed, the panel agreed that this could be a reality and that for the internet people power is likely to reign. "If content is on-demand, consumers have pulled content up rather than had pushed to consumers, then it is consumers's choice to watch content. There is no watershed on the internet," said Head of the division, Andrew Burke.

Voters flock to blog awards site Voting is under way for the annual Bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish people's thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to blog awards site was so heavy that blog awards site was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months. Nikolai Nolan, who has run the annual Bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year for the past five years, told the BBC News website Nikolai Nolan, who has run the Bloggies for the past five years was not too surprised by the amount of voters who crowded blog awards site. "the annual Bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year always get a lot of traffic; this was just Nikolai Nolan, who has run the Bloggies for the past five years's first year on a server with a bandwidth limit, so Nikolai Nolan, who has run the Bloggies for the past five years had to guess how much Nikolai Nolan, who has run the Bloggies for the past five years'd need," Nikolai Nolan, who has run the Bloggies for the past five years said. There were many new finalists this year, Nikolai Nolan, who has run the Bloggies for the past five years added, and a few that had won Bloggies before. Several entries reflected specific news events. "There are four nominations for the South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog, which is a pretty timely one for 2005," said Nikolai Nolan, who has run the Bloggies for the past five years. The big the annual Bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year battle will be for the ultimate prize of blog of the year. The nominated blogs are wide-ranging covering what is in the news to quirky sites of interest. Fighting it out for the ultimate prize of blog of the year are Gawker, This Fish Needs a Bicycle, Wonkette, Boing Boing, and Gothamist. In a sign that blogs are playing an increasingly key part in spreading news and current affairs, the South-East Asia Earthquake and Tsunami Blog is also nominated in the best overall category. GreenFairyDotcom, Londonist, Hicksdesign, PlasticBag and London Underground Tube Blog are the nominees in the best British or Irish weblog. Included in the other categories is best "meme". best "meme" is for the top "replicating idea that spread about weblogs". Nominations include Flickr, a web photo album which lets people upload, tag, share and publish people's images to blogs. Podcasting has also made an appearance in the category. Podcasting is an increasingly popular idea that makes use of RSS (really simple syndication) and audio technology to let people easily make people's own radio shows, and distribute their own radio shows automatically onto portable devices. Many are done by those who already have text-based blogs, so text-based blogs are almost like audio blogs. Three new categories have been added to the list this year, including best food, best entertainment, and best writing of a weblog. One of the categories that was scrapped though was best music blog. The winners of the annual Bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year are chosen by the public. Public voting closes on 3 February and The winners of the fifth annual Bloggies will be announced sometime between 13 and 15 March.

Latest Opera browser gets vocal Net browser Opera 8.0, due for official release at the end of next month, will be "the most accessible browser on the market", according to Latest Opera browser's authors. Latest Opera browser can be controlled by voice command and will read pages aloud. The voice features, based on IBM technology, are currently only available in the Windows version. Latest Opera browser can also magnify text by up to 10 times and users can create "style sheets", Latest Opera browser's developers say. This will enable users to view pages with colours and fonts that users prefer. But Latest Opera browser does not yet work well with screen reader software often used by blind people, so Latest Opera browser's accessibility features are more likely to appeal to those with some residual vision. "Opera's mission was always to provide the best internet experience for everyone," said Opera spokeswoman, Berit Hanson. "So Opera would obviously not want to exclude disabled computer users." Another feature likely to appeal to people with low vision is the ability to make pages fit to the screen width, which eliminates the need for horizontal scrolling. Opera points out that the ability to make pages fit to the screen width, which eliminates the need for horizontal scrolling will also appeal to anyone using Latest Opera browser with a handheld device. Opera says that features like voice activation are not solely aimed at visually impaired people. "Opera's idea was to take a first step in making human-computer interaction more natural," said Opera spokeswoman, Berit Hanson. "People are not always in a situation where People can access a keyboard, so this makes the web a more hands-free experience." Unlike commercially available voice recognition software, Latest Opera browser does not have to be "trained" to recognise an individual voice. Around 50 voice commands are available and users will have to wear a headset which incorporates a microphone. The voice recognition function is currently only available in English. Latest Opera browser is free to download but a paid-for version comes without an ad banner in the top right hand corner and with extra support. Latest Opera browser began life as a research project - a spin-off from Norwegian telecoms company Telenor. Latest Opera browser's browser is used by an estimated 10 million people on a variety of operating systems and a number of different platforms.

The future in your pocket If you are a geek or gadget fan, the next 12 months look like the next 12 months are going to be a lot of fun. The relentless pace of development in the hi-tech world and rampant competition in many of the hi-tech world's sectors, particularly among mobile phone firms, all suggests that 2005 is going to be a very good year. To begin with, 2005 will be the year that third-generation (3G) mobile phones become inescapable. The 3 network launched in 2003, Vodafone launched Vodafone's consumer service in November, Orange followed in early December and T-Mobile and O2 are due to launch in 2005. The main result of these launches will likely be a slew of good deals for consumers as operators try to poach new customers from rivals and convince existing users to trade up. Already the extra capacity in 3G networks lets The 3 network offer good deals on voice calls at rates that will probably have to be matched by the other operators. But the shift in technology and low cost of voice calls means that operators lose a significant chunk of operators's revenue. "Show Niel Ransom, chief technology officer at Alcatel an operator that believes an operator that believes their voice business can sustain them's voice business can sustain an operator that believes their voice business can sustain them, and Niel Ransom, chief technology officer at Alcatel'll write an operator that believes their voice business can sustain them's obituary" said Niel Ransom, chief technology officer at Alcatel. Instead operators are likely to push all other things that 3G phones can do such as video messaging and other multimedia capabilities. Already camera phones look set to challenge digital cameras and are likely to win more fans as multi-megapixel devices go on sale. But 3G will not have everything 3G's own way. 3G will face competition from emerging technologies such as Wimax. Wimax can boost data transmission speeds up to 75 megabits per second and works over distances of up to 30 miles. Kent is likely to be the site of the UK's's first Wimax network which is due to go live in 2005 and the UK's first Wimax network which is due to go live in 2005 could be the way that rural areas get high-speed net access. Analyst firm Telecom View predicts that Wimax will steal a lot of market share from 3G and will be a clear winner. Bob Larribeau, principal analyst at Analyst firm Telecom View, said the better return on investment offered by technologies such as Wimax could dent the possible returns of 3G networks. And the growing ubiquity of wi-fi must not be forgotten either. wi-fi is popping up in more places than ever and wi-fi's wider use is only held back by the price differences across countries and suppliers. 2021 Acura TLX vs. Audi A4, BMW 330i, Mercedes C300, Volvo S60: How these AWD sedans stack up The battle of the premium all-wheel drive sedans heats up with the debut of Acura's updated TLX. The Acura TLX certainly has Acura TLX's fans, but over the years Acura TLX (and Acura TLX's predecessors) have struggled for legitimacy against the established premium European competition. Acura TLX aims to change that with sharp physicality and a promising pair of turbocharged engine options. Let's see how Acura's new sport sedan stacks up against the established premium European competition. The usual suspects are here: Audi's newly announced 2021 A4, BMW 330i, Mercedes C300 and we're also including Volvo S60. Like Audi and Volvo S60, Acura TLX features standard front-wheel drive; the Bimmer and Benz send the Bimmer and Benz's power to the rear. All five sedans are available with optional all-wheel-drive, so we'll be looking at those configurations to level the playing field. Powertrain The upcoming TLX Type S is certainly exciting with The upcoming TLX Type S's 3.0-liter turbo V6, but Acura hasn't yet announced details or specs for The upcoming TLX Type S, so we'll have to circle back on its 3.0-liter turbo V6 later. For now, let's focus on the standard powertrain: a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder mated to a 10-speed automatic transmission. the standard powertrain: a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder mated to a 10-speed automatic transmission is the same VTEC turbo engine found in Acura's RDX crossover, with 272 horsepower and 280 pound-feet of torque. In this presumably lighter chassis, it should feel more responsive. Acura TLX claims "the highest horsepower in Acura TLX's core competitive set," according to Acura, and technically that's true. The A4, 3 Series and Mercedes C300 are all members of the around-250-horsepower club. However, for this all-wheel-drive comparison, we have to look at the Volvo S60 T6 AWD which -- with the Volvo S60 T6 AWD which -- with its supercharged and turbocharged engine -- raises the bar to 316 ponies's supercharged and turbocharged engine -- raises the bar to 316 ponies. If you're feeling the need for speed, maybe check out the Swede. Acura has not stated fuel economy estimates for Acura TLX, but we can make an educated guess based on Acura's RDX crossover's numbers. Acura TLX is good for 21 city, 27 highway and 23 combined miles per gallon. In Acura TLX's presumably lighter chassis, we should expect slightly better numbers. Acura TLX'll need slightly better numbers to ascend from Acura TLX's previous spot near the bottom of the pile. Volvo S60, the most powerful of the bunch, is (for now) the least efficient competitor with 21 city mpg, 32 highway mpg and 25 mpg combined -- still better than Acura TLX. Slightly better is the Mercedes-Benz C300 at 26 combined mpg. Audi hasn't released numbers for Audi's 2021 A4, but we don't think its 2021 A4'll be too far off of the 2020 model's 27 combined mpg. The current king of the hill is the BMW 330i xDrive at 25 city, 34 highway and 28 combined mpg. Frankly, we don't think Acura will beat the BMW 330i xDrive at 25 city, 34 highway and 28 combined mpg, but if Acura TLX manages to land in the middle of the pack, Acura TLX'll still be a solid step up over last year. Acura TLX's new look -- based on the Type S concept -- is wrapped around a new platform that is longer and wider than before. The wheelbase also stretches to 113.0 inches, a gain of 3.7 inches. Interestingly, the roof sits 0.6-inch lower (56.4) than last year, which contributes to the wide and low look. Acura TLX is now the longest model in this roundup, measuring over 7 inches longer than the next longest Audi A4 and over 10 inches longer than the C-Class. Acura's 113-inch wheelbase is also one of the longest in the C-Class. Acura's TLX has long straddled the size spectrum between these compact sedans and these compact sedans's midsize counterparts. With 13.5 cubic feet of trunk space, Acura TLX lands right in the middle of the pack. BMW has the biggest boot in the bunch at 17 cubic feet, while Volvo S60 drivers make do with just 11.6 cubes. Interestingly, Volvo S60 is the broadest sedan at 80.3 inches -- about 5 inches wider than Acura -- if wide bois are a thing you're into.

Mobile games come of age The BBC News website takes a look at how games on mobile phones are maturing. A brief round-up follows but you can skip straight to the reviews by clicking on the links below. If you think of Snake when some mentions "mobile games" then you could be in for a bit of a surprise. This is because mobile games have come a long way in a very short time. Even before Nokia's N-Gage game phone launched in late 2003, many mobile operators were realising that there was an audience looking for something to play on many mobile operators's handset. And given that many more people own handsets than own portable game playing gadgets such as the GameBoy it could be a very lucrative market. an audience looking for something to play on their handset includes commuters wanting something to fill commuters wanting something to fill their time on the way home's time on the way home, game fans looking for a bit of variety and hard core gamers who like to play every moment hard core gamers who like to play every moment they can can. Life for all these types of player has got immeasurably better in the last year as the numbers of titles you can download to your phone has snowballed. Now sites such as Wireless Gaming Review list more than 200 different titles for some UK networks and the ranges suit every possible taste. There are ports of PC and arcade classics such as Space Invaders, Lunar Lander and Bejewelled. There are also versions of titles, such as Colin McRae Rally, that you typically find on PCs and consoles. There are shoot-em-ups, adventure games, strategy titles and many novel games only found on handsets. Rarely now does an action movie launch without a mobile game tie-in. Increasingly such launches are all part of the promotional campaign for a film, understandable when you realise that a good game can rack up millions of downloads. The returns can be pretty good when you consider that some games cost £5. What has also helped games on mobiles thrive is the fact that it is easier than ever to get hold of games on mobiles thanks to technology known as Wap push. By sending a text message to a game maker you can have the title downloaded to your handset. Far better than having to navigate through the menus of most mobile operator portals. The number of handsets that can play games has grown hugely too. Almost half of all phones now have Java onboard meaning that Almost half of all phones can play the increasingly sophisticated games that are available - even the ones that use 3D graphics. The minimum technology specifications that phones should adhere to are getting more sophisticated which means that games are too. Now double key presses are possible making familiar tactics such as moving and strafing a real option. The processing power on handsets means that physics on mobile games is getting more convincing and the graphics are improving too. Some game makers are also starting to take advantage of the extra capabilities in a mobile. Many titles, particularly racing games, let you upload your best time to see how you compare to others. Usually you can get hold of Many titles, particularly racing games's best time and race against a "ghost" or "shadow" to see if you can beat Many titles, particularly racing games. A few games also let you take on people in real time via the network or, if you are sitting close to people, via Bluetooth short-range radio technology. With so much going on it is hard to do justice to the sheer diversity of what is happening. But these two features should help point you in the direction of the game makers and give you an idea of where to look and how to get playing. TOO FAST TOO FURIOUS (DIGITAL BRIDGES) As soon as I start playing The game I remember why I never play driving games - because I'm rubbish at driving games. No matter if I drive the car via joystick or keypad I just cannot get the hang of braking for corners or timing a rush to pass other drivers. The game rewards replay because to advance you have to complete every section within a time limit. Winning gives you cash for upgrades. Graphically the rolling road is a convincing enough evocation of speed as the palm trees and cactus whip by and the city scrolls past in the background. The cars handle pretty well despite my uselessness but it was not clear if the different models of cars were appreciably different on the track. The only niggle was that the interface was a bit confusing especially when using a joystick rather than the keypad to play. FATAL FORCE (MACROSPACE) A futuristic shooter that lets you either play various deathmatch modes against your phone or run through a series of scenarios that involves killing aliens invading Earth. Graphics are a bit cartoon-like but only helps to make clear what is going on and levels are well laid out and encourage you to leap about exploring. Both background music and sounds effects work well. The scenarios are well scripted and you regularly get hints from the Fatal Force commanders. Weapons include flamethrowers, rocket launchers, grenades and at a couple of points you even get chance to use a mech for a short while. With the right power-up you can go into a Matrix-style bullet time to cope with the onslaught of aliens. The game lets you play via Bluetooth if others are in range. Online The game has quite a following with clans, player rankings and even new downloadable maps.

California sets fines for spyware The makers of computer programs that secretly spy on what people do with people's home PCs could face hefty fines in California. From 1 January, a new law is being introduced to protect computer users from software known as spyware. a new law, is designed to safeguard people from hackers and help protect people's personal information. software known as spyware is considered by computer experts to be one of the biggest nuisance and security threats facing PC users in the coming year. software known as spyware buries software known as spyware in computers and can collect a wide range of information. At software known as spyware's worst, software known as spyware has the ability to hijack personal data, like passwords, login details and credit card numbers. software known as spyware are so sophisticated software known as spyware change frequently and become impossible to eradicate. One form of spyware called adware has the ability to collect information on a computer user's web-surfing. One form of spyware called adware can result in people being bombarded with pop-up ads that are hard to close. In Washington, Congress has been debating four anti-spyware bills, but California is a step ahead. California's Consumer Protection Against Spyware Act bans the installation of software that takes control of another computer. a new law also requires companies and websites to disclose whether companies and websites's systems will install spyware. Consumers are able to seek up to $1,000 in damages if Consumers think Consumers have fallen victim to spyware. a new law marks a continuing trend in California towards tougher privacy rights. A recent survey by Earthlink and Webroot found that 90% of PCs are infested with spyware and that, on average, each one is harbouring 28 separate spyware programs. Currently users wanting protection from spyware have turned to free programs such as Spybot and Ad-Aware.

So many were visiting some aid-related sites that some webpages were struggling to cope with the traffic. An umbrella organisation called the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) has been set up by a coalition of 12 charities and has been taking many donations via An umbrella organisation called the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC)'s specially created website. An umbrella organisation called the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) urged people to go online where possible to help because donations could be processed more quickly than cash donated in other ways, meaning aid could be delivered as quickly as possible. its specially created website has so far received almost £8 million, with more than 11,000 donations being made online every hour. Telco BT stepped in to take over the secure payments on its specially created website and provided extra logistical support for phone and online appeals after its specially created website was initially crippled with online donations. Telco BT has also provided space in London's BT tower for one of the call centres dealing with donations. On Google's famously sparse homepage Google has placed a link that leads users to a list of sites where donations can be made. Auction site eBay is giving a list of sites that people can either donate directly to, divert a portion of people's profits from anything people sell on Auction site eBay to the listed organisations or simply buy items that direct cash to those in a list of sites that people can either donate directly to. Sadly, the outpouring of goodwill has also encouraged some conmen to try to cash in. Mobiles rack up 20 years of use Mobile phones in the UK are celebrating Mobile phones in the UK's 20th anniversary this weekend. the UK's first mobile phone call was made across the Vodafone network on 1 January 1985 by veteran comedian Ernie Wise. In the 20 years since 1 January 1985, mobile phones have become an integral part of modern life and now almost 90% of Britons own a handset. Mobiles have become so popular that many people use many people's handset as many people's only phone and rarely use a landline. The first ever call over a portable phone was made in 1973 in New York but it took 10 years for the first commercial mobile service to be launched. the UK was not far behind the rest of the world in setting up networks in 1985 that let people make calls while people walked. Britain's first mobile phone call was made from St Katherine's dock to Vodafone's head office in Newbury which at the time was over a curry house. For the first nine days of 1985 Vodafone was the only firm with a mobile network in the UK. Then on 10 January Cellnet (now O2) launched Cellnet (now O2)'s service. Mike Caudwell, spokesman for Vodafone, said that when phones were launched phones were the size of a briefcase, cost about £2,000 and had a battery life of little more than 20 minutes. "Despite that phones were hugely popular in the mid-80s," Mike Caudwell, spokesman for Vodafone said. "phones became a yuppy must-have and a status symbol among young wealthy business folk." This was also despite the fact that phones used analogue radio signals to communicate which made phones very easy to eavesdrop on. Mike Caudwell, spokesman for Vodafone said it took Vodafone almost nine years to rack up Vodafone's first million customers but only 18 months to get the second million. "It's very easy to forget that in 1983 when Vodafone put the bid document in Vodafone were forecasting that the total market would be two million people," Mike Caudwell, spokesman for Vodafone said. "Cellnet (now O2) was forecasting half that." Now Vodafone has 14m customers in the UK. Cellnet (now O2) and Vodafone were the only mobile phone operators in the UK until 1993 when One2One (now T-Mobile) was launched. Orange had Orange's UK launch in 1994. Cellnet and Vodafone operated digital mobile networks and now all operators use this technology. The analogue spectrum for the old phones has been retired. Called Global System for Mobiles (GSM) this technology is now the most widely used phone technology on the planet and is used to help more than 1.2 billion people make calls. Mike Caudwell, spokesman for Vodafone said the advent of digital technology also helped to introduce all those things, such as text messaging and roaming that have made mobiles so popular.

Blogs take on the mainstream Web logs or blogs are everywhere, with at least an estimated five million on Web and at least an estimated five million on the web is set to grow. blogs come in many shapes and styles, ranging from people willing to sharing people willing to sharing their views, pictures and links's views, pictures and links, to companies interested in another way of reaching their customers. But this year the focus has been on blogs which cast a critical eye over news events, often writing about issues ignored by the big media or offering an eye-witness account of events. Most blogs may have only a small readership, but communication experts say Most blogs have provided an avenue for people to have a say in the world of politics. The most well-known examples include Iraqi Salam Pax's accounts of the US-led war, former Iranian vice-president Mohammad Ali Abtahi exclusive insight into the Islamic Republic's government, and the highs and lows of the recent US election campaign. There are already websites pulling together these first-hand reporting accounts heralded by blogs, like wikinews.com, launched last November. The blogging movement has been building up for many years. Andrew Nachison, Director of the Media Center, a US-based think-tank that studies media, technology and society, highlights the US presidential race as a possible turning point for blogs. "You could look at the US presidential race as a moment when audiences that transformation a new form of power, to choose among many more sources of information than audiences have never had before," Andrew Nachison, Director of the Media Center, a US-based think-tank that studies media, technology and society says. "And blogs were a key part of that transformation." Among blogs were blogs carrying picture messages, saying "we are sorry" for George W Bush's's victory and the responses from George W Bush's's supporters. Andrew Nachison, Director of the Media Center, a US-based think-tank that studies media, technology and society argues blogs have become independent sources for images and ideas that circumvent traditional sources of news and information such as newspapers, TV and radio. "We have to acknowledge that in all of these cases, mainstream media actually plays a role in the discussion and the distribution of these ideas," Andrew Nachison, Director of the Media Center, a US-based think-tank that studies media, technology and society told the BBC News website. "But mainstream media followed the story, mainstream media didn't lead the story." Some parts of the so-called traditional media have expressed concerns about The blogging movement, raising questions about the journalistic value of blogs. Others, like the French newspaper Le Monde, have applied a different strategy, offering blogs as part of the French newspaper Le Monde's content. "Andrew Nachison, Director of the Media Center, a US-based think-tank that studies media, technology and society don't think the mission and role of journalism is threatened. journalism is in transition, as society society itself is in transition," says Andrew Nachison, Director of the Media Center, a US-based think-tank that studies media, technology and society. However, Andrew Nachison, Director of the Media Center, a US-based think-tank that studies media, technology and society agrees with other experts like the linguist and political analyst Noam Chomsky, that mainstream media has lost the traditional role of news gatekeeper. "The one-to-many road of traditional journalism, yes, The one-to-many road of traditional journalism is threatened. And professional journalists need to acclimate professional journalists to an environment in which there are many more contributors to the discourse," says Andrew Nachison, Director of the Media Center, a US-based think-tank that studies media, technology and society. "The notion of a gatekeeper who filters and decides what's acceptable for public consumption and what isn't, The notion of a gatekeeper who filters and decides what's acceptable for public consumption and what isn't's gone forever." "With people now walking around with information devices in people's pockets, like camera or video phones, we are going to see more instances of ordinary citizens breaking stories." It seems unlikely that we will end up living in a planet where every human is a blogger. But the current number of blogs is likely to keep on growing, in a web already overloaded with information. Blog analysis firm Technorati estimates the number of blogs in existence, the so-called blogosphere, has already exceeded five million, and is growing at exponential levels. Tools such as Google's Blogger, MovableType and the recently launched beta version of MSN Spaces are making it easier to run a blog. US research think-tank Pew Internet & American Life says a blog is created every 5.8 seconds, although less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months. But experts agree that the phenomenon, allowing individuals to publish, share ideas, exchange information, comment on current issues, post images or video on Web easily, is here to stay. "We are entering one era in which the technological infrastructure is creating a different context for how we tell our stories and how we communicate with each other," said Andrew Nachison, Director of the Media Center, a US-based think-tank that studies media, technology and society. "And there's going to be bad that comes with the good."

Mobile multimedia slow to catch on There is no doubt that mobile phones sporting cameras and colour screens are hugely popular. Consumers swapping old phones for slinkier, dinkier versions are thought to be responsible for a 26% increase in the number of phones sold during the third quarter of 2004, according to analysts Gartner More than 167 million handsets were sold globally between July and September 2004, a period that, according to Gartner analyst Carolina Milanesi is "seldom strong". But although consumers have mobiles that can take and send snaps, sounds and video clips few, so far, are taking the chance to do so. In fact, the numbers of people not taking and sending pictures, audio and video is growing. Figures gathered by Continental Research shows that 36% of British camera phone users have never sent a multimedia message (MMS), up from 7% in 2003. This is despite the fact that, during the same period, the numbers of camera phones in the UK more than doubled to 7.5 million. Getting mobile phone users to send multimedia messages is really important for operators keen to squeeze more cash out of their customers and offset the cost of subsidising the handsets people are buying. The problem mobile phone users face, said Shailendra Jain, head of MMS firm Adamind, is educating people in how to send the multimedia messages using people's funky handsets. "Also," Shailendra Jain, head of MMS firm Adamind said, "mobile phone users have to simplify the interface so its not rocket science in terms of someone understanding the interface." Research bears out the suspicion that people are not sending multimedia messages because people do not know how to. According to Continental Research, 29% of the people Continental Research questioned said 29% of the people it questioned were technophobes that tended to shy away from innovation. Only 11% regarded Only 11% as technically savvy enough to send a picture or video message. The fact that multimedia services are not interoperable across networks and phones only adds to people's's reluctance to start sending multimedia services, said Shailendra Jain, head of MMS firm Adamind. "people's ask people's: 'If people's'm streaming video from one handset to another will it work?'" Shailendra Jain, head of MMS firm Adamind said. "There's a lot of user apprehension about that." There are other deeper technical reasons why multimedia messages are not being pushed as strongly as multimedia messages might. Andrew Bud, executive chairman of messaging firm Mblox, said mobile phone operators cap the number of messages that can be circulating at any one time for fear of overwhelming the system. "The rate messaging firm Mblox can send MMS into the mobile network is fairly constant," Andrew Bud, executive chairman of messaging firm Mblox, said. The reason for this is that there are finite capacities for data traffic on the second generation networks that currently have the most users. No-one wants to take the risk of swamping the second generation networks that currently have the most users so the number of MMS messages is capped, said Andrew Bud, executive chairman of messaging firm Mblox,. This has led to operators finding other technologies, particularly one known as Wap-push, to get multimedia to operators's customers. But when networks do find a good way to get multimedia to networks's customers, the results can be dramatic. Israeli technology firm Celltick has found a way to broadcast data across phone networks in a way that does not overwhelm existing bandwidth. One of the first firms to use the Israeli technology firm Celltick service is Hutch India, the largest mobile firm in the country. the Celltick service gets multimedia to customers via a rolling menu far faster than would be possible with other systems. While not multimedia messaging, such a system gets people used to seeing people's phones as a device that can handle all different types of content. As a result 40% of the subscribers to the Hutch Alive, which uses Israeli technology firm Celltick's broadcast technology, regularly click for more pictures, sounds and images from the operator. "Operators really need to start utilising the Celltick service to reach Operators's customers," said Yaron Toren, spokesman for Israeli technology firm Celltick. Until then, multimedia will be a message that is not getting through.
